nodes.title: The Effect of Different Concentrations of Epinephrine in Otoendoscopic Surgery on Surgical Field Clarity: A Double-Blind, Randomized Study
nodes.summary:
evaluated the effect of different concentrations of epinephrine on surgical field clarity in otoendoscopic surgery.
Four concentration groups of epinephrine were used: 1:5000, 1:10,000, 1:20,000, and 1:40,000.
The results showed no significant difference in surgical field clarity among the four groups.
However, the higher concentration groups (1:5000 and 1:10,000) had more significant hemodynamic changes.
The lower concentration groups (1:20,000 and 1:40,000) had less impact on hemodynamics and returned to baseline levels after 30 minutes.
The study recommends using concentrations between 1:20,000 and 1:40,000 for minimal impact on hemodynamics.

nodes.title: Regulation of Hemocytes in Drosophila Requires dappled Cytochrome b5
nodes.summary:
Drosophila melanogaster is used as a model to study the regulation of hemocytes, which are similar to blood cells in humans. 
The dappled gene, which encodes cytochrome b5, is essential for regulating hemocytes. 
Mutations in the dappled gene cause melanotic tumors and misregulation of hemocytes. 
The dappled gene is involved in electron transfer reactions and is conserved across species. 
Expression of wild-type dappled in hemocytes rescues the melanotic tumor phenotype. 
Curcumin, a compound with anti-inflammatory properties, enhances the melanotic phenotype in dappled mutants. 
The study of dappled provides a tractable genetic model for understanding cytochrome b5 function in blood cells and other tissues.

nodes.title: Nutritional supplements, COX-2 and IGF-1 expression in men on active surveillance for prostate cancer
nodes.summary:
A randomized clinical trial was conducted to examine the effects of lycopene and fish oil supplements on gene expression in normal prostate tissue. 
The trial involved 97 men with low-burden prostate cancer who were on active surveillance. 
Participants were randomized to receive either lycopene, fish oil, or a placebo for 3 months. 
The primary outcomes were changes in IGF-1 and COX-2 gene expression between baseline and 3-month biopsies. 
No significant differences were found in IGF-1 or COX-2 expression between the supplement and placebo groups. 
The results suggest that 3-month intervention with lycopene or fish oil supplement had no effect on normal prostate expression of IGF-1 and COX-2.

nodes.title: Establishment and characterization of DB-1: a leptin receptor-deficient murine macrophage cell line
nodes.summary:
DB-1 is a leptin receptor-deficient murine macrophage cell line established from bone marrow cells of leptin receptor-deficient mice. 
The cell line is diploid, has a normal complement of chromosomes, and lacks the long isoform of the leptin receptor. 
DB-1 cells exhibit morphological properties characteristic of macrophages and are adherent with multiple processes. 
They display functional macrophage characteristics, including phagocytic activity and responsiveness to IFN-c and LPS stimuli. 
The cells are unresponsive to leptin and do not migrate in response to adipocyte-conditioned medium or leptin. 
DB-1 cells can serve as a tool to study the link between leptin and innate immune function, particularly in the context of obesity and inflammation. 
The cell line can be used for in vitro and in vivo studies, including adoptive transfer studies, to investigate the role of the leptin receptor in cell function.

nodes.title: Safety and Pharmacokinetics of Intranasally Administered Heparin
nodes.summary:
Intranasally administered unfractionated heparin (UFH) is a potential prophylactic for COVID-19.
The purpose of this research was to measure the safety and pharmacokinetics of UFH clearance from the nasal cavity.
Double-blinded daily intranasal dosing in mice with four doses of UFH was carried out for 14 consecutive days.
No significant changes were observed in activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT), platelet count, or frequency of minor irritant events.
In vivo imaging in a mouse model showed a single phase clearance of UFH from the nasal cavity, with 3.2% remaining after 12 hours.
The results indicate that UFH is safe for extended daily intranasal dosing in mice and humans, with potentially protective levels for up to 12 hours after dosing.

nodes.title: Lack of Norovirus Replication and Histo-Blood Group Antigen Expression in 3-Dimensional Intestinal Epithelial Cells
nodes.summary:
Noroviruses are a leading cause of gastroenteritis worldwide, but an in vitro model for their replication has been elusive. 
A previous study reported norovirus replication in a 3-dimensional intestinal epithelial cell model, but this finding could not be replicated. 
The current study used a highly purified norovirus stock and found no evidence of replication in the 3-dimensional cell model. 
Immunocytochemical analysis showed no detectable presence of histo-blood group antigens, which are necessary for norovirus binding and host tropism. 
The study suggests that the cytopathic effects observed in the previous study may have been caused by lipopolysaccharide contamination in the virus stock. 
The 3-dimensional intestinal epithelial cell model does not support norovirus replication, likely due to the lack of histo-blood group antigens on the cell surface. 
Further research is needed to develop an in vitro model that can support norovirus replication and facilitate the study of norovirus pathogenesis.

nodes.title: Physical Forces Modulate Oxidative Status and Stress Defense Meditated Metabolic Adaptation of Yeast Colonies: Spaceflight and Microgravity Simulations
nodes.summary:
Yeast colonies were grown in microgravity and simulated microgravity conditions. 
Gene expression changes were observed in response to microgravity and simulated microgravity. 
The stress response genes SSA4 and RPL34b were upregulated in microgravity. 
Microgravity increased reactive oxygen species production and apoptosis. 
The effects of microgravity on yeast colonies were distinct from those of simulated microgravity. 
Random positioning and rotation induced distinct changes in gene expression and cell death. 
The study provides insights into the effects of microgravity on cellular physiology and has implications for understanding mechanisms of drug action and cell aging.

nodes.title: Effects of liquid cultivation on gene expression and phenotype of C. elegans
nodes.summary:
Cultivating C. elegans in liquid media alters gene expression and phenotype.
The N2 and AB1 strains exhibit distinct transcriptional responses to liquid cultivation.
Environment change-induced gene expressions are transmitted to subsequent generations.
Genotype has a substantial impact on adaptive responses to environmental changes.
Functional analysis of the transcriptome correlates with phenotypic changes.
The study reveals substantial differences between N2 and AB1 strains in transcriptomic responses.
The data provides standard controls for future studies using liquid cultivation of C. elegans.

nodes.title: Immunization induces inflammation in the mouse heart during spaceflight
nodes.summary:
Immunization with tetanus toxoid and CpG adjuvant in space induces inflammation in the mouse heart.
The nuclear factor kappa B (NF-ÎºB) signaling pathway is activated, leading to the release of pro-inflammatory cytokines.
Transcriptomic changes in the heart include alterations in the cytoskeleton and expression of transcripts associated with protection from oxidative stress.
The study used RNA sequencing and bioinformatic analysis to identify differentially expressed genes and transcripts.
Immunization in space amplifies cytoskeletal rearrangements and induces transcripts that protect the heart from oxidative stress.
The findings suggest that spaceflight environment can exacerbate the risk of vaccine-induced cardiac inflammation.
The study provides a foundation for future research into the impact of immune challenges on the heart during spaceflight.

nodes.title: Multi-drug resistant Enterobacter bugandensis species isolated from the International Space Station and comparative genomic analyses with human pathogenic strains
nodes.summary:
Five Enterobacter bugandensis strains were isolated from the International Space Station (ISS) 
and their whole genome sequences were characterized using hybrid de novo assembly of Nanopore and Illumina reads. 
The ISS strains were compared with three clinical strains and showed high genome similarities. 
A total of 4733 genes were identified, with 112 genes involved in virulence, disease, and defense. 
Genes associated with resistance to antibiotics and toxic compounds were also identified. 
The ISS strains showed a 79% probability of being human pathogens and shared similar antimicrobial resistance patterns. 
The presence of multidrug resistance genes and efflux pumps renders the ISS strains resistant to various drugs. 
Further studies are required to confirm the pathogenicity of the ISS strains and explore the impact of spaceflight on their physiological traits. 
The findings have implications for crew health and safety on future space missions.

nodes.title: Modeled microgravity alters apoptotic gene expression and caspase activity in the squid-vibrio symbiosis
nodes.summary:
Modeled microgravity alters apoptotic gene expression and caspase activity in the squid-vibrio symbiosis.
The study used the Hawaiian bobtail squid, Euprymna scolopes, and the gram-negative bacterium, Vibrio fischeri, to investigate the effects of microgravity on apoptosis.
The results showed that microgravity increased the expression of apoptosis genes and caspase activity in the host squid.
The increase in caspase activity was mitigated by caspase inhibitors, suggesting that perturbations to the normal apoptosis signaling cascade can be mitigated.
The study provides new insight into the mechanisms underlying apoptotic dysregulation in response to microgravity-like stress and its potential impact on animal-microbial homeostasis during spaceflight.

nodes.title: TNO1, a TGN-localized SNARE-interacting protein, modulates root skewing in Arabidopsis thaliana
nodes.summary:
TNO1, a trans-Golgi network-localized protein, modulates root skewing in Arabidopsis thaliana.
The tno1 mutant exhibits enhanced root skewing and epidermal cell file rotation.
Root skewing in tno1 mutants is insensitive to microtubule destabilization by propyzamide.
Microtubule stabilization by taxol enhances root skewing in tno1 mutants.
The microtubule array orientation in tno1 roots is unaffected, suggesting an alternative mechanism for cell file rotation.
TNO1 may be involved in anisotropic cell expansion or cell wall trafficking dynamics.
The study suggests a link between TNO1, auxin-dependent, and microtubule-associated processes in root growth and development.

nodes.title: TNO1, a TGN-localized SNARE-interacting protein, modulates root skewing in Arabidopsis thaliana
nodes.summary:
TNO1, a trans-Golgi network-localized protein, modulates root skewing in Arabidopsis thaliana.
The tno1 mutant exhibits enhanced root skewing and epidermal cell file rotation.
Root skewing in tno1 mutants is insensitive to microtubule destabilization by propyzamide.
Microtubule stabilization by taxol enhances root skewing in tno1 mutants.
The microtubule array orientation in tno1 roots is unaffected, suggesting an alternative mechanism for cell file rotation.
TNO1 may be involved in anisotropic cell expansion or cell wall trafficking dynamics.
The study suggests a link between TNO1, auxin-dependent, and microtubule-associated processes in root growth and development.

nodes.title: Skewing in Arabidopsis roots involves disparate environmental signaling pathways
nodes.summary:
Arabidopsis roots exhibit skewing and waving when grown on a tilted surface.
Skewing is influenced by environmental signaling pathways, including sugar and salt signaling.
Transcriptome analysis identified 11 highly probable skew gene candidates (HPSGC) involved in skewing.
These genes are associated with various cellular processes, including cell wall organization and hormone signaling.
HPSGC genes show similar expression patterns, despite being part of disparate signaling pathways.
Sugar signaling is a major pathway identified in HPSGC, with genes involved in sucrose efflux and sugar transport.
Salt signaling is also represented, with genes involved in salt tolerance and sodium ion transport.
Future studies are needed to elucidate the specific roles of HPSGC in root skewing.

nodes.title: Spaceflight induces novel regulatory responses in Arabidopsis seedling as revealed by combined proteomic and transcriptomic analyses
nodes.summary:
Arabidopsis seedlings grown in microgravity exhibit novel regulatory responses.
Proteomic and transcriptomic analyses reveal differential expression of 968 genes and 210 proteins.
Post-translational modifications, including phosphorylation, play a crucial role in microgravity response.
Cell wall synthesis and auxin signaling are significantly altered in microgravity.
Plastid function and redox homeostasis are also impacted by microgravity.
The study highlights the importance of combining transcriptomic and proteomic approaches to understand plant responses to microgravity.

nodes.title: Antiviral screening of natural, antiinflammatory compound library against African swine fever virus
nodes.summary:
African swine fever virus (ASFV) is a significant threat to pig production, with no effective vaccines available. 
A library of 297 natural compounds with anti-inflammatory properties was screened for antiviral activity against ASFV. 
Five compounds, including tetrandrine and berbamine, showed significant inhibition of ASFV-induced cytopathic effect. 
Tetrandrine and berbamine exhibited high levels of anti-ASFV activity, inhibiting early stages of infection and reducing pro-inflammatory cytokine production. 
The compounds' antiviral effects were independent of host cell type or virus strain, and they demonstrated sustained activity over multiple replication cycles. 
Tetrandrine showed particularly high and sustained anti-inflammatory activity, making it a promising candidate for further development. 
Overall, the study highlights the potential of natural compounds as antiviral agents against ASFV and their potential to mitigate disease-related inflammation.

nodes.title: Spatial omics technologies at multimodal and single cell/subcellular level
nodes.summary:
Spatial omics technologies enable a deeper understanding of cellular organizations and interactions within tissues.
These technologies can identify specific compartments or regions with differential transcript or protein abundance.
Various spatial methodologies are being developed, differing in spatial resolution, multiplexing capability, and scale.
Targeted spatial omics methods use antibodies and RNA probes to detect specific molecular entities.
Transcriptome-wide spatial omics methods use next-generation sequencing platforms to profile the transcriptome in an unbiased manner.
Spatial omics data can be analyzed using traditional methods, such as cell segmentation and differential expression analysis.
Novel methods, such as spatial microenvironment analysis and inference of intercellular interactions, can also be applied.

nodes.title: Effect of spaceflight on Pseudomonas aeruginosa final cell density is modulated by nutrient and oxygen availability
nodes.summary:
Pseudomonas aeruginosa final cell density is affected by spaceflight when nutrients are limited.
Low phosphate and oxygen availability increase final cell density during spaceflight.
Increasing phosphate or oxygen availability minimizes spaceflight effects on final cell density.
Motility does not significantly impact final cell density in spaceflight conditions.
Spaceflight conditions do not induce cellular aggregation in P. aeruginosa PA14 planktonic cells.
Environmental conditions and nutrient availability modulate microbial responses to spaceflight.
Microgravity allows cells to grow better with limited resources compared to Earth conditions.

nodes.title: 5AtRabD2b and AtRabD2c have overlapping functions in pollen development and pollen tube growth
nodes.summary:
AtRabD2b and AtRabD2c are two Rab GTPases in Arabidopsis that play important roles in pollen development and pollen tube growth.
They have overlapping functions and are highly expressed in pollen, with 99% amino acid identity.
The AtrabD2b/2c double mutant has shorter siliques and produces deformed pollen with swollen and branched pollen tube tips.
The proteins localize to the Golgi bodies, consistent with their proposed role in trafficking from the ER to the Golgi apparatus.
The loss of AtRabD2b and AtRabD2c function cannot be compensated for by the remaining AtRabD family members.
The AtrabD2b/2c double mutant has defects in pollen germination and tube elongation, leading to reduced fertility.
The study suggests that AtRabD2b and AtRabD2c are essential for vesicle trafficking during pollen tube growth.

nodes.title: Transcriptional and Proteomic Responses of Pseudomonas aeruginosa PAO1 to Spaceflight Conditions Involve Hfq Regulation and Reveal a Role for Oxygen á°
nodes.summary:
Pseudomonas aeruginosa PAO1 responded to spaceflight conditions by differentially regulating 167 genes and 28 proteins.
The RNA binding protein Hfq played a key role in the spaceflight response, with 13.4% of its regulon induced or downregulated.
Genes involved in anaerobic metabolism were upregulated, while those involved in microaerophilic metabolism were downregulated.
The lectin-encoding genes lecA and lecB, and the rhamnolipid-encoding gene rhlA, were induced under spaceflight conditions.
Denitrification was the primary way for P. aeruginosa to cope with oxygen limitation under spaceflight conditions.
A comparison with P. aeruginosa grown in low-fluid-shear conditions using the rotating wall vessel bioreactor revealed similarities and differences.
Hfq was identified as a common regulator in the responses of P. aeruginosa and S. Typhimurium to spaceflight and low-fluid-shear conditions.

nodes.title: Ethylene-Induced Flavonol Accumulation in Guard Cells Suppresses Reactive Oxygen Species and Moderates Stomatal Aperture 1[W][OPEN]
nodes.summary:
Flavonols accumulate in guard cells of Arabidopsis thaliana, where they act as antioxidants to reduce reactive oxygen species (ROS) levels. 
Ethylene treatment increases flavonol accumulation in guard cells, leading to decreased ROS levels and a reduced rate of abscisic acid (ABA)-induced stomatal closure. 
The absence of flavonols in the transparent testa4-2 mutant results in increased ROS levels and a faster rate of ABA-induced stomatal closure. 
Flavonol accumulation is localized to the nuclei and cytosol of guard cells, where it may modulate the activity of redox-sensitive transcription factors. 
Elevated ethylene levels increase flavonol accumulation, which in turn reduces ROS levels and decreases the rate of stomatal closure. 
The ethylene-insensitive2-5 mutant shows no increase in flavonol accumulation in response to ethylene treatment, highlighting the importance of ethylene signaling in regulating flavonol synthesis. 
Overall, the study demonstrates that flavonols play a crucial role in modulating ROS levels and stomatal closure in response to ethylene and ABA signaling.

nodes.title: The role of FGF-2 and BMP-2 in regulation of gene induction, cell proliferation and mineralization
nodes.summary:
Fibroblast growth factor-2 (FGF-2) induces gene expression, cell growth, and proliferation in osteoblast-like cells.
FGF-2 downregulates genes associated with mineralization, such as collagen type-1 and osteocalcin.
Bone morphogenic protein-2 (BMP-2) stimulates expression of mineralization-associated genes, including collagen type-1 and osteocalcin.
BMP-2 has little effect on gene expression associated with growth and proliferation.
FGF-2 and BMP-2 play critical roles in different stages of bone repair, with FGF-2 involved in the early stage of proliferation and BMP-2 in the later stage of mineralization.
The sequential regulation of gene expression by FGF-2 and BMP-2 is essential for bone formation and repair.
FGF-2 and BMP-2 have distinct effects on osteoblast-like cells, with FGF-2 promoting proliferation and BMP-2 promoting mineralization.

nodes.title: Single-cell RNA sequencing of the carotid artery and femoral artery of rats exposed to hindlimb unloading
nodes.summary:
presents a single-cell RNA sequencing analysis of carotid and femoral arteries in rats exposed to hindlimb unloading, a model of microgravity.
The analysis identified 23 cell clusters, including endothelial cells, smooth muscle cells, fibroblasts, and immune cells, with distinct gene expression profiles.
Hindlimb unloading induced changes in cell type composition, including an increased percentage of endothelial cells in the carotid artery and a decreased proportion of smooth muscle cells in both arteries.
The study also revealed sub-clusters within each cell type, such as endothelial cells undergoing endothelial-to-mesenchymal transition.
Cellular communication analysis showed enhanced interactions between smooth muscle cells and fibroblasts, and transcription factor analysis identified key regulators of vascular remodeling.
The findings provide insights into the mechanisms of vascular remodeling under microgravity conditions and have implications for understanding the effects of long-duration spaceflight on the cardiovascular system.

nodes.title: Immune Suppressive Extracellular Vesicle Proteins of Leptopilina heterotoma Are Encoded in the Wasp Genome
nodes.summary:
Leptopilina heterotoma are parasitoid wasps that develop in Drosophila hosts.
The wasps' venom contains extracellular vesicles (MSEVs) with immune suppressive functions.
A proteomics analysis identified 407 proteins in the MSEV proteome, with 90% having sequences present in the whole-body transcriptome.
The L. heterotoma genome was sequenced and assembled, revealing that 90% of MSEV proteins have coding regions within the genomic scaffolds.
The results suggest that MSEVs are encoded in the wasp nuclear genome and are not of viral origin.
The study provides insights into the evolution of figitid and related wasp species and their interactions with hosts.

nodes.title: Absence of Î³-sarcoglycan alters the response of p70S6 kinase to mechanical perturbation in murine skeletal muscle
nodes.summary:
The dystrophin glycoprotein complex plays a crucial role in skeletal muscle function.
Mutations in the complex's components cause muscular dystrophies, such as Duchenne muscular dystrophy.
The sarcoglycan subcomplex is essential for muscle integrity, and its absence leads to severe myofiber degeneration.
The response of p70S6 kinase to mechanical perturbation is altered in the absence of Î³-sarcoglycan.
The absence of Î³-sarcoglycan uncouples the response of p70S6K to stretch, implying its importance in mechanotransduction signaling.
The findings suggest that altered load-sensing mechanisms exist in muscular dystrophies where the sarcoglycans are absent.

nodes.title: An extensive allelic series of Drosophila kae1 mutants reveals diverse and tissue-specific requirements for t6A biogenesis
nodes.summary:
Drosophila kae1 mutants exhibit diverse and tissue-specific requirements for t6A biogenesis.
Kae1 is a core factor in t6A biosynthesis, and its loss affects t6A-modified tRNAs.
The mutants show prominent melanotic masses, lymph gland overgrowth, and ectopic generation of lamellocytes.
Strongly mitotic tissues, such as imaginal discs, are sensitive to loss of kae1, whereas nonproliferating tissues are less affected.
The study highlights the biological complexity of t6A modification during animal development and disease.

nodes.title: Disturbances in human position sense during alterations in gravity: a parabolic flight experiment
nodes.summary:
The study investigated the effects of altered gravity on human position sense using three methods: two-arm matching, one-arm pointing, and one-arm repositioning.
Participants performed these tasks during parabolic flights, experiencing periods of hypergravity, microgravity, and normal gravity.
The results showed that position sense was disturbed during changes in gravity, with significant increases in errors during hypergravity and decreases during microgravity for matching and pointing tasks.
In contrast, repositioning errors remained unaffected by gravity changes, suggesting a different underlying mechanism.
The study's findings support the idea that different methods of measuring position sense involve distinct processes and may be influenced by gravity in different ways.
The results have implications for our understanding of proprioception and the role of gravity in shaping our sense of body position and movement.

nodes.title: FAIRness and Usability for Open-access Omics Data Systems
nodes.summary:
The FAIRness of five open-access omics data systems was assessed using 14 metrics.
The range of overall FAIRness scores was 6-12, with an average of 10.1 and standard deviation of 2.4.
The systems performed best in data findability and accessibility, but worst in data interoperability.
Reusability of metadata was frequently not well supported, with none of the systems using a metadata representation language with sufficient semantics.
The systems also failed to fully leverage FAIR vocabularies for metadata, hindering data integration and reuse.
To improve FAIRness, two new principles are proposed: leveraging an integrated credentialing architecture and collocating data and executable code within Big Data systems.
These principles can help maximize data usability and reusability in Big Data systems, particularly in the omics data domain.

nodes.title: New Device for High-Throughput Viability Screening of Flow Biofilms á°
nodes.summary:
A new device called BioFlux has been developed for high-throughput viability screening of flow biofilms.
The device uses microfluidic channels and a distributed pneumatic pump to provide fluid flow to 96 individual biofilms.
It allows fine control of continuous or intermittent fluid flow over a broad range of flow rates.
The device is compatible with plate readers and multichannel pipettors, making it suitable for high-throughput screening.
The BioFlux device has been used to screen the effects of antimicrobial agents on flow biofilms, with results showing dose-dependent biofilm killing.
The device has the potential to be used for high-throughput screening of other biofilm parameters, such as expression of fluorescently tagged proteins or formation of the extracellular matrix.

nodes.title: Microbiomes of the dust particles collected from the International Space Station and Spacecraft Assembly Facilities
nodes.summary:
The International Space Station (ISS) has a unique microbiome due to its microgravity environment and continuous human habitation.
The ISS microbiome is dominated by Actinobacteria, Firmicutes, and Proteobacteria phyla.
Actinobacteria are more abundant in ISS samples, while Proteobacteria are more abundant in Earth-based cleanroom samples.
The viable bacterial population in ISS samples is lower than in Earth-based cleanroom samples.
PMA treatment can differentiate between viable and dead microbial cells, providing a more accurate estimate of the viable microbiome.
The ISS microbiome is distinct from that of Earth-based cleanrooms, with implications for astronaut health and spacecraft maintenance.

nodes.title: Human presence impacts fungal diversity of inflated lunar/Mars analog habitat
nodes.summary:
Human presence impacts the fungal diversity of an inflatable lunar/Mars analog habitat.
The habitat's fungal community structure changed over a 30-day occupation period.
Viable fungal families, such as Davidiellaceae and Pleosporaceae, increased during occupation.
The most abundant viable fungal genera were Epiccocum, Alternaria, and Pleosporales.
Proper maintenance protocols are necessary to preserve the habitat and keep it safe for inhabitants.
The study used propidium monoazide treatment to differentiate between viable and dead fungal cells.
The results have implications for the maintenance and safety of closed habitats in space exploration.

nodes.title: Erratum to: Whole metagenome profiles of particulates collected from the International Space Station
nodes.summary:
The original article had an error in Fig. fig-4. 
The X-axis label was missing from the figure. 
The authors reported the mistake after publication. 
A corrected version of Fig. fig-4 is provided. 
The new figure includes the missing X-axis label. 
The correction aims to improve the accuracy of the article. 
The updated figure is attached to the erratum notice.

nodes.title: Correction to: Succession and persistence of microbial communities and antimicrobial resistance genes associated with International Space Station environmental surfaces
nodes.summary:
The original article contained a typographic error in scientific notation.
The error occurred in the number of reads associated with microorganisms.
Approximately 7.3 Ã 10^8 reads were generated after high-quality trimming.
The reads came from PMA and non-PMA treated samples.
All metagenomics reads were normalized across all samples.
This yielded 3.1 Ã 10^8 total reads and 7.4 Ã 10^6 assigned to each sample.
The errors did not affect the taxonomic diversity of the samples.

nodes.title: Characterization of the total and viable bacterial and fungal communities associated with the International Space Station surfaces
nodes.summary:
The International Space Station (ISS) is a closed system inhabited by microorganisms from various sources.
Microbial monitoring of the ISS has been conducted using traditional culture methods, but these methods have limitations.
A study was conducted to characterize the total and viable bacterial and fungal communities on ISS surfaces using molecular and culture-based methods.
The study found a diverse population of bacteria and fungi on ISS surfaces, with changes in microbial load over time but not across locations.
The dominant organisms were associated with the human microbiome and may include opportunistic pathogens, highlighting the importance of further study to understand the impact on astronaut health.

nodes.title: Reproducible changes in the gut microbiome suggest a shift in microbial and host metabolism during spaceflight
nodes.summary:
Spaceflight alters the gut microbiome in mice, with changes in alpha diversity and community structure.
The ISS rodent housing environment contributes to these changes, with spaceflight-specific factors also playing a role.
Microgravity is hypothesized to be a key factor, influencing microbial physiology and host physiological responses.
The gut microbiome shifts towards a higher Firmicutes-to-Bacteroidetes ratio during spaceflight, similar to previous findings in a twin astronaut.
Spaceflight-associated changes in the gut microbiome are linked to altered host gene expression in the liver, particularly in pathways related to protein metabolism and redox processes.

nodes.title: The influence of spaceflight on the astronaut salivary microbiome and the search for a microbiome biomarker for viral reactivation
nodes.summary:
Spaceflight impacts the astronaut salivary microbiome, with changes in diversity and richness observed during flight.
Streptococcus was the most abundant organism, making up 8% of total organisms detected, and its diversity decreased during spaceflight.
Proteobacteria and Fusobacteria increased during flight, while Actinobacteria decreased.
Correlation analyses revealed a positive correlation between Gracilibacteria, Absconditabacteria, and Abiotrophia and EBV viral titers.
A negative correlation was found between Oribacterium, Veillonella, and Haemophilus and EBV viral titers.
The study suggests a potential role for the salivary microbiome in viral reactivation during spaceflight.
Further studies are needed to examine the role of specific organisms in viral reactivation and to develop mitigation strategies for disease prevention during space missions.

nodes.title: Metabolic modeling of the International Space Station microbiome reveals key microbial interactions
nodes.summary:
Metabolic modeling of the International Space Station microbiome reveals key microbial interactions.
The study uses a computational approach to predict metabolic interactions in the ISS microbiome.
Klebsiella pneumoniae is found to be beneficial to many other microorganisms, especially those from the Pantoea genus.
Species belonging to the Enterobacteriaceae family are often the most beneficial to other microorganisms in the community.
The study also identifies parasitic and amensalistic interactions between K. pneumoniae and other microorganisms, including Aspergillus and Penicillium species.
The findings have implications for understanding the organization of the ISS microbiome and potential interventions to control microbial growth.

nodes.title: Microbial Tracking-2, a metagenomics analysis of bacteria and fungi onboard the International Space Station
nodes.summary:
The International Space Station (ISS) is a unique built environment with a distinct microbiome.
Staphylococcus sp. and Malassezia sp. are the most represented bacterial and fungal species on the ISS.
The ISS surface microbiome is dominated by human-associated organisms, with temporal changes in microbial population.
No spatial differences were found in the microbiome, but significant temporal changes were observed.
The ISS antimicrobial resistance gene profiles are stable over time, with 29 resistance genes detected.
Metagenomic assembled genomes (MAGs) were reconstructed, showing a propensity for amino acid utilization over carbohydrate metabolism.

nodes.title: Microbial Tracking-2, a metagenomics analysis of bacteria and fungi onboard the International Space Station
nodes.summary:
The International Space Station (ISS) is a unique built environment with a distinct microbiome.
Staphylococcus sp. and Malassezia sp. were the most represented bacterial and fungal species on the ISS.
The ISS surface microbiome was dominated by human-associated organisms, with temporal changes in microbial population.
No spatial differences were found in the microbiome, but significant temporal changes were observed.
The antimicrobial resistance gene profiles were stable over time, with 29 resistance genes detected across all samples.
Metagenomic assembled genomes (MAGs) were reconstructed, showing a propensity for amino acid utilization over carbohydrate metabolism.
Co-occurrence analysis revealed strong associations between bacterial and fungal genera, with potential implications for astronaut health and spacecraft integrity.

nodes.title: Machine learning algorithm to characterize antimicrobial resistance associated with the International Space Station surface microbiome
nodes.summary:
Antimicrobial resistance (AMR) is a concern in space habitats due to microgravity, radiation, and confinement.
The International Space Station (ISS) is used to investigate microbial diversity and virulence associated with spaceflight.
A deep learning model, DeepARG, is used to predict AMR genes in metagenomic data from the ISS.
The model identifies hundreds of antibiotic resistance genes in isolates, including Enterobacter bugandensis and Bacillus cereus.
Experimental validation using disc assays confirms the high resistance of these pathogens to various beta-lactam antibiotics.
The study demonstrates the advantages of machine learning in uncovering concealed AMR determinants in metagenomics datasets.
The results expand the understanding of the ISS environmental microbiomes and their pathogenic potential in humans.

nodes.title: Multidrug-resistant Acinetobacter pittii is adapting to and exhibiting potential succession aboard the International Space Station
nodes.summary:
Acinetobacter pittii isolated from the International Space Station (ISS) has formed a genetically distinct clade.
ISS-associated A. pittii strains exhibit increased antimicrobial resistance, particularly to cephalosporins.
The strains have acquired unique genes, including the transcriptional regulator LexA, which may enhance survival in harsh environments.
A. pittii's relative abundance has increased across ISS environmental samples, suggesting potential succession.
The ISS environment may be exerting selective pressure on A. pittii, driving genetic changes and increased mutational frequency.
ISS-associated A. pittii strains contain a distinct accessory genome, with 175 genes enriched in ISS strains.
The study highlights the need for continued monitoring of microbial evolution and adaptation in space environments.

nodes.title: Characterization of metagenome-assembled genomes from the International Space Station
nodes.summary:
Metagenome-assembled genomes (MAGs) were generated from International Space Station (ISS) environmental samples.
A total of 46 MAGs were assembled, including 18 bacterial species and four fungal genomes.
Phylogenetic analysis showed ISS-specific evolution in five bacterial species, with genes related to cell membranes being highly frequent.
Antimicrobial resistance (AMR) genes were more prevalent in Enterobacter bugandensis MAG, and variations in AMR and virulence genes were characterized.
The Pantoea/Kalamiella strains had the most single-nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) within the ISS strains, suggesting they are more sensitive to microgravity changes.
The study provides evidence for ISS-specific bacterial evolution and adaptation strategies in microbes under microgravity conditions.

nodes.title: Characterization of metagenome-assembled genomes from the International Space Station
nodes.summary:
Metagenome-assembled genomes (MAGs) were generated from International Space Station (ISS) environmental samples.
A total of 46 MAGs were assembled, including 18 bacterial species and four fungal genomes.
Phylogenetic analysis showed ISS-specific evolution in five bacterial species, with genes related to cell membranes being highly frequent.
Antimicrobial resistance (AMR) genes were more prevalent in Enterobacter bugandensis MAGs.
The Pantoea/Kalamiella strains had the most single-nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) within the ISS strains, suggesting they are more sensitive to microgravity changes.
Biofilm-forming and quorum-sensing genes in E. bugandensis MAGs were highly conserved across clinical strains.
The study provides evidence for ISS-specific bacterial evolution and adaptation strategies in microbes under microgravity conditions.

nodes.title: Genomic, functional, and metabolic enhancements in multidrug-resistant Enterobacter bugandensis facilitating its persistence and succession in the International Space Station
nodes.summary:
Enterobacter bugandensis is a multidrug-resistant bacterium found in the International Space Station (ISS).
It has distinct genomic and functional enhancements compared to its Earth counterparts.
The ISS strains exhibit resistance to 23 different multidrug classes, including cephalosporin and fluoroquinolone antibiotics.
E. bugandensis coexists with other microorganisms in the ISS, including Pantoea and Klebsiella species.
Metabolic modeling suggests that E. bugandensis provides metabolic benefits to Gram-positive microorganisms.
The bacterium's presence in the ISS poses potential risks to astronaut health and highlights the need for further research.

nodes.title: Predicting how varying moisture conditions impact the microbiome of dust collected from the International Space Station
nodes.summary:
Moisture conditions impact the microbiome of dust collected from the International Space Station.
Fungal growth in dust increases with elevated relative humidity, reaching 2.1 Ã 10^10 spore equivalents per milligram at 100% relative humidity.
Bacterial communities change with constant relative humidity incubations, but cannot be modeled using the time-of-wetness framework.
Fungal diversity decreases with increasing moisture, while bacterial diversity shows similar trends.
The time-of-wetness framework can predict fungal growth in spacecraft dust, but may need refinement for other environmental factors.
Understanding microbial growth in spacecraft is crucial for protecting astronaut health and spacecraft integrity.
Refining moisture control and developing planetary protection protocols will aid in preventing microbial contamination during future space missions.

nodes.title: Predicting how varying moisture conditions impact the microbiome of dust collected from the International Space Station
nodes.summary:
Moisture conditions impact the microbiome of dust collected from the International Space Station.
Fungal growth in ISS dust is facilitated by elevated relative humidity, with significant growth at 80% RH.
Bacterial communities in ISS dust change with constant relative humidity incubations, decreasing in diversity at 85% RH.
The time-of-wetness framework models fungal growth in ISS dust, with activation-limited growth at 85% RH and deactivation-limited growth at 100% RH.
Fungal diversity in ISS dust decreases with increasing relative humidity, with significant reductions at 85% RH.
Aspergillus is the dominant fungal genus in ISS dust, becoming more dominant as RH and time elevated increase.
Understanding microbial growth in spacecraft is crucial for protecting astronaut health and maintaining spacecraft integrity.

nodes.title: Adaptation to space conditions of novel bacterial species isolated from the International Space Station revealed by functional gene annotations and comparative genome analysis
nodes.summary:
Five novel bacterial species isolated from the International Space Station (ISS) were analyzed.
Their genomes were annotated using a deep-learning based tool, revealing adaptations to space conditions.
The bacteria showed increased DNA repair activity, mechanosensitive channel proteins, and mobile genetic elements.
These adaptations enable the bacteria to manage hypoosmotic stress, counteract radiation exposure, and enhance metabolism.
The study also found potential pathogenic capabilities, including small molecule and peptide synthesis and ATP-dependent transporters.
The bacteria's ability to form biofilms and degrade antimicrobial compounds was also observed.
The findings suggest that the ISS bacteria have evolved unique genetic traits to survive in space.

nodes.title: Adaptation to space conditions of novel bacterial species isolated from the International Space Station revealed by functional gene annotations and comparative genome analysis
nodes.summary:
Five novel bacterial species isolated from the International Space Station (ISS) were analyzed.
Their genomes were annotated using a deep-learning based tool, revealing adaptations to space conditions.
The bacteria showed increased DNA repair activity, mechanosensitive channel proteins, and mobile genetic elements.
These adaptations enable the bacteria to manage hypoosmotic stress, counteract radiation exposure, and enhance metabolism.
The study also found potential pathogenic capabilities, including small molecule and peptide synthesis and ATP-dependent transporters.
The bacteria's ability to form biofilms and degrade antimicrobial compounds was also observed.
The findings suggest that the ISS bacteria have evolved unique genetic traits to survive in space.

nodes.title: A comprehensive SARS-CoV-2 and COVID-19 review, Part 1: Intracellular overdrive for SARS-CoV-2 infection
nodes.summary:
SARS-CoV-2, the virus responsible for COVID-19, has caused significant global impact with over 5 million lives lost and 257 million cases reported. 
The virus infects cells by binding to the human angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 (hACE2) receptor, leading to membrane fusion and internalization. 
SARS-CoV-2 manipulates host cell machinery to promote viral replication, altering calcium ion signaling, intracellular pathways, and metabolic adaptations. 
The virus affects various organs, including the lungs, heart, liver, and brain, with widespread distribution of ACE2 receptors contributing to its systemic effects. 
Mitochondrial dysfunction and altered cellular metabolism are key features of SARS-CoV-2 infection, with shifts towards glycolysis and increased production of reactive oxygen species. 
Understanding the biology of SARS-CoV-2 infection is crucial for developing effective therapeutic strategies and informing public health interventions. 
Future research should focus on defining the mechanisms of viral entry, elucidating the dynamics of protein machinery capture, and understanding the impact of SARS-CoV-2 on cellular physiology.

nodes.title: A comprehensive SARS-CoV-2 and COVID-19 review, Part 2: host extracellular to systemic effects of SARS-CoV-2 infection
nodes.summary:
SARS-CoV-2 infection affects whole-body metabolism, leading to changes in biochemical pathways and production of circulating metabolites. 
These adaptations result in systemic effects, including tissue remodeling and function, shifts in whole-body metabolism and bioenergetics, and changes in immune and endocrine states. 
The balance of biochemical components, such as the machinery, fuel sources, and messenger molecules, appears to shift towards a physiological catabolic state. 
This state may be further exacerbated by a patient's underlying conditions and demographics, leading to diverse clinical diagnoses and observations. 
SARS-CoV-2 infection also influences the endocrine system, with reduced thyroid, adrenal, and pancreatic islet function, as well as damage to the testes and changes in menstrual cycles. 
The non-coding transcriptome, including microRNAs, long non-coding RNAs, and circular RNAs, plays a significant role in regulating the viral replicative cycle and cellular antiviral responses. 
Exosomes, extracellular vesicles generated by all cells, carry cellular components and serve as a biomarker for COVID-19, with potential implications for understanding organ adaptations and disease severity.

nodes.title: Emergence of novel cephalopod gene regulation and expression through large-scale genome reorganization
nodes.summary:
Coleoid cephalopods have the largest nervous system among invertebrates, enabling complex behaviors.
Their genomic basis remains unknown, with this study using comparative and functional genomics in Euprymna scolopes.
The study reveals a unique genomic organization, with extensive reorganization leading to hundreds of novel gene clusters.
These clusters contribute to complex expression patterns, particularly in the nervous system.
The emergence of these clusters is proposed to be instrumental in cephalopod nervous system evolution.
Microsyntenic profiling is suggested as central to understanding cephalopod innovations.
The study provides insight into the evolution of complex tissue expression patterns in cephalopods.

nodes.title: Release of CD36-associated cell-free mitochondrial DNA and RNA as a hallmark of space environment response
nodes.summary:
Astronauts undergoing long-duration spaceflight on the ISS showed changes in plasma cell-free RNA profiles.
Mitochondrial components, including DNA and RNA, increased in plasma during spaceflight and returned to baseline levels post-flight.
Screening with antibodies identified CD36 as a surface marker for extracellular vesicles containing mitochondrial components.
The CD36 fraction contained RNA species from genes representing diverse tissue specificities, including brain, skeletal muscle, and retina.
Tissue-specific RNAs indicated responses in previously uncharacterized tissue types, such as the pituitary gland and thyroid gland.
Comparison with mouse blood samples revealed common molecular changes associated with microgravity, including metabolic stress responses and neurological disorders.
The study highlights the potential of liquid biopsies for monitoring internal tissue responses in space and detecting early molecular events associated with spaceflight-related health risks.

nodes.title: Single-cell analysis identifies conserved features of immune dysfunction in simulated microgravity and spaceflight
nodes.summary:
Microgravity alters immune cell function, with changes in gene expression and pathways.
Simulated microgravity affects innate and adaptive immunity, including monocytes and T cells.
Key pathways altered include interferon signaling, cytoskeleton regulation, and oxidative stress.
Microgravity induces inflammatory responses and impairs immune cell function.
Quercetin, a flavonol, can reverse some of the transcriptional changes caused by microgravity.

nodes.title: Microbial adaptation to spaceflight is correlated with bacteriophage-encoded functions
nodes.summary:
Microbial populations on the International Space Station are rapidly adapting to the environment.
Bacteriophages are key mediators of bacterial adaptation on Earth and may play a role in spaceflight.
Analysis of 245 genomes from spaceflight isolates revealed significant differences in phage-associated genes.
Prophage regions encoded functions correlated with increased persistence in extreme environments.
283 complete prophage regions were identified, with 21% classified as novel species or genera.
Prophages contributed to variation between flight and terrestrial strains of the same species.
Phage-encoded proteins conferred unique capabilities to hosts, including antibiotic resistance and virulence.

nodes.title: Ethical considerations for the age of non-governmental space exploration
nodes.summary:
Non-governmental space exploration raises new ethical concerns, including selecting space travelers and conducting human subject research. 
Stringent selection criteria are crucial to protect astronaut and spaceflight participant health. 
Current guidance applies mostly to government-sponsored astronauts, leaving a gap for non-governmental space travelers. 
The health risks associated with space travel, such as radiation exposure and microgravity, are significant and not fully understood. 
Informed consent for human subject research in space is challenging due to unknown risks and side effects. 
Ethical principles, including avoiding harm and respecting autonomy, must be adapted for space research. 
Guidelines for non-governmental space research on human subjects are urgently needed to ensure safety and ethics.

nodes.title: Astronaut omics and the impact of space on the human body at scale
nodes.summary:
Human spaceflight is expected to increase in the coming years, with missions to Mars and beyond. 
To ensure the health and safety of astronauts, a new field of research called human space omics is emerging. 
Human space omics involves the study of how spaceflight affects the human body at the molecular level. 
This research has the potential to improve our understanding of how spaceflight affects human health and to develop personalized medicine approaches for astronauts. 
However, human space omics also raises ethical, cultural, and legal challenges that need to be addressed. 
These challenges include concerns about privacy, genetic discrimination, and informed consent. 
To address these challenges, international cooperation and standardization of policies and procedures are necessary. 
The development of a Human Cell Space Atlas, a global reference for basic space life science research, could also help to advance our understanding of human space omics. 
Ultimately, the goal of human space omics is to improve the health and safety of astronauts and to enable long-term space exploration.

nodes.title: Spatial multi-omics of human skin reveals KRAS and inflammatory responses to spaceflight
nodes.summary:
Spaceflight alters skin gene expression, with significant upregulation of genes related to inflammation and KRAS signaling.
These changes are observed across all skin regions, with specific responses in outer and inner epidermis, dermis, and vasculature.
The study used multi-omics assays, including GeoMx Digital Spatial Profiler and single-cell RNA/ATAC-seq, to assess spatial gene expressions.
Post-flight samples showed decreased expression of genes related to cell junctions and extracellular matrices, and increased expression of immune-related genes.
The study also found changes in skin microbiota, with decreases in Actinobacteria and increases in Veillonella, and correlations between microbiome changes and gene expression fluctuations.
Immune system changes were observed, including increases in T-cell signatures in the outermost epidermal layers and decreases in immune cells in vascular regions.
The study provides insights into the effects of spaceflight on the skin and immune system, with implications for future space missions and countermeasures.

nodes.title: Biological horizons: pioneering open science in the cosmos
nodes.summary:
The search for life beyond Earth is a complex and multidisciplinary challenge.
Open science approaches can accelerate progress in this field by facilitating collaboration.
The Biological Horizons initiative aims to promote open science in astrobiology.
It provides a platform for sharing data, methods, and results openly and transparently.
This approach enables researchers to build upon each other's work more efficiently.
By leveraging open science, the initiative seeks to drive innovation and discovery.
The Biological Horizons initiative has the potential to transform our understanding of life in the universe.

nodes.title: Collection of biospecimens from the inspiration4 mission establishes the standards for the space omics and medical atlas (SOMA)
nodes.summary:
The SpaceX Inspiration4 mission collected biospecimens from four crew members before, during, and after spaceflight. 
The collection process included venous whole blood, capillary dried blood spot cards, saliva, urine, stool, body swabs, and skin biopsies. 
A total of 2,911 sample aliquots were shipped to Weill Cornell Medicine for downstream assays and biobanking. 
The study aimed to establish a foundational set of methods for biospecimen collection and banking on commercial spaceflight missions. 
The collected biospecimens will enable comprehensive, multi-omic profiles of human responses to spaceflight. 
The Space Omics and Medical Atlas (SOMA) initiative will aid in future human spaceflight and space biology experiments. 
The SOMA protocols provide a molecular roadmap for crew health, medical biometrics, and possible countermeasures.

nodes.title: Secretome profiling reveals acute changes in oxidative stress, brain homeostasis, and coagulation following short-duration spaceflight
nodes.summary:
Secretome profiling of astronauts after a 3-day spaceflight revealed changes in oxidative stress, brain homeostasis, and coagulation markers.
These changes were largely reversible, but some proteins remained differentially abundant six months later.
The study identified potential biomarkers for spaceflight-associated health risks, including anemia, coagulation, and oxidative stress.
Brain-associated proteins were increased in plasma and EVPs, suggesting potential BBB disruption or neuroinflammation.
The study highlights the importance of secretome profiling for monitoring crew health and developing countermeasures for spaceflight-associated health risks.

nodes.title: Spatially resolved multiomics on the neuronal effects induced by spaceflight in mice
nodes.summary:
Spaceflight alters gene expression in the mouse brain, affecting neurogenesis, synaptogenesis, and neuronal development.
Changes in gene expression are observed in multiple brain regions, including the cortex, hippocampus, and striatum.
Astrocyte activation and immune dysfunction are also detected, with potential implications for neurodegenerative diseases.
The study uses spatial transcriptomics and single-cell multiomics to investigate the effects of spaceflight on the brain.
The results show similarities between spaceflight-induced changes and neurodegenerative disorders, such as Parkinson's disease.
The study provides a foundation for understanding the risks of spaceflight to the central nervous system and highlights the need for further research.

nodes.title: Space radiation damage rescued by inhibition of key spaceflight associated miRNAs
nodes.summary:
Space radiation causes damage to human cells and tissues, 
increasing the risk of cancer, cardiovascular disease, and other health problems.
Researchers identified three microRNAs (miR-16-5p, miR-125b-5p, and let-7a-5p) 
that are associated with space radiation damage and can be used as biomarkers.
Inhibiting these microRNAs with antagomirs can rescue space radiation damage 
in 3D human microvessel cell cultures and may be a potential countermeasure 
for space travelers to mitigate radiation-induced health risks. 
The antagomirs can reduce inflammation, DNA double-strand breaks, 
and mitochondrial dysfunction caused by space radiation. 
This study provides new insights into the effects of space radiation 
on human cells and tissues and suggests a potential therapeutic strategy 
to protect astronauts from radiation-induced health risks during long-duration space missions.

nodes.title: Direct RNA sequencing of astronaut blood reveals spaceflight-associated m6A increases and hematopoietic transcriptional responses
nodes.summary:
used direct RNA sequencing to analyze the effects of spaceflight on the human transcriptome.
The analysis revealed changes in gene expression and methylation patterns in astronauts' blood samples.
Erythrocyte-associated pathways were found to be significantly affected by spaceflight, with changes in CO2 and O2 takeup and release.
The study also identified novel transcripts and alternative splicing events associated with spaceflight.
m6A methylation analysis showed significant changes in methylation patterns, particularly on the day of return to Earth.
The findings provide insights into the molecular responses of the human body to spaceflight and have implications for future space missions.

nodes.title: Single-cell multi-ome and immune profiles of the Inspiration4 crew reveal conserved, cell-type, and sex-specific responses to spaceflight
nodes.summary:
The Inspiration4 mission crew exhibited immune responses to spaceflight, 
including increased cytokine production and changes in gene expression.
A "spaceflight signature" of gene expression was identified, 
characterized by enrichment in oxidative phosphorylation and immune function.
The signature was conserved across multiple datasets, 
including the NASA Twins Study and mouse transcriptomes.
Sex-dependent differences in response to spaceflight were observed, 
with males showing more pronounced changes in immune cell gene expression.
The study provides insights into the effects of spaceflight on the human immune system, 
informing the development of countermeasures for future space missions.

nodes.title: Cosmic kidney disease: an integrated panomic, physiological and morphological study into spaceflight-induced renal dysfunction
nodes.summary:
Spaceflight induces renal dysfunction and increases the risk of nephrolithiasis in astronauts. 
Renal transporter dephosphorylation and remodelling of the nephron occur in response to spaceflight. 
Galactic cosmic radiation (GCR) exposure equivalent to a Mars roundtrip dose causes renal damage and dysfunction. 
Urinary and plasma biochemical analyses reveal increased excretion of metabolites and electrolytes that are risk factors for nephrolithiasis. 
Tubular remodelling in spaceflight may be a primary event causing subsequent dysregulation of serum and urine electrolyte homeostasis. 
The study suggests that renal-targeted therapies, such as thiazides or calcilytics, may be effective in reducing spaceflight-induced hypercalciuria. 
Renal damage and dysfunction from spaceflight and GCR exposure have significant implications for long-term deep space travel and require further study.

nodes.title: Spatiotemporal expression and control of haemoglobin in space
nodes.summary:
Astronauts in space experience a decrease in red blood cell mass, known as space anaemia.
The study examined the developmental expression of haemoglobin over time and space using multi-omic datasets from NASA GeneLab.
Results showed significant variations in globin gene expression corresponding to the distinct spatiotemporal characteristics of the collected samples.
The study revealed a shift towards the production of fetal haemoglobin in flight, with increased expression of genes involved in gamma-globin expression.
Several genes involved in erythropoiesis were also found to be perturbed in flight, suggesting that space anaemia may be due to both increased haemolysis and down-regulation of genes involved in erythropoiesis.
The observed changes in gene expression may be a response mechanism to combat the effects of space anaemia.
Future studies will investigate the direct effects of haemoglobin switch actors on fetal haemoglobin levels in spaceflight and afterward.

nodes.title: Protective alleles and precision healthcare in crewed spaceflight
nodes.summary:
Spaceflight poses significant health risks to astronauts, including radiation exposure and muscle and bone loss. 
Research on protective alleles, which occur naturally in human populations, may help mitigate these risks. 
These alleles have been linked to improved health outcomes, such as increased radiation tolerance and stronger bones. 
Studying these alleles could inform the development of personalized countermeasures, such as tailored nutrition and exercise plans. 
Omics technologies, including genomics and metabolomics, can help identify and characterize these protective alleles. 
The integration of omics data with traditional healthcare approaches could lead to more effective and targeted treatments for astronauts. 
Ultimately, the study of protective alleles has the potential to improve the health and safety of astronauts on deep space missions.

nodes.title: Glutathione triggers leaf-to-leaf, calciumbased plant defense signaling
nodes.summary:
Glutathione (GSH) is identified as a critical signaling molecule 
that triggers long-distance calcium-based defense signaling events in plants.
GSH-deficient mutants exhibit impaired plant defense signaling events 
despite high accumulation of glutamate, a previously defined wound signal.
The GLR3.3 protein is required for GSH-triggered systemic calcium signaling, 
and GSH binds to the ATD domain of GLR3.3, distinct from glutamate binding.
GSH application induces systemic calcium signaling, activating defense genes 
and triggering jasmonic acid biosynthesis in distal leaves.
The study reveals a novel role for GSH in plant defense signaling, 
providing insights into the complex mechanisms of plant systemic defense responses.

nodes.title: Mechanosensing antagonizes ethylene signaling to promote root gravitropism in rice
nodes.summary:
Root gravitropism in rice is regulated by a complex interplay of phytohormones and mechanosensing.
The COILING ROOT IN WATER 1 (CRW1) gene, encoding an ETHYLENE-INSENSITIVE3 (EIN3)-BINDING F-BOX PROTEIN, is essential for root gravitropism.
Loss of CRW1 function leads to excessive ethylene signaling, causing root coiling in hydroponics.
Mechanosensing-induced calcium signaling antagonizes ethylene signaling, promoting root gravitropism in rice.
Gentle mechanical resistance, such as that encountered in water-saturated paddy soil, is sufficient to rescue the root coiling phenotype of crw1 mutants.

nodes.title: Mechanosensing antagonizes ethylene signaling to promote root gravitropism in rice
nodes.summary:
Root gravitropism in rice is regulated by a complex interplay of phytohormones and mechanosensing.
The COILING ROOT IN WATER 1 (CRW1) gene, encoding an ETHYLENE-INSENSITIVE3 (EIN3)-BINDING F-BOX PROTEIN, is essential for root gravitropism.

Mechanosensing-induced calcium signaling antagonizes ethylene signaling, promoting root gravitropism in rice.
Gentle mechanical resistance, such as that encountered in water-saturated paddy soil, is sufficient to rescue the root coiling phenotype of crw1 mutants.

nodes.title: Mechanosensing antagonizes ethylene signaling to promote root gravitropism in rice
nodes.summary:
Root gravitropism in rice is regulated by a complex interplay of phytohormones and mechanosensing.
The COILING ROOT IN WATER 1 (CRW1) gene, encoding an ETHYLENE-INSENSITIVE3 (EIN3)-BINDING F-BOX PROTEIN, is essential for root gravitropism.
