Mechanosensing-induced calcium signaling antagonizes ethylene signaling, promoting root gravitropism in rice.
Gentle mechanical resistance, such as that encountered in water-saturated paddy soil, is sufficient to rescue the root coiling phenotype of crw1 mutants.

nodes.title: Mechanosensing antagonizes ethylene signaling to promote root gravitropism in rice
nodes.summary:
Root gravitropism in rice is regulated by a complex interplay of phytohormones and mechanosensing.
The COILING ROOT IN WATER 1 (CRW1) gene, encoding an F-box protein, is essential for root gravitropism.
Loss of CRW1 function leads to excessive ethylene signaling, causing root coiling in hydroponics.
Mechanosensing-induced calcium signaling antagonizes ethylene signaling, promoting root gravitropism.
Gentle mechanical resistance, such as that encountered in water-saturated paddy soil, rescues the root coiling phenotype.

nodes.title: Longitudinal characterization of multispecies microbial populations recovered from spaceflight potable water
nodes.summary:
The International Space Station (ISS) potable water system is a unique environment for studying microbial populations. 
Microbial isolates from the ISS potable water system were analyzed for antimicrobial resistance, biofilm formation, and other phenotypes. 
The study found that the isolates were resistant to multiple antibiotics and formed biofilms with distinct structures. 
The isolates also exhibited varying degrees of hemolysis, with some strains showing unstable hemolytic phenotypes. 
Interspecies interactions were observed, with some strains showing positive or negative interactions. 
The study suggests that the ISS potable water system is a dynamic environment with changing microbial populations over time. 
The findings have implications for understanding microbial risk assessments in space and terrestrial environments.

nodes.title: Longitudinal characterization of multispecies microbial populations recovered from spaceflight potable water
nodes.summary:
The International Space Station (ISS) potable water system is a unique environment for studying microbial populations. 
Microbial isolates from the ISS potable water system were analyzed for antimicrobial resistance, metabolism, and biofilm formation. 
The results showed that the isolates were resistant to multiple antibiotics and had varying abilities to form biofilms. 
The study also found that the microbial populations in the ISS potable water system changed over time, with some species becoming more dominant. 
The interactions between different microbial species were also examined, and the results showed that some species had positive or negative interactions. 
The study highlights the importance of understanding the microbial ecology of the ISS potable water system to ensure the health and safety of astronauts. 
The findings of this study have implications for the management of microbial populations in closed environments, such as space stations and hospitals.

nodes.title: npj | biofilms and microbiomes Article
nodes.summary:
Spaceflight alters the murine gut microbiota, with changes in 44 microbiome species.
Metagenomics reveals significant changes in fatty acid and bile acid metabolism.
Host gene expression is altered, with changes in bile acid and energy metabolism.
Immune suppression is observed, with downregulation of immune response pathways.
Spaceflight increases total body weight and carcass mass in mice.
Gut microbiome changes are associated with spaceflight pathology and may influence human health.

nodes.title: npj | biofilms and microbiomes Article
nodes.summary:
Spaceflight alters the murine gut microbiota, with changes in 44 microbiome species.
Metagenomics reveals significant changes in fatty acid and bile acid metabolism.
Host gene expression is altered, with changes in bile acid and energy metabolism.
Immune suppression is observed, with downregulation of immune response pathways.
Spaceflight increases total body weight and carcass mass in mice.
Gut microbiome changes are associated with spaceflight pathology and may influence human health.

nodes.title: From the bench to exploration medicine: NASA life sciences translational research for human exploration and habitation missions
nodes.summary:
NASA's life sciences translational research aims to address human health challenges in space exploration.
The agency's goal is to enable longer-duration missions by developing effective countermeasures.
Translational research at NASA involves a two-phased approach: basic-to-applied and applied-to-operational.
The agency can learn from the National Institutes of Health's (NIH) model of translational science.
NASA's current translational research approach includes collaborative workshops and symposia.
The agency is working to enhance institutional coordination and team science to spur translation.
Examples of NASA's life sciences basic-to-applied translational research include immune response, microbe-host interactions, oxidative stress, and visual impairment.

nodes.title: Investigation of simulated microgravity effects on Streptococcus mutans physiology and global gene expression
nodes.summary:
Streptococcus mutans, a primary causative agent of dental caries, 
was studied under simulated microgravity conditions using high-aspect 
ratio vessels to assess changes in metabolite and transcriptome profiles. 
Results showed that stationary phase S. mutans simulated microgravity 
cultures displayed increased killing by H2O2 compared to normal gravity 
control cultures. RNA-seq analysis revealed that expression of 153 genes 
was up-regulated and 94 genes were down-regulated during simulated 
microgravity growth. The study suggests that growth under microgravity 
analog conditions promotes changes in S. mutans gene expression and 
physiology that may translate to an altered cariogenic potential. 
Simulated microgravity cultures experienced a ten-fold decrease in 
supernatant glucose levels and increased expression of genes involved 
in carbohydrate metabolism and transport. The study provides insight 
into the response of S. mutans to low-fluid shear encountered in the 
oral cavity and has implications for understanding the effects of 
space flight on oral health.

nodes.title: Three-dimensional organotypic co-culture model of intestinal epithelial cells and macrophages to study Salmonella enterica colonization patterns
nodes.summary:
A three-dimensional co-culture model of intestinal epithelial cells and macrophages was developed to study Salmonella enterica colonization patterns.
The model was created using the NASA Rotating Wall Vessel bioreactor and consisted of HT-29 epithelial cells and U937 macrophages.
The co-culture model exhibited in vivo-like structural and phenotypic characteristics, including apical-basolateral polarity and mucin production.
The model was used to study the colonization profiles of distinct Salmonella pathovars, including Typhimurium and Typhi.
The presence of macrophages in the co-culture model had an inhibitory effect on the adherence, invasion, and survival of all Salmonella strains evaluated.
The model was able to distinguish between the Salmonella pathovars and their ability to colonize and survive within the host cells.

nodes.title: Interplay of space radiation and microgravity in DNA damage and DNA damage response
nodes.summary:
Space radiation and microgravity pose a threat to DNA integrity in living organisms.
Space radiation can cause DNA damage directly or indirectly through free radical production.
Microgravity can impact DNA repair, leading to accumulation of severe DNA lesions.
Studies have investigated the effects of space radiation and microgravity on DNA damage and repair.
Results from ground-based and spaceflight studies have been conflicting, with some showing increased sensitivity to radiation and decreased DNA repair under microgravity.
Further experiments are needed in the true space environment to understand the interplay between space radiation and microgravity on DNA damage and repair.
The effects of space radiation and microgravity on DNA damage and repair are complex and influenced by various factors, including radiation type, sequence, and exposure duration.

nodes.title: Cardiovascular progenitor cells cultured aboard the International Space Station exhibit altered developmental and functional properties
nodes.summary:
Cardiovascular progenitor cells cultured aboard the International Space Station exhibit altered developmental and functional properties.
These changes include increased expression of early developmental markers and enhanced proliferative potential in neonatal cells.
Spaceflight reduces terminal mesodermal derivative marker expression and endothelial-like tube formation in neonatal cells.
Cells from both age groups demonstrate enhanced migratory capacity after spaceflight culture.
DNA repair gene expression is induced in both neonatal and adult cells following spaceflight.
Stress response genes are also induced, but apoptosis is not observed in either age group.
These findings suggest that spaceflight can modify the properties of cardiac progenitor cells.

nodes.title: Acceleration profiles and processing methods for parabolic flight
nodes.summary:
Parabolic flights provide a cost-effective way to simulate space environments with variable gravity levels.
A solution for collecting and analyzing altered gravity environments during parabolic flights is presented.
The approach uses a commercially available accelerometer and vibration measurement system.
Data from a Boeing 727-200F flight with 20 parabolas is used to validate the solution.
The method allows for unsupervised classification of all phases of flight and provides a consistent approach to quantifying gravito-inertial accelerations.
The solution can be integrated with diverse experimental designs and does not depend on accelerometer orientation.
The code and data are made publicly available to facilitate future parabolic flight research and analysis.

nodes.title: Articular cartilage and sternal fibrocartilage respond differently to extended microgravity
nodes.summary:
Articular cartilage and sternal fibrocartilage respond differently to extended microgravity.
The study found that articular cartilage showed evidence of degradation after 30 days of microgravity.
Proteoglycan staining was reduced and mRNA expression of cartilage matrix proteins was decreased.
In contrast, sternal cartilage showed no evidence of cartilage breakdown and a distinct gene expression profile.
The difference in response is attributed to the relative change in biomechanical environment.
Weight-bearing articular cartilage is negatively affected by microgravity, while minimally loaded sternal fibrocartilage is not.
Maintenance of biomechanical loading during spaceflight may minimize articular cartilage destruction.

nodes.title: Spaceflight-induced alternative splicing during seedling development in Arabidopsis thaliana
nodes.summary:
Plants grown in spaceflight experience novel environmental signals, including microgravity and ionizing radiation.
The spaceflight-induced transcriptome was analyzed with a focus on genes that undergo alternative splicing.
RNA sequence data from the APEX03 spaceflight experiment was re-examined to detect alternative splicing differences induced by spaceflight.
Presence/absence variation analysis identified putative expression-level differences in alternatively spliced isoforms between spaceflight and ground controls.
The study provides the first evidence of a role for alternative splicing in the molecular processes of physiological adaptation to the spaceflight environment.
Alternative splicing enhances the diversity of the eukaryotic transcriptome, and unique patterns arise in response to terrestrial plant stressors.
The results serve as strong evidence that alternative splicing has a role during the molecular adaptation process to the spaceflight environment in higher eukaryotic organisms.

nodes.title: Longitudinal time course of muscle impairments during partial weight-bearing in rats
nodes.summary:
Muscle impairments occur in rats during partial weight-bearing due to reduced mechanical loading.
The impairments are dose-dependent and correlated to the level of weight-bearing.
Muscle mass and function are significantly impaired after 7 days of suspension.
The soleus muscle atrophies more than the gastrocnemius muscle in reduced weight-bearing environments.
A fiber type switch is observed in the soleus and gastrocnemius muscles with decreasing weight-bearing level.
The partial weight-bearing model in rats is effective in modeling the impact of reduced mechanical loading on muscle health.
The model can be used to investigate the effects of partial gravity and to develop mitigating strategies for muscle impairments during space missions.

nodes.title: Spaceflight and simulated microgravity conditions increase virulence of Serratia marcescens in the Drosophila melanogaster infection model
nodes.summary:
Serratia marcescens bacteria grown in spaceflight conditions were more lethal to Drosophila melanogaster hosts than ground control bacteria.
The increased virulence of spaceflight bacteria was also observed in bacteria grown in simulated microgravity conditions on the ground.
The increased virulence phenotype was temporary and did not persist after the bacteria were passaged on the ground.
Spaceflight bacteria grew at a greater rate than ground controls in vitro and in the host at later time points.
The increased virulence of spaceflight bacteria was similar in magnitude between wild-type flies and those with impaired immune function.
Infection with spaceflight bacteria did not induce significant changes in host gene expression related to immunity.
The study suggests that spaceflight induces physiological changes in the pathogen, resulting in increased virulence, which can be reversed after normal growth on the ground.

nodes.title: Spaceflight and simulated microgravity conditions increase virulence of Serratia marcescens in the Drosophila melanogaster infection model
nodes.summary:
Serratia marcescens bacteria grown in spaceflight conditions were more lethal to Drosophila melanogaster hosts than ground control bacteria.
The increased virulence of spaceflight bacteria was also observed in bacteria grown in simulated microgravity conditions on the ground.
The increased virulence phenotype was temporary and did not persist after the bacteria were passaged on the ground.
Spaceflight bacteria grew at a greater rate than ground controls in vitro and in the host at later time points.
The increased virulence of spaceflight bacteria was similar in magnitude between wild-type flies and those with impaired immune function.
Infection with spaceflight bacteria did not induce significant changes in host gene expression related to immunity.
The study suggests that spaceflight induces physiological changes in the pathogen, resulting in increased virulence, which can be reversed after normal growth on the ground.

nodes.title: Dose-dependent skeletal deficits due to varied reductions in mechanical loading in rats
nodes.summary:
Reduced skeletal loading leads to marked bone loss in rats. 
Trabecular bone density declined in proportion to the degree of unloading and continued progressively with time. 
Ex vivo measurements revealed deficits in bone volume fraction and trabecular microarchitecture. 
Histologic analyses showed decreased osteoblast number and mineralizing surface in unloaded rats. 
Three-point bending of the femoral diaphysis indicated modest or no reductions in femoral stiffness and estimated modulus. 
The study demonstrates dose-dependent trabecular bone loss in rats following exposure to differing levels of quadrupedal partial weight-bearing. 
The skeletal deficits appear progressive, not reaching a plateau by 4 weeks of partial weight-bearing.

nodes.title: Evaluating the effect of spaceflight on the host-pathogen interaction between human intestinal epithelial cells and Salmonella Typhimurium
nodes.summary:
The STL-IMMUNE study investigated the effects of spaceflight on host-pathogen interactions between human intestinal epithelial cells and Salmonella Typhimurium. 
Human colonic epithelial cells (HT-29) were cultured in hollow fiber bioreactors and infected with S. Typhimurium during spaceflight. 
The study used a combination of transcriptomic and proteomic analyses to examine the responses of both the host cells and the pathogen to spaceflight. 
The results showed significant changes in the expression of genes and proteins involved in various cellular processes, including immune response and stress response. 
The study also found that spaceflight altered the virulence of S. Typhimurium and its ability to infect host cells. 
The findings of this study have important implications for understanding the risks of infectious diseases during space missions. 
The study provides new insights into the effects of spaceflight on host-pathogen interactions and highlights the need for further research in this area.

nodes.title: Modeled microgravity alters lipopolysaccharide and outer membrane vesicle production of the beneficial symbiont Vibrio fischeri
nodes.summary:
Modeled microgravity alters the production of lipopolysaccharide (LPS) and outer membrane vesicles (OMVs) in Vibrio fischeri.
The bacterium sheds more LPS under microgravity-like conditions, which is correlated with increased OMV production.
Flagellar motility is not necessary for the increase in LPS shedding under microgravity conditions.
The cell membranes of V. fischeri are more susceptible to disruption when cultivated under modeled microgravity conditions.
The increased release of OMVs under microgravity conditions may reflect changes in membrane integrity.
The study suggests that microgravity-like conditions can alter the physiology of symbiotic microbes, which may have implications for host health during spaceflight.
The findings provide insight into how microgravity-like conditions may alter host-microbe relationships at the physiological level.

nodes.title: Effects of spaceflight aboard the International Space Station on mouse estrous cycle and ovarian gene expression
nodes.summary:
Female mice were exposed to microgravity for 37 days on the International Space Station.
The effects of spaceflight on the estrous cycle and ovarian gene expression were examined.
No significant differences were found in the proportion of animals in each phase of the estrous cycle.
Ovarian tissue steroid levels indicated no differences in estradiol, but lower progesterone levels in flight mice.
Genes involved in ovarian steroidogenic function were not differentially expressed across groups.
The study suggests that female mice can exhibit estrous cyclic activity during extended microgravity exposure.
The ability of these females to exhibit estrous cycle activity provides a model to test fertility in microgravity.

nodes.title: Rad-Bio-App: a discovery environment for biologists to explore spaceflight-related radiation exposures
nodes.summary:
Rad-Bio-App is a web-accessible database that imports radiation metadata from NASA's GeneLab data repository.
It allows users to explore experiments in the context of radiation exposure and other metadata.
The app provides an easy-to-use, graphically-driven environment for radiation biologists and non-specialist researchers.
It enables visualization and understanding of the impact of ionizing radiation on biological systems in spaceflight.
Rad-Bio-App helps identify space radiation conditions not simulated on the ground.
It allows filtering of data by radiation type, energy, dose, and dose rate.
The app facilitates the identification of common molecular signatures from biology experiencing similar radiation dose rates.

nodes.title: Evidence for increased thermogenesis in female C57BL/6J mice housed aboard the international space station
nodes.summary:
Female C57BL/6J mice were housed on the International Space Station for 37 days. 
The mice were then sacrificed and their carcasses were returned to Earth for analysis. 
RNA was isolated from brown adipose tissue (BAT) and white adipose tissue (WAT) samples. 
Spaceflight resulted in differential gene expression in BAT, indicating increased non-shivering thermogenesis. 
Gene expression in WAT suggested increased glucose uptake and metabolism, adipogenesis, and Î²-oxidation. 
The RNA integrity was assessed and found to be of good quality for both flight and ground control animals. 
The study's findings provide evidence for increased thermogenesis in female C57BL/6J mice exposed to spaceflight conditions.

nodes.title: Evaluating the lettuce metatranscriptome with MinION sequencing for future spaceflight food production applications
nodes.summary:
Healthy plants are vital for successful long-duration space missions as they provide life support and food.
The microbiome of plants plays a critical role in improving plant health and production.
A methodology was developed to investigate the transcriptional activities of the microbiome of red romaine lettuce.
Microbial transcripts were enriched from host-microbe total RNA and sequenced using the Oxford Nanopore MinION platform.
The results showed that this approach was highly reproducible and effective for detecting microbial transcriptional activity.
The study demonstrated the feasibility of using metatranscriptomics to monitor the transcriptional activity of crop microbiomes.
This approach can help facilitate and maintain plant health for on-orbit space food production.

nodes.title: Overexpression of catalase in mitochondria mitigates changes in hippocampal cytokine expression following simulated microgravity and isolation
nodes.summary:
Isolation and simulated microgravity alter cytokine expression in the hippocampus and plasma.
Eleven cytokines were elevated in single housed mice compared to social housed mice.
MCAT mice, which overexpress catalase in mitochondria, were protected from these changes.
Simulated microgravity and isolation led to discrete sets of differentially expressed cytokines.
Mitochondrial ROS signaling contributed to cytokine responses in the CNS.
MCAT mice exhibited reduced oxidative damage and inflammation in the hippocampus.
The study's findings implicate mitochondrial ROS in neuroimmune responses to microgravity and isolation.

nodes.title: Î±Klotho decreases after reduced weight-bearing from both spaceflight and hindlimb unloading
nodes.summary:
AlphaKlotho levels decreased after reduced weight-bearing from both spaceflight and hindlimb unloading. 
Plasma Î±Klotho was 50% lower in mice after 35 days in orbit aboard the ISS compared to ground controls. 
Hindlimb unloading also lowered circulating plasma Î±Klotho by 36% after 30 days. 
Exercise after hindlimb unloading partially or fully recovered Î±Klotho levels, depending on the type of exercise. 
Climbing exercise fully recovered Î±Klotho levels, while running exercise only partially recovered them. 
No differences were observed in FGF23 concentration between groups. 
The decrease in Î±Klotho post-flight occurred with reduced gastrocnemius mass, suggesting a link between Î±Klotho and skeletal muscle activity.

nodes.title: Characterization of gene expression profiles in the mouse brain after 35 days of spaceflight mission
nodes.summary:
Gene expression profiles in mouse brain tissue were characterized after a 35-day spaceflight mission.
A total of 54 genes were differently expressed between the flight and ground control groups.
Many pathways associated with cellular stress, inflammation, apoptosis, and metabolism were altered.
Downregulation of genes involved in neuronal function, oligodendrocyte differentiation, and myelin sheath maintenance was observed.
Immune-related genes were also downregulated, suggesting impaired antimicrobial defense and increased viral susceptibility.
The study suggests that spaceflight-induced stress responses may have a significant impact on neuronal function and immune regulation.
Altered gene expression profiles may have long-term effects on brain morphology and organism behavior.

nodes.title: Microgravity enhances the phenotype of Arabidopsis zigzag-1 and reduces the Wortmannin-induced vacuole fusion in root cells
nodes.summary:
Microgravity enhances the phenotype of Arabidopsis zigzag-1 by reducing hypocotyl growth. 
The microgravity environment of the ISS does not alter the association of vacuoles and amyloplasts. 
Wortmannin-induced vacuole fusion is delayed in microgravity, particularly in the epidermis. 
The feasibility of chemical treatments in plants on the ISS was demonstrated using the BRIC-PDFU hardware. 
Fixation of fluorescent protein-labeled organelles on the ISS is feasible, allowing for post-flight microscopy. 
The microgravity environment may slow down membrane fusion events in plants, but not sufficiently to inhibit growth. 
The study's results contribute to the understanding of plant cell biology in microgravity environments.

nodes.title: Microfluidics-integrated spaceflight hardware for measuring muscle strength of Caenorhabditis elegans on the International Space Station
nodes.summary:
Caenorhabditis elegans is used as a model organism to study muscle strength in microgravity.
A microfluidic device called NemaFlex-S is designed to measure muscle strength of C. elegans.
The device is integrated with a worm-loading apparatus to facilitate easy loading of worms.
The apparatus is designed to prevent contamination and minimize crew time on the ISS.
The NemaFlex-S device and worm-loading apparatus were launched to the ISS and operated successfully.

nodes.title: Meta-analysis of the space flight and microgravity response of the Arabidopsis plant transcriptome
nodes.summary:
Spaceflight imposes a unique set of environmental effects on plants, including microgravity and increased radiation exposure. 
A meta-analysis of 15 Arabidopsis thaliana spaceflight experiments was conducted to understand the plant response to spaceflight. 
The analysis revealed that factors such as analysis type and environmental conditions can confound comparisons between datasets. 
A curated matrix of metadata was developed to facilitate comparisons between studies with similar experimental designs. 
The analysis identified common responses to spaceflight, including changes in cell wall processes and oxidative stress. 
The study also highlighted the importance of considering the effects of spaceflight on plant physiology and development. 
The results provide a foundation for future research on plant responses to spaceflight and the development of strategies for plant growth in space. 
The study's findings have implications for the use of plants in space exploration and the development of sustainable life support systems.

nodes.title: Microbial applications for sustainable space exploration beyond low Earth orbit
nodes.summary:
Microbes play a crucial role in sustainable space exploration beyond low Earth orbit.
They can be used for bioregenerative life support systems, in situ resource utilization, and biological applications.
Microbes can help with air and water recycling, waste management, and food production.
They can also be used for energy generation through microbial fuel cells and biomining.
However, microbes can also have negative impacts, such as increased pathogenicity and biofilm formation.
Mitigation strategies, such as antimicrobial coatings and CRISPR/Cas technologies, are being developed to address these concerns.

nodes.title: Future space experiment platforms for astrobiology and astrochemistry research
nodes.summary:
Astrobiology and astrochemistry research rely on space experiments to address key topics. 
The International Space Station and future platforms like CubeSats and the Lunar Orbital Gateway offer opportunities for experiments. 
Key topics include understanding the origins of life, habitability, and signs of life. 
Space experiments can study the effects of microgravity, radiation, and other environmental factors on biological systems. 
The European Space Agency's Topical Team has identified recommendations for future experiments and platforms. 
In situ measurements and experimental parameters are crucial for advancing scientific knowledge in astrobiology and astrochemistry. 
Future space platforms will enable the search for life beyond Earth and the study of planetary habitability.

nodes.title: Influence of the spaceflight environment on macrophage lineages
nodes.summary:
Macrophages play a crucial role in the immune system, bridging innate and adaptive immunity. 
Spaceflight and microgravity can alter macrophage function and phenotype, leading to immune dysregulation. 
Studies have shown that spaceflight can impair macrophage phagocytosis, antigen presentation, and cytokine production. 
Microgravity and cosmic radiation can also affect macrophage polarization, leading to changes in inflammatory responses. 
Isolation, confinement, and hypercapnia can further exacerbate immune dysfunction in spaceflight environments. 
Understanding the effects of spaceflight on macrophages is essential for developing countermeasures to mitigate immune-related risks in deep space missions. 
Future research should focus on characterizing macrophage responses to combined spaceflight stressors and developing targeted interventions to optimize immune function.

nodes.title: Paving the way to better understand the effects of prolonged spaceflight on operational performance and its neural bases
nodes.summary:
Space exploration poses significant risks to human behavior and performance due to prolonged exposure to microgravity and other environmental stressors. 
Research gaps exist in understanding the effects of spaceflight on cognitive domains, particularly visuospatial processing and spatial navigation. 
Sex-specific differences in response to spaceflight are unclear due to the underrepresentation of women in astronaut corps. 
The use of integrative omics technologies can help elucidate the mechanisms underlying changes in brain and behavior. 
Understanding the internal representation of gravity and its effects on the nervous system is crucial for developing effective countermeasures. 
Artificial gravity and personalized countermeasures, such as autonomous self-adaptive training and augmented feedback, may help mitigate neurobehavioral risks. 
An integrative framework combining multiple disciplines and methodologies is necessary to address the complex challenges of space exploration and promote a holistic understanding of human adaptation to spaceflight.

nodes.title: Impacts of radiation exposure, hindlimb unloading, and recovery on murine skeletal muscle cell telomere length
nodes.summary:
Astronauts experience muscle atrophy and telomere length changes during spaceflight.
This study used a hindlimb unloading and radiation exposure model to mimic spaceflight conditions in mice.
Telomere lengthening was observed in muscle stem cells and myonuclei, but not in endothelial cells.
The combination of radiation and hindlimb unloading had a synergistic effect on telomere lengthening.
Telomere length did not return to baseline levels after a 2-week recovery period.
The study suggests that alternative lengthening of telomeres (ALT) mechanisms may be involved in telomere lengthening.

nodes.title: Biofilm formation of Pseudomonas aeruginosa in spaceflight is minimized on lubricant impregnated surfaces
nodes.summary:
Pseudomonas aeruginosa biofilm formation is minimized on lubricant impregnated surfaces in spaceflight.
Biofilms in microgravity are less robust than on Earth, with reduced biomass and surface area coverage.
Lubricant impregnated surfaces strongly inhibit biofilm formation compared to stainless steel surfaces.
The inhibition effect is greater in spaceflight than on Earth, making lubricant impregnated surfaces a promising option for spacecraft use.
Gene expression analysis reveals potential mechanisms of biofilm reduction on lubricant impregnated surfaces.
The results suggest that lubricant impregnated surfaces could be used to reduce biofilm formation in spacecraft components.
Biofilm formation on lubricant impregnated surfaces in microgravity remains limited, with minimal changes in gene expression over time.

nodes.title: Bioreactor development for skeletal muscle hypertrophy and atrophy by manipulating uniaxial cyclic strain: proof of concept
nodes.summary:
Skeletal muscles adapt to changes in tensile loading by adjusting their mass and cross-sectional area.
A bioreactor was developed to simulate skeletal muscle tensile loading during spaceflight experiments.
The bioreactor uses uniaxial cyclic strain to induce hypertrophy and atrophy in murine skeletal muscle myotubes.
Myotube diameter increased significantly following 2 and 5 days of cyclic stretch.
Cessation of cyclic stretch resulted in substantial atrophy and elevation of catabolic markers.
The bioreactor mimics the effects of overloading and microgravity-induced skeletal muscle atrophy.
The StrexCell system is a viable alternative bioreactor to study spaceflight and re-loading in skeletal muscle cells.

nodes.title: Explainable machine learning identifies multi-omics signatures of muscle response to spaceflight in mice
nodes.summary:
Muscle atrophy is a major challenge faced by astronauts during spaceflight due to prolonged exposure to microgravity.
Machine learning methods can identify patterns in complex biological data to discover biomarkers in heterogeneous datasets.
QLattice symbolic regression was used to predict calcium reuptake levels and classify spaceflight and ground control mice based on multi-omics features.
The top features predictive of Ca2+ uptake rate in TA muscle were Acyp1 and Rps7 proteins, which may play a role in the dysregulation of calcium induced by spaceflight.
Gene set enrichment analysis revealed significant enrichment of biological signaling involved in apoptosis, endocytosis, and protein localization in TA muscle.
The QLattice analysis identified critical genes playing an important role in calcium reuptake of TA and SOL muscles, which could serve as targets for future interventions to reduce muscle atrophy during space travel.

nodes.title: Altered quorum sensing and physiology of Staphylococcus aureus during spaceflight detected by multi-omics data analysis
nodes.summary:
Staphylococcus aureus undergoes significant alterations in physiology and virulence factor production in spaceflight environments.
The Accessory Gene Regulator quorum sensing system is highly upregulated in spaceflight samples.
Increased expression of virulence factors, including proteases and toxins, is observed in spaceflight samples.
S. aureus metabolism is altered in spaceflight, with changes in amino acid metabolism and transport of non-preferred carbon sources.
The bacterium's ability to cause disease may be affected by its altered physiology and virulence factor production in spaceflight environments.
Spaceflight cultures exhibit increased cell density and altered protein secretion compared to ground control cultures.
Overall, the study suggests that S. aureus poses a potential health risk to astronauts during long-term spaceflight missions.

nodes.title: Published in cooperation with the Biodesign Institute at Arizona State University, with the support of NASA
nodes.summary:
Altered gravitational conditions affect human physiology, causing changes in musculoskeletal, cardiovascular, immune, and nervous systems.
Microgravity exposure leads to severe abnormalities in the central nervous system of Mus musculus, including neuroinflammation and altered gene expression.
The musculoskeletal system is also vulnerable to microgravity, with changes in gene expression, muscle atrophy, and bone loss.
Comparative meta-analysis reveals overlap and reproducibility in genes identified as differentially expressed within musculoskeletal tissues in each species.
However, the level of overlap between species is limited, partly due to the limited availability of human samples.
Further research is needed to understand the effects of microgravity on human physiology and to identify potential countermeasures.

nodes.title: npj | microgravity Brief communication Published in cooperation with the Biodesign Institute at Arizona State University, with the support of NASA
nodes.summary:
The NASA Open Science Data Repository provides access to biological studies, including the SpaceX Inspiration4 mission. 
This dataset encompasses omics and clinical assays, facilitating comprehensive research on space-induced biological responses. 
The data allows for multi-modal, longitudinal assessments, bridging the gap between human and model organism studies. 
Community-driven data standards enable artificial intelligence and machine learning to glean insights, guiding future mission planning. 
The dataset includes omics assays, such as direct RNA sequencing and metagenomics, as well as clinical assays for blood profiling. 
All subjects were consented and samples were collected and processed under the approval of the Institutional Review Board. 
The data can be programmatically accessed through GLOpenAPI, enabling researchers to analyze the data and gain insights into space-induced biological responses.

nodes.title: npj | microgravity Brief communication Published in cooperation with the Biodesign Institute at Arizona State University, with the support of NASA
nodes.summary:
The NASA Open Science Data Repository provides access to biological studies, including the SpaceX Inspiration4 mission. 
This dataset encompasses omics and clinical assays, facilitating comprehensive research on space-induced biological responses. 
The data allows for multi-modal, longitudinal assessments, bridging the gap between human and model organism studies. 
Community-driven data standards enable artificial intelligence and machine learning to glean insights, guiding future mission planning. 
The dataset includes omics assays, such as direct RNA sequencing and metagenomics, as well as clinical assays for blood profiling. 
All subjects were consented and samples were collected and processed under the approval of the Institutional Review Board. 
The data can be programmatically accessed through GLOpenAPI, enabling researchers to analyze the data and gain insights into space-induced biological responses.

nodes.title: npj | microgravity Brief communication Published in cooperation with the Biodesign Institute at Arizona State University, with the support of NASA
nodes.summary:
Spaceflight causes significant skeletal muscle atrophy and weakness due to muscle unloading and Ca 2+ dysregulation. 
The sarco(endo)plasmic reticulum Ca 2+ ATPase (SERCA) pump is responsible for regulating Ca 2+ levels in muscle cells. 
Manganese(III) meso-tetrakis(N-n-butoxyethylpyridinium-2-yl) porphyrin (BuOE) was used as an antioxidant treatment. 
Soleus muscles from space-flown mice showed impaired Ca 2+ uptake ability and increased reactive oxygen/nitrogen species (RONS). 
BuOE treatment did not attenuate muscle atrophy or SERCA dysfunction in space-flown mice. 
Spaceflight increased SERCA's ionophore ratio and 4-HNE content, indicating SR Ca 2+ leak and oxidative stress. 
Future studies should investigate alternative therapeutics to increase SERCA activation or reduce Ca 2+ leak.

nodes.title: npj | microgravity Brief communication Published in cooperation with the Biodesign Institute at Arizona State University, with the support of NASA
nodes.summary:
Spaceflight causes significant skeletal muscle atrophy and weakness due to muscle unloading and Ca 2+ dysregulation. 
The sarco(endo)plasmic reticulum Ca 2+ ATPase (SERCA) pump is responsible for regulating Ca 2+ levels in muscle cells. 
Manganese(III) meso-tetrakis(N-n-butoxyethylpyridinium-2-yl) porphyrin (BuOE) was used as an antioxidant treatment. 
Soleus muscles from space-flown mice showed impaired Ca 2+ uptake ability and increased reactive oxygen/nitrogen species (RONS). 
BuOE treatment did not attenuate muscle atrophy or SERCA dysfunction in space-flown mice. 
Spaceflight increased SERCA's ionophore ratio and 4-HNE content, indicating SR Ca 2+ leak and oxidative stress. 
Future studies should investigate alternative therapeutics to increase SERCA activation or reduce Ca 2+ leak.

nodes.title: npj | microgravity Article Published in cooperation with the Biodesign Institute at Arizona State University, with the support of NASA
nodes.summary:
Exposure to microgravity reduces the cytotoxicity of natural killer cells against leukemia cells.
This reduction in cytotoxicity is observed in both NK-92MI cells and primary human NK cells.
The reduction in cytotoxicity is more pronounced when NK cells are exposed to continuous microgravity.
RNA-seq analysis reveals changes in gene expression that may contribute to the reduced cytotoxicity.
The combined exposure to space radiation and microgravity may increase the risk of leukemia in astronauts.
The study's findings have implications for the health and safety of astronauts on long-duration space missions.
The reduction in NK cell function may be mitigated by targeting specific pathways altered by microgravity.

nodes.title: npj | microgravity Article Published in cooperation with the Biodesign Institute at Arizona State University, with the support of NASA
nodes.summary:
Exposure to microgravity reduces the cytotoxicity of natural killer cells against leukemia cells.
This reduction in cytotoxicity is observed in both NK-92MI cells and primary human NK cells.
The reduction in cytotoxicity is more pronounced when NK cells are exposed to continuous microgravity.
RNA-seq analysis reveals changes in gene expression that may contribute to the reduced cytotoxicity.
The changes in gene expression include upregulation of inhibitory receptors and downregulation of activating receptors.
The reduced cytotoxicity of NK cells in microgravity may increase the risk of leukemia in astronauts during space missions.
The findings of this study have implications for the health and safety of astronauts on long-duration space missions.

nodes.title: Published in cooperation with the Biodesign Institute at Arizona State University, with the support of NASA
nodes.summary:
Stem cell research in space has provided insights into stem cell properties and behavior in microgravity.
Microgravity offers a unique environment for stem cell expansion and differentiation.
Studies have shown that mesenchymal stem cells, hematopoietic stem cells, and neural stem cells can be grown in space.
These cells have potential therapeutic applications for various diseases and injuries.
However, there are limitations and gaps in knowledge, including conflicting evidence on the effects of microgravity on stem cells.
Further research is needed to understand the effects of microgravity on stem cell growth and differentiation.
The use of space-grown stem cells for clinical applications requires standard safety and functionality protocols and regulatory approvals.

nodes.title: npj | microgravity Article Published in cooperation with the Biodesign Institute at Arizona State University, with the support of NASA
nodes.summary:
Female Sprague-Dawley rats exposed to hindlimb unloading (HLU) for 14 days showed increased aortic pulse wave velocity (PWV) compared to controls. 
Male rats did not exhibit changes in PWV after HLU exposure. 
The increase in PWV in female rats was accompanied by lower levels of aortic G protein-coupled estrogen receptor (GPER) and peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor gamma (PPARÎ³). 
Oxidative stress markers, such as 8-hydroxy-2'-deoxyguanosine (8-OHdG), were also increased in female rats after HLU. 
Administration of the GPER agonist G1 reduced PWV and 8-OHdG levels in HLU-exposed female rats. 
These findings suggest that lower GPER levels contribute to arterial stiffening in female rats exposed to simulated microgravity. 
The study highlights sex-specific vascular adaptations to microgravity and the potential role of GPER in mitigating arterial stiffness.

nodes.title: 41564 2024 Article 1635
nodes.summary:
Astronauts' microbiomes change during short-term spaceflight, 
with most alterations being transient across body sites. 
The oral microbiome exhibits longer-term shifts, 
including increased plaque-associated bacteria. 
Microbial genes associated with phage activity and stress response 
are enriched across multiple body sites. 
The study reveals a core functional microbial landscape of spaceflight, 
with implications for future missions and spacecraft design. 
Host immune cell gene expression is correlated with microbial features, 
particularly in the oral microbiome. 
The research provides insights into the interplay between the space environment 
and host-microbiome composition, 
informing strategies for maintaining astronaut health during space travel.

nodes.title: Check for updates
nodes.summary:
Astronauts on the I4 mission underwent comprehensive physiological profiling 
using 13 biospecimen sample types and multi-omic assays. 
The study generated 2,911 samples and 1,194 processed samples for analysis. 
The results showed telomere elongation and changes in gene expression, 
including immune activation and DNA damage response. 
The data also revealed distinct RNA fingerprints of spaceflight and 
changes in the microbiome and proteome. 
The study's findings have implications for understanding the effects of spaceflight 
on the human body and for developing countermeasures for future missions. 
The data and resources from the study are available to the scientific community.

nodes.title: Molecular and physiological changes in the SpaceX Inspiration4 civilian crew
nodes.summary:
The Inspiration4 mission studied the effects of short-duration spaceflight on the human body.
The crew collected data on cardiovascular physiology, cognitive performance, and behavioral states.
Data showed modest effects on cardiovascular physiology and cognitive performance.
There was substantial interindividual variability in response to spaceflight.
Two of the four crew members experienced space motion sickness, consistent with previous reports. 
The study demonstrated the feasibility of collecting multidimensional measurements in commercial astronaut crews.
The data will contribute to the development of reference ranges and pre-flight preparatory tasks for future crew selection and mission planning.

nodes.title: Characterization of mouse ocular response to a 35-day spaceflight mission: Evidence of blood-retinal barrier disruption and ocular adaptations
nodes.summary:
Spaceflight induces apoptosis in retinal vascular endothelial cells and photoreceptors in mice.
The blood-retinal barrier (BRB) integrity is compromised due to changes in protein expression.
Proteomic analysis reveals alterations in cellular organization, cell cycle, and mitochondrial function.
Spaceflight increases the risk of BRB disruption, leading to possible ocular impairment and injury.
The study suggests that astronauts may be at risk for retinal damage and late degeneration.
The data indicate a complex cellular response to spaceflight, altering retina structure and BRB integrity.
The findings may help facilitate the development of countermeasures for human spaceflight and planetary exploration.

nodes.title: Effect of Leptin Deficiency on the Skeletal Response to Hindlimb Unloading in Adult Male Mice
nodes.summary:
Leptin-deficient ob/ob mice were compared to wild-type mice in their skeletal response to hindlimb unloading.
The study found that leptin deficiency did not attenuate unloading-induced osteopenia in male mice.
ob/ob mice had lower bone mass and density, and altered bone microarchitecture compared to wild-type mice.
Hindlimb unloading resulted in lower bone mineral content and density in both genotypes.
The magnitude of unloading-induced osteopenia was similar in ob/ob and wild-type mice, suggesting leptin is not required for bone loss induced by unweighting.
The study's findings have implications for understanding the role of leptin in bone metabolism and the skeletal response to mechanical unloading.

nodes.title: Spaceflight influences gene expression, photoreceptor integrity, and oxidative stressrelated damage in the murine retina
nodes.summary:
Spaceflight alters gene expression in the murine retina, affecting visual perception and phototransduction pathways.
Six hundred differentially expressed genes were identified, with 286 upregulated and 314 downregulated genes.
Twelve genes associated with retinitis pigmentosa were differentially expressed, indicating a potential link between spaceflight and retinal disease.
Differentially expressed transcription factors suggest changes in chromatin organization and regulation of gene expression.
The space environment decreases retinal tissue thickness and increases oxidative stress and cone photoreceptor damage.
Immunofluorescence staining revealed degradation of cone photoreceptors and increased retinal oxidative stress.
Micro-computed tomography imaging showed significant decreases in total retina, retinal pigment epithelium, and choroid layer thickness after spaceflight.

nodes.title: Multi-omics analysis of multiple missions to space reveal a theme of lipid dysregulation in mouse liver
nodes.summary:
Spaceflight has detrimental effects on astronaut physiology, including lipid metabolism disruption in the liver.
Mouse studies on the Space Shuttle and International Space Station (ISS) showed lipid accumulation in the liver.
Oil Red O staining and transcriptomic analysis revealed increased lipid metabolism and fatty acid processing in space-flown mice.
Key upstream regulators, including Glucagon and Insulin, were predicted to be commonly regulated across all conditions.
Proteomic analysis showed changes in lipid-related proteins, including Apolipoproteins and Cyp7a1, which are associated with NAFLD progression.
The study suggests that spaceflight induces NAFLD-related pathways in mice, independently of strain or mission duration.
These findings have implications for understanding the risks of liver disease in astronauts on long-duration space missions.

nodes.title: Author correction: Multi-omics analysis of multiple missions to space reveal a theme of lipid dysregulation in mouse liver
nodes.summary:
Space missions have been shown to affect the liver of mice, causing changes in gene expression and metabolism. 
Multi-omics analysis was used to study the effects of space travel on mouse liver. 
The analysis revealed a common theme of lipid dysregulation across multiple missions. 
Changes in lipid metabolism were observed, including alterations in fatty acid synthesis and degradation. 
The study also found changes in the expression of genes involved in lipid regulation. 
These changes were consistent across different space missions, suggesting a common response to space travel. 
The findings have implications for understanding the effects of space travel on liver function and overall health.

nodes.title: Validation of a new Rodent experimental System to investigate consequences of Long Duration Space Habitation
nodes.summary:
Female mice were launched into space and lived on the International Space Station for 21-37 days. 
The mice appeared healthy and active, with increased physical activity in microgravity. 
Body and organ weights were similar to ground controls, except for the thymus and liver, which were heavier in spaceflight mice. 
The soleus muscle showed expected atrophy due to microgravity. 
Tissue samples were collected and preserved on-orbit, and RNA quality was found to be acceptable for molecular analyses. 
The study demonstrates a new capability for long-duration rodent experiments in space with on-orbit sample recovery. 
The findings provide insights into the effects of microgravity on rodent physiology and behavior. 
The results have implications for understanding the consequences of long-duration space travel on living organisms.

nodes.title: Dietary countermeasure mitigates simulated spaceflight-induced osteopenia in mice
nodes.summary:
Mice were fed a control diet or a diet supplemented with dried plum powder to investigate the bone protective potential of dried plum against simulated spaceflight-induced bone loss. 
The study found that the dried plum diet prevented most of the bone loss caused by simulated microgravity and ionizing radiation in both the appendicular and axial skeleton. 
The dried plum diet also protected osteoblast progenitor cells from damage caused by hindlimb unloading, indicating its potential as a countermeasure against bone loss. 
The results suggest that dried plum may be an effective dietary supplement to prevent bone loss in astronauts and individuals exposed to microgravity and radiation. 
The study's findings have important implications for the development of countermeasures against bone loss in spaceflight and other environments where bone health is compromised. 
The dried plum diet was found to be effective in preventing bone loss in both the tibia and vertebrae, and its potential as a countermeasure against bone loss is promising. 
The study's results provide new insights into the potential of dietary interventions to prevent bone loss in spaceflight and other environments.

nodes.title: Sierra nevada sweep: metagenomic measurements of bioaerosols vertically distributed across the troposphere
nodes.summary:
Aerobiology research was conducted using NASA's C-20A aircraft to study bioaerosols at different altitudes. 
The aircraft flew over the Sierra Nevada mountains at four altitudes: 10,000 ft, 20,000 ft, 30,000 ft, and 40,000 ft. 
Metagenomic sequencing and traditional culturing methods were used to analyze the bioaerosols. 
The results showed significant differences in microbial taxa between flight samples and control samples. 
The most abundant taxa identified in the flight samples included Achromobacter, Alcaligenes, Delftia, and Mycobacterium. 
Viable bacteria, including Bacillus zhangzhouensis and Bacillus pumilus, were also detected in the samples. 
The study's findings have implications for understanding the atmospheric microbiome and its potential impact on public health and agriculture. 
The research highlights the need for further studies to develop consistent sampling and analysis methodologies for aerobiology research.

nodes.title: nemaLife chip: a micropillar-based microfluidic culture device optimized for aging studies in crawling C. elegans
nodes.summary:
The NemaLife chip is a microfluidic device designed for whole-life culture of C. elegans.
It features a micropillar arena, sieve channels, and ports for feeding and reagent introduction.
The device allows for scoring of animal survival and health measures, such as pharyngeal pumping and tap-induced stimulated reversals.
The NemaLife chip eliminates the need for manual transfers and progeny-blocking chemical interventions.
It also reduces animal loss and stress associated with swim-induced fatigue in liquid environments.
The device has been validated with longevity analyses of classical aging mutants and RNAi knockdown of age-related genes.
The NemaLife chip enables reliable lifespan and physiological data collection, making it a valuable tool for aging studies in C. elegans.

nodes.title: Spaceflight and hind limb unloading induces an arthritic phenotype in knee articular cartilage and menisci of rodents
nodes.summary:
Reduced weight-bearing from spaceflight or hind limb unloading induces cartilage degradation in rodents.
Cartilage loss occurs at the region of greatest weight-bearing and tibial-femoral cartilage-cartilage contact.
Exercise after a period of joint unloading reduces cartilage degradation and improves thickness.
Running exercise is superior to climbing exercise in recovering cartilage damage after a period of reduced loading.
Meniscal volume is also affected by reduced weight-bearing, with exercise promoting recovery.
The study suggests that prescribed exercise programs may alleviate and recover articular cartilage damage in humans.

nodes.title: Immunological and hematological outcomes following protracted low dose/low dose rate ionizing radiation and simulated microgravity
nodes.summary:
Mice were exposed to simulated spaceflight conditions for 21 days, 
combining low-dose gamma irradiation and hindlimb unloading. 
At 7 days post-exposure, blood and spleen samples were analyzed. 
Results showed negligible differences in immune differentials, 
but significant changes in red blood cell differentials and morphology. 
Gene expression analysis revealed altered pathways involved in 
signal transduction, metabolism, cell cycle, and DNA repair. 
Inflammation and dysregulated immune function were also observed. 
The study suggests that recovery from spaceflight is a complex process. 
Immune and hematological systems are affected, with potential implications 
for astronaut health on long-duration space missions.

nodes.title: A multi-omics longitudinal study of the murine retinal response to chronic low-dose irradiation and simulated microgravity
nodes.summary:
Mice were exposed to low-dose gamma irradiation and hindlimb unloading to simulate space radiation and microgravity.
The study analyzed retinal tissue at 7 days, 1 month, and 4 months post-exposure using RNA-seq and reduced representation bisulfite sequencing.
A total of 4178 differentially methylated loci or regions and 457 differentially expressed genes were identified.
Nucleotide metabolism was enriched in all groups with activation at 1 month and suppression at 7 days and 4 months.
Genes and processes related to Notch and Wnt signaling showed alterations 4 months post-exposure.
Twenty-three genes showed significant changes in methylation and expression compared to unexposed controls.

nodes.title: High-gradient magnetic fields and starch metabolism: results from a space experiment
nodes.summary:
High-gradient magnetic fields were used to study their effect on starch metabolism in Brassica rapa seeds in space. 
The experiment was conducted on the Space-X Crew Resupply Service 3 mission and compared the effects of space, clinorotation, and static growth conditions. 
Amyloplast size in root tips increased under weightlessness but decreased under clinorotation, indicating that plants perceive weightlessness and adjust their metabolism. 
The data show that plants perceive weightlessness and that their metabolism adjusts to microgravity and mechanostimulation. 
Transcript analysis revealed that amylase activity is affected by mechanostimulation, with reduced transcription in space samples and enhanced transcription after clinorotation. 
The results support the concept of plant proprioception of weightlessness and metabolic control of amyloplast size, which is responsive to gravitational and mechanosensory responses. 
The study provides new insights into the effects of microgravity on plant growth and development, and has implications for future space missions and plant breeding programs.

nodes.title: Production of reactive oxygen species and involvement of bioprotectants during anhydrobiosis in the tardigrade Paramacrobiotus spatialis
nodes.summary:
The tardigrade Paramacrobiotus spatialis undergoes anhydrobiosis, a state of suspended metabolism, in response to desiccation.
Reactive oxygen species (ROS) production increases significantly during anhydrobiosis, causing oxidative stress.
Bioprotectants, such as glutathione peroxidase, play a crucial role in combating ROS and ensuring desiccation tolerance.
RNA interference was used to target genes involved in desiccation tolerance, including those encoding antioxidant enzymes and aquaporins.
Targeting the glutathione peroxidase gene compromised survival during desiccation, highlighting its importance in anhydrobiosis.
Aquaporins 3 and 10 were also found to be involved in rehydration, with their targeting affecting animal motility.
Desiccation tolerance in P. spatialis depends on the synergistic action of multiple molecules working together.

nodes.title: Phylogenomics, phenotypic, and functional traits of five novel (Earth-derived) bacterial species isolated from the International Space Station and their prevalence in metagenomes
nodes.summary:
Six novel bacterial species were isolated from the International Space Station (ISS) 
and characterized using whole-genome sequencing and phenotypic analysis.
The species belonged to four genera: Arthrobacter, Leifsonia, Paenibacillus, and Sporosarcina.
Phylogenetic analysis revealed that the novel species were distinct from previously described species.
The genomes of the novel species contained genes related to virulence, disease, and defense, 
as well as genes involved in antibiotic resistance and secondary metabolite production.
The study highlights the importance of characterizing the microbiome of the ISS 
and the potential for discovering new species with unique characteristics and applications.

nodes.title: Phylogenomics, phenotypic, and functional traits of five novel (Earth-derived) bacterial species isolated from the International Space Station and their prevalence in metagenomes
nodes.summary:
Six novel bacterial species were isolated from the International Space Station (ISS) 
and characterized using whole-genome sequencing and phenotypic analysis.
The species belonged to four genera: Arthrobacter, Leifsonia, Paenibacillus, and Sporosarcina.
Phylogenetic analysis revealed that the novel species were distinct from previously described species.
The genomes of the novel species contained genes related to virulence, disease, and defense, 
as well as genes involved in antibiotic resistance and secondary metabolite production.
The study highlights the importance of characterizing the microbiome of the ISS 
and the potential for discovering new species with unique characteristics and applications.

nodes.title: Effects of altered gravity on growth and morphology in Wolffia globosa implications for bioregenerative life support systems and space-based agriculture
nodes.summary:
Wolffia globosa was studied under altered gravity conditions to assess its potential as a space crop. 
The plant's growth and morphological responses were evaluated under simulated microgravity, partial gravity, and hypergravity environments. 
Results showed a slight reaction to different gravitational levels in growth and morphological traits. 
The relative growth rates of plants under simulated microgravity and partial gravity were reduced compared to other gravity levels. 
Morphological analysis revealed differences in plant dimensions and frond length-to-width ratios under diverse gravity conditions. 
The study's findings suggest that Wolffia globosa is responsive to gravitational changes, with its growth and morphological adaptations being slightly influenced by varying gravitational environments. 
Wolffia globosa's adaptability to altered gravity conditions makes it a potential candidate for space agriculture and bioregenerative life support systems.

nodes.title: Chromosomal positioning and epigenetic architecture influence DNA methylation patterns triggered by galactic cosmic radiation
nodes.summary:
Galactic cosmic radiation (GCR) causes significant changes to biological systems, including damage to DNA structure by altering epigenetic phenotype with emphasis on DNA methylation.
High-LET (56Fe, 28Si) and low-LET (X-ray) radiation induce distinct DNA methylation patterns, with 56Fe primarily increasing DNA methylation and X-ray decreasing it.
The spatial distribution of epigenetic modifications, such as H3K4me3 and H3K27ac, influences the effect of GCR on human cells, with higher methylation changes observed in outer layers of the nucleus.
Chromatin accessibility and multidimensional architecture of sequences may make H3K4me3 and H3K27ac-marked sequences more susceptible to radiation.
The study provides novel insights into epigenetic nuclear architecture and highlights the role of spatial distribution of key epigenetic modifications in response to GCR.

nodes.title: Aging and putative frailty biomarkers are altered by spaceflight
nodes.summary:
Spaceflight alters aging and frailty biomarkers in both rodents and humans.
Frailty-related genes are differentially expressed in various tissues, including muscles.
Interferon inflammatory response and muscle tissue development pathways are enriched in rodent muscles during spaceflight.
Novel sarcopenia-related genes are differentially expressed during spaceflight, and some predict sarcopenia with high accuracy.
Multiple frailty-related biomarkers are differentially expressed in human muscles during spaceflight, with some genes unique to humans or conserved between humans and mice.
Astronauts' cell-free DNA and PBMCs show differential expression of frailty genes, which may not return to baseline after reentry.
Metabolic flux simulations reveal dysregulation of metabolic functions related to frailty in spaceflight.

nodes.title: Fungal diversity differences in the indoor dust microbiome from built environments on earth and in space
nodes.summary:
Fungal diversity in indoor dust differs between Earth-based homes and the International Space Station (ISS).
Earth-based homes have a more diverse fungal community with 465 OTUs, compared to 102 OTUs on the ISS.
The most abundant fungal genera on Earth are Epicoccum, Alternaria, Pseudopithomyces, and Cladosporium.
In contrast, Aspergillus, Cyberlindnera, Rhodotorula, and Candida are more abundant on the ISS.
Fungal community composition changes significantly when exposed to elevated moisture conditions.
Bacterial communities also differ between Earth and ISS, with Earth having 237 bacterial ASVs and the ISS having 102.
The differences in microbial communities may be attributed to unique environmental stressors on the ISS, such as microgravity and radiation.

nodes.title: Impact of microgravity and lunar gravity on murine skeletal and immune systems during space travel
nodes.summary:
Microgravity and lunar gravity affect murine skeletal and immune systems during space travel.
The study investigated the impact of microgravity, lunar gravity, and normal gravity on mice.
Bone density reduction under microgravity was partially recovered by lunar gravity.
Thymus atrophy induced by microgravity was half recovered by both normal and lunar gravity.
Gene expression changes in the thymus and spleen were observed under different gravitational loads.
The study highlights organ-specific variations in responsiveness to gravity, serving as an animal test for establishing a molecular-level gravity threshold.

nodes.title: Analyzing the relationship between gene expression and phenotype in space-flown mice using a causal inference machine learning ensemble
nodes.summary:
Spaceflight has detrimental effects on human and rodent health, including liver dysfunction.
A machine learning ensemble called CRISP was used to identify genes correlated with lipid density in space-flown mice.
CRISP analysis revealed 20 genes associated with lipid metabolism, including Apoc3, Apoc1, and Scd1.
These genes were validated using pathway analysis, gene set enrichment, and scientific literature.
The results suggest that CRISP can identify causal relationships between gene expression and phenotype.
The study's findings have implications for understanding liver dysfunction in space-flown rodents and potentially in humans.

nodes.title: Behavioral and multiomics analysis of 3D clinostat simulated microgravity effect in mice focusing on the central nervous system
nodes.summary:
Mice exposed to 3D clinostat simulated microgravity showed decreased activity and altered gait.
They also exhibited enhanced fear memory and bone loss, with immune and endocrine changes.
The brain transcriptome was affected, with alterations in signaling pathways related to human diseases.
Serum metabolomics revealed changes in metabolic pathways, including ABC transporters and sphingolipid signaling.
The gut microbiota was also altered, with a reduction in Bacteroides and Turicibacter.
The 3D clinostat model was compared to hindlimb unloading and spaceflight models, showing distinct differences.
The model demonstrated a closer resemblance to spaceflight-induced brain transcriptome changes.

nodes.title: Identification of therapeutic targets for chronic kidney disease through Mendelian randomization analysis of druggable genes
nodes.summary:
Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD) is a complex condition with limited therapeutic options.
Mendelian randomization analysis identified 12 druggable genes associated with CKD risk.
The TUBB gene was found to be the most promising pharmacological target for CKD treatment.
Colocalization analysis suggested that CKD and TUBB may share a causal variant.
Gene Ontology and KEGG enrichment analyses revealed that significant genes are involved in MAP kinase activity and oxytocin signaling pathways.
The study provides valuable insights for future drug development in the context of CKD.
TUBB represents a potential therapeutic target for CKD, meriting further investigation into its underlying mechanisms.

nodes.title: Plants grown in Apollo lunar regolith present stress-associated transcriptomes that inform prospects for lunar exploration
nodes.summary:
Arabidopsis thaliana plants were grown in lunar regolith from Apollo 11, 12, and 17 missions. 
The plants showed slow development and stress morphologies, with differential gene expression indicating ionic stresses. 
All plants grown in lunar soils exhibited stress responses similar to those caused by salt, metal, and reactive oxygen species. 
The interaction between plants and lunar regolith needs to be further understood to enable efficient use of lunar regolith for life support. 
Plant growth in lunar regolith was challenging, with plants taking longer to develop and being smaller than those grown in JSC-1A simulant. 
The plants grown in Apollo 11 regolith struggled the most, while those in Apollo 17 regolith fared better. 
Lunar regolith can be used for plant production, but further characterization and optimization are required to make it a routine in situ resource.

nodes.title: Spaceflight induces changes in gene expression profiles linked to insulin and estrogen
nodes.summary:
Spaceflight alters gene expression profiles linked to insulin and estrogen signaling in mice and humans.
The liver is the most impacted organ by spaceflight, with inhibited insulin and estrogen receptor signaling.
Insulin resistance and hepatic steatosis are predicted to occur in the liver during spaceflight.
Estrogen signaling is also impaired, contributing to mitochondrial dysfunction and insulin resistance.
Changes in insulin and estrogen signaling are observed in multiple human missions, including the Inspiration4 mission.
The study highlights the importance of understanding the effects of spaceflight on insulin and estrogen signaling for future long-duration space missions.

nodes.title: Spaceflight induces changes in gene expression profiles linked to insulin and estrogen
nodes.summary:
Spaceflight alters gene expression profiles linked to insulin and estrogen signaling in mice and humans.
The liver is the most impacted organ by spaceflight, with inhibited insulin and estrogen receptor signaling.
Insulin resistance and hepatic steatosis are predicted to occur in the liver during spaceflight.
Estrogen signaling is also impaired, contributing to mitochondrial dysfunction and insulin resistance.
Changes in insulin and estrogen signaling are observed in multiple human missions, including the Inspiration4 mission.
The study highlights the importance of understanding the effects of spaceflight on insulin and estrogen signaling for future long-duration space missions.

nodes.title: Telomeric RNA (TERRA) increases in response to spaceflight and high-altitude climbing Check for updates
nodes.summary:
Telomeric RNA (TERRA) increases in response to spaceflight and high-altitude climbing.
TERRA transcripts are elevated in astronauts and climbers, indicating a role in DNA damage response.
Simulated microgravity does not lead to increased TERRA abundance, suggesting radiation exposure is key.
TERRA responds to ionizing radiation-induced DNA double-strand breaks (DSBs) in human cells.
TERRA accumulation at telomeric DSBs is observed, forming protective TERRA:telomeric DNA hybrids.

nodes.title: Tardigrade secretory proteins protect biological structures from desiccation Check for updates
nodes.summary:
Tardigrade secretory proteins, specifically SAHS proteins, have been found to protect biological structures from desiccation.
These proteins are highly structured and similar to fatty acid-binding proteins, with a large internal cavity that may be filled with water or solutes.
SAHS proteins undergo a structural shift from a beta-sheet to an alpha-helical structure in response to desiccation-mimicking conditions.
The proteins have been shown to protect liposomes and bacterial cells from desiccation-induced damage, with a notable increase in survival rates.
The protective effect of SAHS proteins is comparable to that of trehalose, a well-known cryoprotectant.
SAHS proteins may have practical applications in protecting non-tardigrade cells, such as agricultural microbes, against desiccation.
The proteins' ability to stabilize membrane-bound elements of cells makes them a potential tool for improving the durability of microbial biofertilizers.

nodes.title: Protein kinase 2 of the giant sarcomeric protein UNC-89 regulates mitochondrial morphology and function Check for updates
nodes.summary:
UNC-89 is a giant sarcomeric protein with two protein kinase domains, PK1 and PK2.
PK2 is a canonical kinase expected to be catalytically active and regulates mitochondrial morphology and function.
Mutants with a KtoA mutation in PK2 have normally organized sarcomeres and muscle function, but fragmented mitochondria.
The KtoA mutation leads to increased ATP levels, glycolysis, and altered electron transport chain complexes.
Mitochondrial fragmentation in PK2 mutants is due to increased association of DRP-1 with mitochondria.
The study suggests signaling from sarcomeres to mitochondria to match energy requirements with energy production.

nodes.title: Protein kinase 2 of the giant sarcomeric protein UNC-89 regulates mitochondrial morphology and function Check for updates
nodes.summary:
UNC-89 is a giant sarcomeric protein with two protein kinase domains, PK1 and PK2.
PK2 is a canonical kinase expected to be catalytically active and regulates mitochondrial morphology and function.

The study suggests signaling from sarcomeres to mitochondria to match energy requirements with energy production.

nodes.title: Genomic characterization and radiation tolerance of Naganishia kalamii sp. nov. and Cystobasidium onofrii sp. nov. from Mars 2020 mission assembly facilities
nodes.summary:
Two novel yeast species, Naganishia kalamii and Cystobasidium onofrii, 
were isolated from NASA cleanrooms and characterized using polyphasic taxonomy.
Phylogenetic analysis revealed that N. kalamii belongs to the N. albida clade, 
while C. onofrii is distantly related to C. benthicum.
Genomic analysis predicted proteins associated with dehydration and desiccation stress-response.
Both species showed UV-C resistance, with N. onofrii being more resistant.
The study highlights the importance of characterizing microorganisms in cleanrooms 
to prevent forward contamination of extraterrestrial environments.

nodes.title: Transcriptomics analysis reveals molecular alterations underpinning spaceflight dermatology Check for updates
nodes.summary:
Spaceflight poses a unique set of challenges to humans, including dermatological issues.
The biology driving skin issues in astronauts is not well understood, but transcriptomics analysis reveals molecular alterations.
Key biological changes related to skin health, DNA damage, and mitochondrial dysregulation are identified as potential drivers for skin health risks.
A machine learning model determines gene pairings associated with spaceflight response in the skin.
The study's findings can guide future research on developing countermeasures for mitigating spaceflight-associated skin damage.

nodes.title: Transcriptomics analysis reveals molecular alterations underpinning spaceflight dermatology Check for updates
nodes.summary:
Spaceflight poses a unique set of challenges to humans, including dermatological issues.
The biology driving skin issues in astronauts is not well understood, but transcriptomics analysis reveals molecular alterations.
Key biological changes related to skin health, DNA damage, and mitochondrial dysregulation are identified as potential drivers for skin health risks.
A machine learning model determines gene pairings associated with spaceflight response in the skin.
The study's findings can guide future research on developing countermeasures for mitigating spaceflight-associated skin damage.

nodes.title: TNO1 Is Involved in Salt Tolerance and Vacuolar Trafficking in Arabidopsis 1[W][OA]
nodes.summary:
TNO1 is a novel protein involved in salt tolerance and vacuolar trafficking in Arabidopsis. 
It localizes to the trans-Golgi network (TGN) and interacts with SYP41. 
The tno1 mutant shows increased sensitivity to high concentrations of NaCl, KCl, and LiCl. 
TNO1 is required for efficient trafficking of some vacuolar proteins. 
The tno1 mutant has delayed formation of the brefeldin A (BFA) compartment in cotyledons. 
TNO1 may function in maintaining TGN structure or identity, potentially via roles in vesicle fusion. 
It is proposed to be a tethering factor at the TGN, similar to USO1 in yeast.

nodes.title: The smallest space miners: principles of space biomining
nodes.summary:
Space biomining is a promising approach for in-situ resource utilization in space exploration.
It involves using microorganisms to extract valuable resources from extraterrestrial rocks and regolith.
The technique has several advantages, including lower energy requirements and potential for recycling waste.
However, space conditions, such as low gravity and radiation, pose significant challenges to biomining.
Research is needed to develop microorganisms and technologies that can thrive in these conditions.
The use of synthetic biology and bioengineering can help overcome these challenges and improve biomining efficiency.
Space biomining can provide valuable resources, including water, oxygen, and metals, for future space missions.

nodes.title: The smallest space miners: principles of space biomining
nodes.summary:
Space biomining is a promising approach for in-situ resource utilization in space exploration.
It involves using microorganisms to extract valuable resources from extraterrestrial rocks and regolith.

nodes.title: Utilization of single-image normalized difference vegetation index (SI-NDVI) for early plant stress detection
nodes.summary:
The normalized difference vegetation index (NDVI) is a standard for vegetation and crop health assessment.
NDVI has been used for decades to monitor global vegetation health and has been adapted for use in fields and greenhouses.
Indoor farming relies on controlled, artificial lighting, making traditional NDVI technology less ideal.
A modified version of NDVI, single-image NDVI (SI-NDVI), can detect plant stress in controlled conditions using NIR and full-spectrum visible light.
SI-NDVI relies on comparison between spectral reflectance in the blue and NIR bands.
The SI-NDVI imager uses a GoPro Hero4 Black camera with a Back-Bone Ribcage AIR modification kit and an NDVI-7 filter.
