SI-NDVI imaging can detect plant stress before it is apparent to the human eye, with applications in indoor farming and laboratory plant studies.

nodes.title: Comparing RNA-Seq and microarray gene expression data in two zones of the Arabidopsis root apex relevant to spaceflight
nodes.summary:
Transcriptome data were obtained from two root tip zones of Arabidopsis thaliana using microarray and RNA-Seq.
A total of approximately 33,500 and 22,700 genes were detected as expressed in the root zones from RNA-Seq and microarray, respectively.
RNA-Seq detected 6403 genes that were differentially expressed between the two root zones, while microarray detected 6351 genes.
4180 genes were commonly identified by both techniques, and 2223 genes were exclusive to RNA-Seq at a fold change of 2 or greater.
RNA-Seq was more efficient in detecting unique and novel transcripts that were not detected by microarray.
The study compared the two techniques and found that RNA-Seq provided more information on isoforms, coding DNA sequences, and transcription start sites.
The results contribute to the understanding of how the transcriptome guides Arabidopsis root function and differentiation.

nodes.title: Microfluidics-enabled method to identify modes of Caenorhabditis elegans paralysis in four anthelmintics
nodes.summary:
A microfluidic device is used to study the effects of four anthelmintic drugs on Caenorhabditis elegans.
The device allows for real-time imaging and quantification of worm behavior over an extended time period.
Multiple parameters are extracted, including curls per second, types of paralyzation, and mode frequency.
The results show differences in the manner of paralysis among the four drugs at equipotent concentrations.
Pyrantel is found to be more effective than levamisole in immobilizing worms, while tribendimidine causes shorter active periods.
Methyridine exhibits a distinct swimming-like movement, suggesting it may act on a different subtype of nAChR receptors.
The multi-parameter extraction method provides a more comprehensive understanding of drug effects on C. elegans.

nodes.title: The interaction of vortical flows with red cells in venous valve mimics
nodes.summary:
Vortical flows in venous valve mimics alter local red blood cell distribution.
The local hematocrit in valve pockets is spatially heterogeneous and differs from feed hematocrit.
Above a threshold shear rate, inertial separation and lift forces contribute to uneven RBC distribution.
RBCs become entrapped in vortices, leading to non-monotonic wall shear stresses.
The study provides insights into complex interactions between fluid flow, RBC distribution, and wall shear rates.
These findings have implications for understanding venous thrombosis and improving cell separation efficiency.
The results highlight the importance of considering local hematocrit rather than bulk hematocrit in evaluating RBC effects on thrombosis.

nodes.title: A Tissue Retrieval and Postharvest Processing Regimen for Rodent Reproductive Tissues Compatible with Long-Term Storage on the International Space Station and Postflight Biospecimen Sharing Program
nodes.summary:
Researchers developed a strategy for determining optimal tissue harvest times after euthanasia for rodent reproductive tissues. 
The time window for tissue collection varied between 1 and 3 hours, depending on the tissue and species. 
RNA quality was preserved in key reproductive tissues fixed in RNAlater up to 40 minutes after euthanasia. 
A long-term tissue storage method was established, yielding high-quality mRNA and protein after 10 months at -80Â°C. 
The method involves storing tissues in RNAlater, which inactivates cellular enzymes and preserves RNA expression profiles. 
This approach is compatible with the International Space Station's (ISS) storage conditions and enables the recovery of high-quality RNA and protein. 
The developed protocols facilitate the integration of tissue harvest logistics in multi-investigator Biospecimen Sharing Programs.

nodes.title: Genes Required for Survival in Microgravity Revealed by Genome-Wide Yeast Deletion Collections Cultured during Spaceflight
nodes.summary:
Yeast deletion collections were used to study the effects of microgravity on cells and organisms.
The collections were grown in spaceflight and ground control conditions with and without hyperosmolar sodium chloride.
The results showed that spaceflight affects core cellular processes including growth control and RNA biogenesis.
DNA repair and replication, response to pH signaling, and mitochondrial function were also significantly affected.
The study found high concordance between the effects of spaceflight and DNA-damaging agents, suggesting a mechanism for spaceflight's negative effects on cell fitness.
The findings can guide future experiments to identify environmental modifications that can bolster cellular integrity and control pathological cell growth.

nodes.title: Thermoneutral housing attenuates premature cancellous bone loss in male C57BL/6J mice
nodes.summary:
Mice housed at standard room temperature exhibit premature cancellous bone loss prior to skeletal maturity.
Housing male C57BL/6J mice at thermoneutral temperature prevents cancellous bone loss from 5 to 16 weeks of age.
Thermoneutral housing results in higher bone formation and lower bone resorption compared to room temperature housing.
The bone-protective effects of thermoneutral housing are associated with increased osteoblastogenesis and osteoblast activity.
There are minimal sex differences in the skeletal responses to housing temperature, with both male and female mice exhibiting similar protective effects.
Thermoneutral housing does not alter bone marrow adiposity in male mice, but increases abdominal white adipose tissue and serum leptin levels.
The study highlights the importance of considering housing temperature as a critical experimental variable in bone metabolism studies using mice.

nodes.title: MHC Diversity Across Time and Space
nodes.summary:
MHC diversity is crucial for resisting infectious diseases in natural populations.
The maintenance of MHC diversity is influenced by parasite-mediated balancing selection.
Geographical patterns of MHC diversity vary along latitudinal and altitudinal gradients.
Habitat fragmentation and climate change can lead to reduced MHC diversity and increased disease susceptibility.
Temporal changes in parasite-mediated selection can impact MHC diversity and disease resistance.
Abrupt climatic changes can disrupt host-parasite interactions and lead to increased disease transmission.
Understanding the mechanisms maintaining MHC diversity is essential for conservation efforts and predicting population susceptibility to diseases.

nodes.title: Low-Dose, Ionizing Radiation and Age-Related Changes in Skeletal Microarchitecture
nodes.summary:
Osteoporosis affects the aged due to progressive bone loss, similar to high-dose ionizing radiation effects. 
Low doses of gamma radiation were hypothesized to accelerate structural changes characteristic of skeletal aging. 
Mice were irradiated with 0, 1, 10, or 100 cGy of gamma radiation and tissues harvested at different time points. 
Microcomputed tomography quantified microarchitecture of cancellous bone, showing irradiation at 100 cGy caused transient changes. 
Ex vivo bone cell differentiation from marrow was unaffected by gamma radiation. 
The capability of marrow-derived cell populations to differentiate into osteoblasts or osteoclasts was unchanged. 
Ionizing gamma irradiation at 100 cGy accelerated changes in trabecular microarchitecture, comparable to later skeletal aging in controls.

nodes.title: Treatment With a Soluble Bone Morphogenetic Protein Type 1A Receptor (BMPR1A) Fusion Protein Increases Bone Mass and Bone Formation in Mice Subjected to Hindlimb Unloading
nodes.summary:
Mice subjected to hindlimb unloading experienced significant bone loss, which was prevented by treatment with a soluble bone morphogenetic protein type 1A receptor fusion protein. 
Treatment with the fusion protein increased bone mass and bone formation in both unloaded and normally loaded mice. 
The fusion protein improved bone microarchitecture, including trabecular and cortical bone, in both groups. 
Bone formation rate was increased 3.5-fold and 5-fold in normally loaded and unloaded mice, respectively, with treatment. 
Osteoclast surface was reduced by 60% in both groups with treatment, indicating decreased bone resorption. 
The results suggest that the soluble bone morphogenetic protein type 1A receptor fusion protein may be useful for maintaining skeletal integrity in disuse-induced bone loss. 
Overall, the study demonstrates the potential of the fusion protein as a therapeutic agent for preventing and treating disuse osteoporosis.

nodes.title: Bisphosphonates attenuate age-related muscle decline in Caenorhabditis elegans
nodes.summary:
Bisphosphonates, specifically zoledronic acid (ZA), have been found to attenuate age-related muscle decline in Caenorhabditis elegans.
ZA treatment increased lifespan and healthspan in a dose-dependent manner, with 100 nM and 1 Î¼M concentrations showing significant benefits.
The anti-sarcopenic effects of ZA were visualized and quantified using transgenic strains expressing GFP-tagged sarcomeres or mitochondria.
ZA delayed the loss of organized sarcomeres and mitochondrial integrity, leading to improved muscle function and overall health.
The mechanisms of ZA-mediated healthspan extension involve the mevalonate-FOXO pathway, muscle-centric myokines, and mitochondrial sirtuins.
ZA's effects on muscle health are conserved across species and may be muscle-intrinsic, given the lack of an endoskeleton in C. elegans.
Overall, bisphosphonates may be a promising therapeutic strategy for maintaining muscle health and preventing sarcopenia in older adults.

nodes.title: The ongoing search for the molecular basis of plant osmosensing
nodes.summary:
Plants have evolved mechanisms to sense changes in cell water content and solute concentrations. 
Understanding how plants cope with water limitation is crucial to mitigate the effects of drought on crop productivity. 
The signaling pathways by which plants respond to osmotic challenge are complex and involve multiple mechanisms. 
Three general models for osmosensing in plant cells have been proposed, including osmotic imbalance across the plasma membrane and increased plasma membrane tension. 
Mechanosensitive channels are capable of sensing membrane tension and responding to it by facilitating the flux of osmolytes across the membrane. 
The molecular mechanisms of osmosensing in plants are not yet fully understood, but research has identified several key players, including the hormone abscisic acid and various ion channels. 
Further research is needed to determine the molecular identity of the osmosensing apparatus and to characterize the nature of the osmotic stress response signaling pathways.

nodes.title: Genetic and tissue level muscle-bone interactions during unloading and reambulation
nodes.summary:
Muscle and bone interactions were studied in a genetically heterogeneous population of 352 adult mice.
The mice underwent 3 weeks of hindlimb unloading followed by 3 weeks of reambulation.
Changes in muscle and cortical bone morphology were quantified and associated with each other.
The results showed that changes in muscle and bone were not correlated during unloading or reambulation.
One significant quantitative trait locus (QTL) was found for muscle area and five QTLs for cortical bone.
The QTLs for muscle and bone did not overlap, indicating distinct genetic regulation of the response.
The study suggests that the premise of a muscle-bone unit that co-adjusts its size during loading and unloading may need to be reassessed.

nodes.title: LC-025-D4LC01090F-s001
nodes.summary:
The photometry platform assembly requires materials listed in Table 1 and can be guided by Figure 1.
The system utilizes Thorlabs' 30 mm cage system for optical component alignment, which is optional.
The platform is mounted to an aluminum optical breadboard using optical posts.
Components are assembled in the direction of the beam path, starting with the fiber optic patch cable and 430 nm LED.
The dichroic mirror's orientation in the filter cube dictates the position of other optical components.
The platform is designed to reflect light delivered by the LED and transmit light received from the objective to the CMOS camera.
The assembly process involves connecting various components, including filters, objectives, and cameras, to achieve optimal optical alignment.

nodes.title: Recent advances in the genome mining of Aspergillus secondary metabolites (covering 2012-2018)
nodes.summary:
Aspergillus species produce diverse secondary metabolites with various bioactivities.
Genome mining has revealed many silent biosynthetic gene clusters in Aspergillus species.
Activation of these clusters has led to the discovery of new secondary metabolites.
The biosynthetic pathways of several secondary metabolites have been elucidated.
Genetic characterization of secondary metabolites in Aspergillus nidulans, Aspergillus fumigatus, Aspergillus niger, and Aspergillus terreus has been summarized.
The review highlights the importance of genome mining and genetic characterization for understanding secondary metabolite biosynthesis.
Further research is needed to fully characterize the Aspergillus secondary metabolome and explore its applications.

nodes.title: Apyrase inhibitors enhance the ability of diverse fungicides to inhibit the growth of different plant-pathogenic fungi
nodes.summary:
Apyrase inhibitors enhance the ability of fungicides to inhibit fungal growth.
The inhibitors increase the potency of copper octanoate, myclobutanil, and propiconazole.
Sclerotinia sclerotiorum is the most sensitive pathogen to the fungicide-potentiating effects.
Apyrase inhibitors increase the retention of propiconazole in fungal cells.
The inhibitors suppress apyrase activity released by fungi into growth media.
The addition of apyrase inhibitors increases the sensitivity of fungi to fungicides in 53 out of 60 treatment combinations.

nodes.title: Identification of Metagenome-Assembled Genomes Containing Antimicrobial Resistance Genes, Isolated from an Advanced Water Treatment Facility
nodes.summary:
Metagenome-assembled genomes (MAGs) were isolated from an advanced water treatment facility.
95 MAGs were found to harbor antimicrobial resistance genes.
These MAGs were obtained from samples prior to microfiltration at the facility.
The MAGs represent a useful resource for the water treatment community.
The facility's treatment process was found to decrease microbial diversity and load.
The study identified microbial lineages harboring antimicrobial resistance genes.
The findings provide insight into the transmission of antibiotic resistance genes in water treatment facilities.

nodes.title: Draft Genome Sequences of Various Bacterial Phyla Isolated from the International Space Station
nodes.summary:
Whole-genome sequences were generated from 96 bacterial strains of 14 species isolated from the International Space Station.
The International Space Station's microbiome is crucial to track for astronaut health due to microgravity's disruption of human immune function.
Eleven of the 14 species found are common members of the human microbiome and can act as opportunistic human pathogens.
Four species from the phylum Actinobacteria were isolated, including Pseudoclavibacter, Kocuria, and Micrococcus.
Multiple coagulase-negative staphylococci were also isolated, which are normal components of human skin flora and often resistant to antibiotics.
Three species from the phylum Proteobacteria were identified, including Acinetobacter pittii, Pseudomonas fulva, and Pseudomonas granadensis.
The strains were collected aboard the ISS over five flight missions between June 2017 and December 2018 from eight predetermined surfaces.

nodes.title: Draft Genome Sequences of Tremellomycetes Strains Isolated from the International Space Station
nodes.summary:
Draft genome sequences of six eukaryotic microbial strains were assembled. 
These strains belong to the class Tremellomycetes and were isolated from the ISS. 
The sequences will aid in understanding the influence of microgravity conditions. 
Microgravity conditions may affect the potential pathogenicity of these organisms. 
Further characterization of the sequences is necessary for a deeper understanding. 
The isolated strains are eukaryotic microorganisms with unique characteristics. 
Understanding their genome sequences can provide insights into their behavior in space.

nodes.title: Draft Genome Sequences of Rhodotorula mucilaginosa Strains Isolated from the International Space Station
nodes.summary:
The whole-genome sequences of 28 Rhodotorula mucilaginosa isolates from the International Space Station were generated. 
These isolates were identified as an emerging human pathogen with the ability to produce carotenoids. 
Carotenoids have various biological activities, including vitamin A biosynthesis and protection from radiation. 
R. mucilaginosa is the most common species isolated from the environment and the most abundant yeast on the ISS. 
The ability of this yeast to produce biofilms makes it a potential threat to life support systems. 
Samples were collected from ISS surfaces and genomic DNA was extracted using a ZymoBIOMICS DNA MagBead kit. 
The whole-genome sequences of these 28 fungal strains were acquired using the Illumina Nextera Flex protocol and paired-end sequencing on a NovaSeq 6000 platform.

nodes.title: Draft Genome Sequences of Sphingomonas Species Associated with the International Space Station
nodes.summary:
The draft genome sequences of three Sphingomonas strains were assembled. 
These strains were isolated from the International Space Station (ISS). 
The genomic sequences will aid in understanding microgravity's influence. 
Microgravity conditions may affect bioactive compound production. 
Comparison to Earth counterparts will provide valuable insights. 
The sequences will help in identifying unique characteristics. 
Understanding these characteristics is crucial for future space missions.

nodes.title: Draft Genome Sequences of Bacillaceae Strains Isolated from the International Space Station
nodes.summary: The draft genome sequences of 29 bacterial isolates from the family Bacillaceae were collected from the International Space Station. These sequences will help understand their roles in space and biotechnological applications. Bacillaceae members are ubiquitous in nature and can produce valuable extracellular enzymes. They can form endospores, crucial for survival in harsh environments. This property makes them important for NASA planetary protection purposes. The report presents draft genome sequences of three Bacillaceae species isolated from the International Space Station. The sequences were assembled using the Illumina Nextera Flex protocol and SPAdes v3.11.1, with quality control performed using FastQC and fastp.

nodes.title: Draft Genome Sequences of Enterobacteriales Strains Isolated from the International Space Station
nodes.summary:
The whole-genome sequences of 26 Enterobacteriales strains isolated from the International Space Station were generated.
These strains were identified as potential pathogens that pose a health risk to astronauts and people on Earth.
Members of the order Enterobacteriales found on ISS surfaces include Pantoea brenneri, Pantoea agglomerans, Kalamiella piersonii, and Enterobacter bugandensis.
These bacteria can adapt to extreme conditions such as microgravity and radiation, making them a concern for long-duration missions.
The strains were isolated from four different locations in the ISS across three flights and were sequenced using the Illumina Nextera Flex protocol.
The draft genome assemblies may help identify the genetic processes responsible for potential pathogenicity.
The analysis of these genome sequences can inform the development of countermeasures to control these bacteria in space environments.

nodes.title: Draft Genome Sequences of Klebsiella Species Isolated from the International Space Station
nodes.summary:
Klebsiella species were isolated from four locations on the International Space Station.
Ten bacterial strains were compared using whole-genome sequencing analysis.
The strains were phylogenetically identified as Klebsiella through this analysis.
Whole-genome sequencing will facilitate comparative genomic studies.
These studies will compare ISS Klebsiella strains to their Earth counterparts.
The goal is to gain insight into the bacteria's adaptation to space conditions.
The draft genome sequences will aid in understanding the genetic basis of this adaptation.

nodes.title: Draft Genome Sequences of Lactobacillales Isolated from the International Space Station
nodes.summary:
Nineteen strains from the order Lactobacillales were isolated from the International Space Station. 
Whole-genome sequences were generated to characterize these potentially pathogenic bacteria. 
The order Lactobacillales consists of Gram stain-positive, facultative anaerobes with some members possessing human pathogenicity characteristics. 
Members of the genus Enterococcus were found to possess antibiotic resistance, posing health concerns for astronauts. 
Astronauts on long flights are immunocompromised due to microgravity-induced physiological and mental stress. 
The strains used for whole-genome sequencing were collected from three different ISS locations across two flights and seven different surface locations. 
The genomic makeup of these potential pathogens will help develop suitable countermeasure and mitigation strategies.

nodes.title: Draft Genome Sequences of Aspergillus and Penicillium Species Isolated from the International Space Station and Crew Resupply Vehicle Capsule
nodes.summary:
The draft whole-genome sequences of 30 fungal strains were assembled. 
These strains belong to the Penicillium and Aspergillus genera. 
They were isolated from the International Space Station and a crew resupply vehicle capsule. 
The whole-genome sequencing will enable detailed genomic characterization. 
This characterization can determine possible applications in space and biotechnology. 
The study is part of an ongoing microbial tracking effort on the International Space Station. 
The genomic data will help understand the importance of these fungi in space environments.

nodes.title: The rapid diagnosis and effective inhibition of coronavirus using spike antibody attached gold nanoparticles â
nodes.summary:
Researchers developed anti-spike antibody attached gold nanoparticles for rapid COVID-19 diagnosis and inhibition.
The nanoparticles can detect COVID-19 antigen or virus via a colorimetric change within 5 minutes.
The detection limit is 1 ng/mL for COVID-19 antigen and 1000 virus particles/mL for pseudo SARS-CoV-2.
Surface-enhanced Raman spectroscopy (SERS) can detect COVID-19 antigen at 4 pg/mL and virus at 18 particles/mL.
The nanoparticles inhibit viral infection by binding to pseudo SARS-CoV-2 and blocking its entry into cells.
The inhibition efficiency is 100% for anti-spike antibody attached gold nanoparticles.

nodes.title: Transcriptional and Hormonal Regulation of Gravitropism of Woody Stems in Populus OPEN
nodes.summary:
Gravitropism in woody stems of Populus trees involves asymmetric production of tension wood.
Tension wood formation is regulated by auxin transport and gibberellic acid (GA) treatment.
The Class I KNOX homeodomain transcription factor ARBORKNOX2 (ARK2) influences fiber development and gravibending.
Genome-wide transcriptomes reveal transcriptional networks underlying wood formation and gravitropism.
Coexpression modules are associated with wood phenotypes, GA response, and ARK2 binding.
The pink module contains genes relevant to tension wood development, including FLAs and transcription factors.
GA treatment and ARK2 genotype affect FLA expression and fiber maturation, influencing gravibending.

nodes.title: HLB1 Is a Tetratricopeptide Repeat Domain-Containing Protein That Operates at the Intersection of the Exocytic and Endocytic Pathways at the TGN/EE in Arabidopsis OPEN
nodes.summary:
HLB1 is a tetratricopeptide repeat domain-containing protein 
that operates at the intersection of exocytic and endocytic pathways 
at the trans-Golgi network/early endosome in Arabidopsis. 
HLB1 associates with the trans-Golgi network/early endosome 
and tracks along filamentous actin, indicating a link between 
post-Golgi traffic and the actin cytoskeleton in plants. 
The min7/ben1 mutant phenocopies the mild root developmental 
defects and latrunculin B hypersensitivity of hlb1, suggesting 
that hlb1 and min7/ben1 operate in common genetic pathways. 
HLB1 interacts with the ADP-ribosylation-factor guanine 
nucleotide exchange factor MIN7/BEN1, and the two proteins 
may form a complex with actin to modulate trans-Golgi network/ 
early endosome function at the intersection of exocytic and 
endocytic pathways in plants.

nodes.title: Correction to "Adaptation to full weight-bearing following disuse in rats: The impact of biological sex on musculoskeletal recovery"
nodes.summary:
The article requires a correction to the second author's name. 
The correct spelling is Megan E. Rosa-Caldwell. 
The error occurred in the original publication. 
The correction aims to rectify the mistake. 
The article's content remains unchanged. 
Only the author's name needs correction. 
The corrected name ensures proper attribution.

nodes.title: Hindlimb suspension in Wistar rats: Sex-based differences in muscle response
nodes.summary:
Hindlimb suspension in Wistar rats leads to significant muscle loss and reduced functional capability. 
Female rats better maintain muscle function during disuse than males, with a more moderate reduction in grip strength. 
Males exhibit a steady decrease in grip strength over time, while females' grip strength remains stable. 
The study highlights sex-based differences in muscle response to disuse, with females experiencing lesser muscle deconditioning. 
Females also show a greater increase in myonuclear density, which may contribute to their better preservation of muscle function. 
Testosterone levels decrease significantly in males exposed to hindlimb suspension, while estradiol levels remain relatively stable in females. 
The findings emphasize the need for sex-specific countermeasures to mitigate muscle loss in astronauts exposed to microgravity.

nodes.title: ANN1 and ANN2 Function in Post-Phloem Sugar Transport in Root Tips to Affect Primary Root Growth 1[OPEN]
nodes.summary:
Annexins ANN1 and ANN2 play a crucial role in post-phloem sugar transport in root tips, affecting primary root growth.
Sugar transport from leaves to roots is essential for plant growth and development, with sugars serving as metabolic substrates and signals.
ANN1 and ANN2 knockout mutants exhibit impaired primary root growth, which can be rescued by exogenous sucrose.
The mutants also display defects in root cap development, which are rescued by sucrose.
Knocking out ANN1 and ANN2 leads to increased reactive oxygen species levels and callose accumulation in root tips.
The study suggests that ANN1 and ANN2 regulate post-phloem sugar transport, impacting primary root growth and development.

nodes.title: Galactose-Depleted Xyloglucan Is Dysfunctional and Leads to Dwarfism in Arabidopsis 1
nodes.summary:
Arabidopsis mutants lacking the F side chain galactosyltransferase MURUS3 form dysfunctional xyloglucan.
This dysfunctional xyloglucan leads to mutants with growth defects, including dwarfism and curled leaves.
Near-normal growth is restored by eliminating xyloglucan or increasing its galactosylation.
The presence of dysfunctional xyloglucan affects cellular processes more than eliminating xyloglucan altogether.
Modifying xyloglucan side chain structure disturbs diverse cellular and physiological processes.
The extent of side chain galactosylation in xyloglucan determines the growth defects of the mur3 mutants.
Dysfunctional xyloglucan disrupts cell wall remodeling, leading to abnormal growth and development.

nodes.title: Topical Review on ER-Golgi Transport Mechanisms in Higher Plants Vesicles versus Tubes: Is Endoplasmic Reticulum-Golgi Transport in Plants Fundamentally Different from Other Eukaryotes? 1
nodes.summary:
The endoplasmic reticulum (ER) and Golgi apparatus are key organelles in eukaryotic cells, involved in protein secretion and transport. 
In higher plant cells, the ER and Golgi apparatus have a unique organization, with mobile Golgi stacks moving along the cortical ER. 
The mechanism of ER-Golgi transport in plants is still debated, with two main models proposed: vesicle-mediated transport and direct tubular connections. 
The vesicle-mediated transport model involves COPII-coated vesicles budding from the ER and fusing with the Golgi apparatus. 
In contrast, the direct tubular connections model proposes that the ER and Golgi apparatus are connected by tubules, allowing for direct transport of proteins and membranes. 
Recent studies using live-cell imaging and electron microscopy have provided new insights into the ER-Golgi interface in plants, but a consensus on the transport mechanism has not been reached.

nodes.title: Pectin Methylesterification Impacts the Relationship between Photosynthesis and Plant Growth 1[OPEN]
nodes.summary:
Pectin methylesterification affects the relationship between photosynthesis and plant growth.
It modulates cell wall plasticity and plant growth by altering leaf area and mesophyll architecture.
CGR2 and CGR3 genes encode pectin methyltransferases that influence cell wall composition.
Altered expression of CGR2 and CGR3 impacts leaf growth, photosynthesis, and respiration.
Pectin methylesterification regulates carbon partitioning to leaf area growth and thickening.

nodes.title: A ROS-Assisted Calcium Wave Dependent on the AtRBOHD NADPH Oxidase and TPC1 Cation Channel Propagates the Systemic Response to Salt Stress 1[OPEN]
nodes.summary:
A ROS-assisted calcium wave dependent on the AtRBOHD NADPH oxidase and TPC1 cation channel propagates the systemic response to salt stress.
The fire-diffuse-fire model describes the process of calcium release and diffusion through the cytosol.
Calcium wave velocities were measured in various lines of Arabidopsis, with results showing a significant difference between the wild type and TPC1 overexpressor.
The ROS-assisted CICR model suggests that ROS production by RBOHD activates plasma membrane calcium channels, leading to calcium release and wave propagation.
Blocking ROS production with DPI, ascorbate, and in the AtRBOHD knockout validates the predictions of the ROS-assisted CICR model.
Imaging of the extracellular ROS wave using OxyBurst Green-BSA shows a propagating ROS wave accompanying the calcium wave.

nodes.title: Reduced Arogenate Dehydratase Expression: Ramifications for Photosynthesis and Metabolism 1[OPEN]
nodes.summary:
Reduced expression of Arogenate Dehydratase (ADT) affects photosynthesis and metabolism in Arabidopsis.
ADT-deficient mutants have impaired carbon flux into phenylalanine biosynthesis, leading to increased ATP/ADP ratios.
This results in overaccumulation of transitory starch and lower electron transport rates due to high-energy quenching.
Metabolomics analysis reveals reduced levels of flavonoids, phenylpropanoids, lignans, and glucosinolates in ADT mutants.
Increased levels of putative galactolipids and apocarotenoids are also observed, potentially related to altered photosynthetic parameters.

nodes.title: Spatial regulation of a common precursor from two distinct genes generates metabolite diversity â
nodes.summary:
Two NRPS-like genes, apvA and atmelA, produce the same intermediate, aspulvinone E, in A. terreus.
The genes are expressed in different tissues, with apvA expressed in hyphae and atmelA in conidia.
The aspulvinone E produced by ApvA is modified to produce aspulvinones, while the aspulvinone E from AtmelA is incorporated into the melanin pathway.
A single trans-prenyltransferase, AbpB, prenylates two substrates, aspulvinones and butyrolactones, expanding metabolite diversity.
The tissue-specific expression of apvA and atmelA is regulated by their specific promoters.
The study reveals a new strategy for expanding chemical diversity in secondary metabolite biosynthesis.
The findings provide new insights into designing and reconstituting biosynthetic pathways for secondary metabolites of biological interest.

nodes.title: Conservation of the Low-shear Modeled Microgravity Response in Enterobacteriaceae and Analysis of the trp Genes in this Response
nodes.summary:
The low-shear modeled microgravity (LSMMG) response is conserved across Enterobacteriaceae.
The direction of LSMMG-induced regulation of phenotypes and gene expression can vary depending on genus.
LSMMG alters acid and oxidative stress resistance in different Enterobacteriaceae genera.
The trp operon genes are not involved in the LSMMG response under the conditions tested.
The TrpR regulator is not required for the LSMMG response in S. Typhimurium and E. coli.
The LSMMG response is a potential tool for bacterial engineering and modification.
The study provides evidence for the conservation of the LSMMG response across Enterobacteriaceae, with potential applications in bacterial engineering.

nodes.title: TPC 201800316D
nodes.summary:
ERU is a plasma membrane-localized protein, not tonoplast-localized as previously thought.
The ERU-GFP fusion protein localizes to the plasma membrane at the site of root hair bulges.
As root hairs transition to rapid tip growth, the ERU-GFP signal intensifies and forms a diffuse fluorescent cap at the root hair apex.
ERU-GFP decorated distinct and dynamic puncta that were reminiscent of post-Golgi and endocytic vesicles.
The tip-directed accumulation of ERU-GFP was most intense in root hairs that grew rapidly.
ERU is important for normal tip-focused cytoplasmic calcium oscillations, a process crucial for sustained root hair growth.
The model proposing tonoplast-based NH4+ signaling as the major driver for ERU-mediated tip-focused calcium oscillations and root hair growth needs reexamination.

nodes.title: Vascular Bundles Mediate Systemic Reactive Oxygen Signaling during Light Stress [OPEN]
nodes.summary:
Systemic signaling and systemic acquired acclimation are essential for plant survival during environmental stress.
Reactive oxygen species (ROS) signaling mediates systemic responses and acclimation during light stress in Arabidopsis.
RBOHD protein is a key player in mediating rapid systemic ROS responses and is expressed in almost all tissues of Arabidopsis.
Complementation of RBOHD expression in the rbohD mutant using xylem parenchyma or phloem-specific promoters restores systemic ROS signaling and systemic stress-response transcript expression.
RBOHD and RBOHF are both required for mediating systemic ROS signaling in response to a local high-light stress treatment.
The integration of ROS, calcium, electric, and hydraulic signals during systemic signaling occurs at the vascular bundles of plants.
Vascular bundles serve as the central rapid systemic signaling superhighway of plants, mediating plant acclimation to abiotic stresses.

nodes.title: Cadaverine regulates biotin synthesis to modulate primary root growth in Arabidopsis
nodes.summary:
Cadaverine inhibits primary root growth in Arabidopsis by modulating biotin synthesis.
The cdh3 mutation enhances primary root growth sensitivity to cadaverine.
Biotin and DAPA supplementation rescues the cadaverine-hypersensitive phenotype.
Cadaverine directly inhibits BIO3-BIO1 enzymatic activity, reducing biotin synthesis.
Decreased biotin synthesis leads to reduced biotinylation of BCCP1 and altered lipid composition.

nodes.title: Human Research Program Human Health Countermeasures Element
nodes.summary:
Astronauts on long-duration space missions have experienced visual and anatomical changes, including optic-disc edema and choroidal folds.
The underlying etiology of these changes is unknown, but microgravity-induced cephalad-fluid shift is suspected to play a significant role.
Fifteen male astronauts have experienced confirmed in-flight and postflight visual and anatomical changes, with four having above-normal CSF pressure postflight.
The spaceflight community suspects that microgravity-induced changes in physiology contribute to these changes.
Astronauts exposed to microgravity experience a cephalad-fluid shift, which may lead to increases in stroke volume, cardiac output, ICP, and IOP.
Contributing factors may include pockets of increased CO2 and high sodium diet, but exercise may be a potential countermeasure to reduce IOP and ICP in-flight.
Further research is needed to address the current knowledge gaps and develop a comprehensive understanding of the Visual Impairment Intracranial Pressure (VIIP) syndrome.

nodes.title: Human Research Program Human Health Countermeasures Element
nodes.summary:
Astronauts on long-duration space missions have experienced visual and anatomical changes, including optic-disc edema and choroidal folds.
The underlying etiology of these changes is unknown, but microgravity-induced cephalad-fluid shift is suspected to play a significant role.
Fifteen male astronauts have experienced confirmed in-flight and postflight visual and anatomical changes, with four having above-normal CSF pressure postflight.
The spaceflight community suspects that microgravity-induced changes in physiology contribute to these changes.
Astronauts exposed to microgravity experience a cephalad-fluid shift, which may lead to increases in stroke volume, cardiac output, ICP, and IOP.
Contributing factors may include pockets of increased CO2 and high sodium diet, but exercise may be a potential countermeasure to reduce IOP and ICP in-flight.
Further research is needed to address the current knowledge gaps and develop a comprehensive understanding of the Visual Impairment Intracranial Pressure (VIIP) syndrome.

nodes.title: Human Research Program Human Health Countermeasures Element
nodes.summary:
Astronauts on long-duration space missions have experienced visual and anatomical changes, including optic-disc edema and choroidal folds.
The underlying etiology of these changes is unknown, but microgravity-induced cephalad-fluid shift is suspected to play a significant role.
Fifteen male astronauts have experienced confirmed in-flight and postflight visual and anatomical changes, with four having above-normal CSF pressure postflight.
The spaceflight community suspects that microgravity-induced changes in physiology contribute to these changes.
Astronauts exposed to microgravity experience a cephalad-fluid shift, which may lead to increases in stroke volume, cardiac output, ICP, and IOP.
Contributing factors may include pockets of increased CO2 and high sodium diet, but exercise may be a potential countermeasure to reduce IOP and ICP in-flight.
Further research is needed to address the current knowledge gaps and develop a comprehensive understanding of the Visual Impairment Intracranial Pressure (VIIP) syndrome.

nodes.title: Environmental Dependence of Competitive Fitness in Rifampin-Resistant rpoB Mutants of Bacillus subtilis
nodes.summary:
Rifampin-resistant rpoB mutants of Bacillus subtilis exhibit varying levels of fitness.
The fitness of these mutants depends on the environment in which they are grown.
In rich laboratory media, the wild-type strain is more fit than most mutants.
However, in a minimal medium with L-asparagine as the sole carbon source, some mutants are more fit.
The H482N mutant is particularly successful in this environment, rising to dominate the population.
Growth rate and lag time are not reliable predictors of fitness in these experiments.
The results highlight the importance of considering environmental factors when assessing fitness.

nodes.title: Nature of Pre-Earthquake Phenomena and their Effects on Living Organisms
nodes.summary:
Earthquakes are preceded by a period of increasing stress in the Earth's crust, 
which can be detected by animals through various physical and chemical signals. 
Positive holes, or electronic charge carriers, are activated in rocks under stress, 
traveling fast and far, and generating ultralow frequency electromagnetic waves. 
These waves can interact with living organisms, causing physiological effects. 
When positive holes reach the Earth's surface, they can ionize the air, producing positive airborne ions, 
and oxidize water, forming hydrogen peroxide and other potentially hazardous compounds. 
Understanding these processes can provide insight into the causes of unusual pre-earthquake animal behavior. 
The activation of positive holes is a non-seismic process that occurs before catastrophic rupture.

nodes.title: Blocking SARS-CoV-2 Delta Variant (B.1.617.2) Spike Protein Receptor-Binding Domain Binding with the ACE2 Receptor of the Host Cell and Inhibiting Virus Infections Using Human Host Defense Peptide-Conjugated Graphene Quantum Dots
nodes.summary:
Researchers designed HNP1 and LL-37 peptide-conjugated graphene quantum dots (GQDs) to block SARS-CoV-2 delta variant spike protein binding with ACE2 receptors. 
The GQDs exhibited high binding affinity with the delta variant spike protein, comparable to ACE2-spike protein binding affinity. 
The binding affinity for the delta B.1.617.2 variant was higher than other variants. 
LL-37 and HNP1 peptide-conjugated GQDs completely inhibited delta variant SARS-CoV-2 pseudovirions entry into host cells. 
The inhibition efficiency of two peptide-attached GQDs was higher than one type of peptide-attached GQDs or only peptides or GQDs. 
The peptide-attached GQDs destroyed the lipid membrane of the virus and removed spike proteins, stopping virus spread. 
The study demonstrates the potential of peptide-conjugated GQDs as a therapeutic strategy against SARS-CoV-2 infection.

nodes.title: A METHOD FOR PREPARING SPACEFLIGHT RNA LATER -FIXED ARABIDOPSIS THALIANA (BRASSICACEAE) TISSUE FOR SCANNING ELECTRON MICROSCOPY 1
nodes.summary:
Spaceflight experiments have limited flexibility due to regulated crew time and limited resources. 
A protocol for preparing Arabidopsis thaliana tissue for scanning electron microscopy (SEM) using RNA later fixation is presented. 
This method allows for the preservation of tissue morphology without the need for dedicated morphologic fixatives. 
The protocol involves desalination, flash-freezing, and critical point drying to produce high-quality images. 
The use of RNA later as a fixative provides distinct advantages for both spaceflight and ground-based experimental applications. 
Field studies may also benefit from this protocol, as it allows for the collection of more data with fewer trips. 
The protocol may assist laboratories with libraries of samples in RNA later by expanding the available techniques for study.

nodes.title: Functional Consequences of Radiation-Induced Oxidative Stress in Cultured Neural Stem Cells and the Brain Exposed to Charged Particle Irradiation
nodes.summary:
Low doses of charged particles cause acute and persistent oxidative stress in neural stem and precursor cells.
Exposure to ion fluences resulting in less than one ion traversal per cell is sufficient to elicit radiation-induced oxidative stress.
Whole body irradiation triggers a compensatory response in the rodent brain, leading to increased antioxidant capacity.
Low dose irradiation impairs novel object recognition in mice 2 and 12 weeks after exposure.
Data suggest that astronauts may develop a heightened risk for mission-critical performance decrements and long-term neurocognitive sequelae.
Radiation-induced oxidative stress is associated with impaired cognition and may be a key factor in the development of neurocognitive deficits.
Exposure to low doses of charged particles causes persistent oxidative stress and cognitive impairment over protracted times.

nodes.title: Spaceflight Induces Specific Alterations in the Proteomes of Arabidopsis
nodes.summary:
Arabidopsis seedlings were grown on the International Space Station for 12 days and then preserved in RNAlater.
The preserved samples were returned to Earth and analyzed using iTRAQ proteomics procedures.
Over 1500 proteins were identified, including 1167 leaf proteins and 1150 root proteins.
256 leaf proteins and 358 root proteins showed statistically significant differential abundance in spaceflight samples compared to ground controls.
The proteomics data were compared with transcriptome data from similar spaceflight samples, showing a positive but limited relationship between transcriptome and proteome regulation.
The differentially abundant proteins were associated with various biological processes, including cell wall metabolism and auxin signaling.
The study demonstrated the feasibility of using RNAlater-preserved plant tissue for broad-scale proteomics analysis of Arabidopsis spaceflight responses.

nodes.title: ARG1 Functions in the Physiological Adaptation of Undifferentiated Plant Cells to Spaceflight
nodes.summary:
investigates the role of the Altered Response to Gravity 1 (ARG1) gene in the physiological adaptation of undifferentiated plant cells to spaceflight.
The study used Arabidopsis thaliana cell cultures, including wild-type and ARG1 knockout lines, to analyze gene expression changes in response to spaceflight.
The results showed that ARG1 plays a significant role in the adaptation of plant cells to spaceflight, with most genes altered in expression being ARG1-dependent.
The study identified 78 genes differentially expressed in wild-type cells and 130 genes in ARG1 knockout cells, with only three genes overlapping between the two genotypes.
The findings suggest that ARG1 is involved in gravity sensing and signal transduction, and its absence leads to the engagement of alternative pathways for physiological adaptation to spaceflight.

nodes.title: Molecular Muscle Experiment: Hardware and Operational Lessons for Future Astrobiology Space Experiments
nodes.summary:
The Molecular Muscle Experiment aims to study spaceflight-induced muscle decline in Caenorhabditis elegans.
The experiment requires specialized hardware and validation of experimental conditions to ensure high-quality data collection.
The researchers designed and validated new experiment cassettes and tested different culture bags for worm growth.
They found that polyethylene bags performed well, while fluorinated ethylene propylene bags did not support worm growth.
The team also optimized culture volume and validated experimental timings for upload to the International Space Station.
They tested various upload scenarios, including passive cold stowage using NASA's phase change materials.
The results provide a platform for future investigators to conduct experiments onboard the ISS.

nodes.title: Relevance of the Unfolded Protein Response to Spaceflight-Induced Transcriptional Reprogramming in Arabidopsis
nodes.summary:
Spaceflight alters the growth of Arabidopsis seedlings, with elongated hypocotyls and petioles.
The unfolded protein response (UPR) plays a minor but significant role in gene expression in spaceflight.
Global transcriptomic analyses reveal that gene expression reprogramming in response to spaceflight depends partially on intact UPR signaling.
Biological pathways connected to differentially expressed genes (DEGs) between flight and ground include stress responses and metabolic processes.
The UPR regulators bZIP60 and bZIP28 have a complex, antagonistic relationship in controlling genes related to abiotic stress responses.
Spaceflight induces the activation of signaling pathways that compensate for the loss of UPR regulators in the control of downstream transcriptional regulatory networks.
The study provides new insights into how plants respond to spaceflight and has implications for improving plant growth and stress responses in space and on Earth.

nodes.title: Hypergravity disruption of homeorhetic adaptations to lactation in rat dams include changes in circadian clocks
nodes.summary:
Hypergravity exposure disrupts homeorhetic adaptations to lactation in rat dams.
Changes in circadian clocks and maternal behavior contribute to reduced pup survival.
Hypergravity alters metabolic activity in mammary, liver, and adipose tissue.
Glucose oxidation and lipid synthesis are decreased in hypergravity-exposed dams.
Hormonal changes, including decreased corticosterone and insulin, occur in hypergravity-exposed dams.
Gene expression of lipid metabolic enzymes and hormone receptors is altered in hypergravity-exposed dams.
Hypergravity exposure affects the circadian system, leading to changes in molecular clock gene expression.

nodes.title: Metabolomic Profiling of the Secretome from Human Neural Stem Cells Flown into Space
nodes.summary:
Human neural stem cells flown into space exhibit increased energy demands in response to microgravity.
The cells show increased glycolysis, with higher levels of pyruvate and glycerate, and activated catabolism of branched-chain amino acids.
The space environment triggers stress response mechanisms, including increased synthesis of NAD+ and formation of polyamine spermidine.
Microgravity induces adaptive responses in living organisms, with changes in gravitational forces affecting biological tissues and entire organisms.
The study analyzed the metabolome of culture medium from neural stem cells flown into space and found significant differences in metabolic pathways.
The results have implications for future space travel, particularly for extended-duration trips, to ensure sufficient energy for CNS homeostasis and optimal cognitive function.

nodes.title: Thermal Plasticity and Evolutionary Constraints in Bacillus: Implications for Climate Change Adaptation
nodes.summary:
Bacillus bacteria were tested for thermal adaptation through experimental evolution under increasing warming conditions.
The bacteria showed limited thermal adaptation, with most strains unable to evolve significant heat tolerance.
Only one B. subtilis strain successfully extended its thermal niche, while B. cereus strains showed reduced growth capacity.
Mutations in genes regulating c-di-AMP synthesis were found to play a critical role in thermal tolerance.
The study highlights the vulnerability of essential bacteria to climate change and the need for further research.
The findings have significant implications for understanding microbial responses to global warming and its potential impacts on ecosystems.

nodes.title: Oligodendrocyte Progenitors Display Enhanced Proliferation and Autophagy after Space Flight
nodes.summary:
Oligodendrocyte progenitors (OLPs) were flown to space and their behavior was studied after return to Earth.
OLPs displayed enhanced proliferation and autophagy after space flight, with some cells dividing faster than ground control cells.
The secretome of space-flown OLPs revealed upregulation of heat shock protein 90 beta (HSP-90Î²) and secreted protein acidic and rich in cysteine (SPARC).
SPARC induces endoplasmic reticulum stress, leading to autophagy, and its upregulation may contribute to the increased autophagy in space-flown OLPs.
The study suggests that microgravity affects OLPs' behavior, leading to increased proliferation and autophagy, which may have implications for astronauts' brain health.
Understanding the effects of microgravity on OLPs can provide insights into the development of countermeasures for intracranial hypertension and visual impairment in astronauts.
Further research is needed to elucidate the mechanisms underlying the changes in OLPs' behavior and to explore the potential benefits of microgravity for cell replacement therapies on Earth.

nodes.title: Transcriptomic Effects on the Mouse Heart Following 30 Days on the International Space Station
nodes.summary:
Transcriptomic analysis of mouse hearts after 30 days on the International Space Station revealed 1147 significantly regulated transcripts. 
The MAPK, PI3K-Akt, and GPCR signaling pathways were predicted to be activated. 
Transcripts related to cytoskeleton breakdown and organization were upregulated. 
No significant change in the expression of extracellular matrix components or oxidative stress pathway-associated transcripts occurred. 
The results indicate an absence of cellular senescence and a significant upregulation of transcripts associated with the cell cycle. 
Transcripts related to cellular maintenance and survival were most affected by spaceflight, suggesting an adaptive response to long-term spaceflight. 
The study provides insight into the molecular changes that occur in the heart during long-term spaceflight, which is essential for future space missions.

nodes.title: NASA GeneLab Platform Utilized for Biological Response to Space Radiation in Animal Models
nodes.summary:
Ionizing radiation from galactic cosmic rays is a major risk factor for astronauts on extended missions.
The NASA GeneLab project provides detailed information on radiation exposure using animal models.
A meta-analysis of transcriptomic datasets in GeneLab identified potential dose-dependent biological responses.
The analysis revealed distinct biological signatures associated with specific ions and biological responses.
Changes in mitochondrial function, ribosomal assembly, and immune pathways were observed as a function of dose. 
The study highlights the importance of understanding the effects of space radiation on human health.
The results can be used to generate novel hypotheses and identify potential targets for mitigation of space radiation effects.
The analysis demonstrates the value of using omics data to understand the effects of space radiation on biological systems.
The study provides a comprehensive analysis of the effects of space radiation on animal models and has implications for human spaceflight.

nodes.title: Selective Proliferation of Highly Functional Adipose-Derived Stem Cells in Microgravity Culture with Stirred Microspheres
nodes.summary:
Human adipose-derived stem cells (hASCs) have limited therapeutic effects due to poor cell retention and reduced differentiation potential. 
A novel culturing technique using microgravity conditions with stirred microspheres was developed to selectively expand highly functional hASCs. 
The technique increased the proportion of SSEA-3(+) hASCs 4.4- and 4.3-fold using polystyrene and collagen microspheres, respectively. 
hASCs cultured in microgravity/microsphere cultures expressed higher levels of pluripotent markers, including OCT4, SOX2, NANOG, MYC, KLF, and CD34. 
These cells also showed improved proliferation, colony formation, network formation, and multiple-mesenchymal differentiation abilities. 
The microgravity culture conditions increased not only the proportion but also the number of SSEA-3(+) cells, making it a promising method for regenerative therapies. 
Further studies are required to optimize the culture protocol and investigate the therapeutic value of these cells using in vivo experiments before clinical trials can proceed.

nodes.title: Transcriptomic Signature of the Simulated Microgravity Response in Caenorhabditis elegans and Comparison to Spaceflight Experiments
nodes.summary:
Caenorhabditis elegans was exposed to simulated microgravity for four days and its transcriptomic response was analyzed.
The results showed that 75% of the simulated microgravity-induced changes in gene expression persisted after returning to ground conditions for four days.
The insulin/IGF-1 and sphingolipid signaling pathways were affected under simulated microgravity, which could impact longevity regulation.
A total of 118 genes were identified as commonly differentially expressed in both simulated microgravity and spaceflight experiments.
These genes were enriched for protein-protein interactions and played a functional role in locomotion, body morphogenesis, and collagen development.
The human orthologs of these genes exhibited overrepresentation for protein domains related to calpain and muscle atrophy.
The study provides insight into the effects of microgravity on biological systems and identifies potential transcriptional regulators of microgravity-responsive genes.

nodes.title: Metabolomics Profile of the Secretome of Space-Flown Oligodendrocytes
nodes.summary:
Oligodendrocyte progenitors (OLPs) were flown to the International Space Station for 26 days to study the effects of microgravity on their metabolomics profile.
The secretome of OLPs in space showed increased glutamate and energy metabolism compared to those on Earth.
Mitochondrial respiration and glycolysis were also increased in OLPs after space flight, indicating a higher energy demand.
The study found significant changes in the metabolite levels of OLPs in space, including increased fumarate and decreased pyruvate.
Glutamate metabolism was also affected, with increased glutamate and glutamine secretion in OLPs in space.
The findings have implications for understanding the effects of microgravity on the human body and potential therapeutic targets for myelin-related disorders.

nodes.title: Spaceflight Induces Strength Decline in Caenorhabditis elegans
nodes.summary:
Spaceflight induces a decline in strength in Caenorhabditis elegans, with a 16.6% decline in wild-type worms and 23% decline in dys-1 mutant worms. 
The decline in strength is associated with changes in gene expression, including upregulation of stress response pathways and downregulation of mitochondrial and cytoskeletal processes. 
The transcriptional gene ontology signatures characterizing weaker animals in flight are similar to those observed in previous studies across species. 
Functional gene cluster analysis implicates decreased neuronal function, including abnormal calcium handling and acetylcholine signaling, in space-induced strength declines. 
The use of C. elegans as a model organism allows for the study of spaceflight-induced changes in a controlled and reproducible manner. 
The findings of this study provide a framework for developing targeted therapeutics against spaceflight-related health decline. 
The study's results have implications for understanding the effects of spaceflight on human health and for the development of countermeasures to mitigate these effects.

nodes.title: Effects of Space Flight on Inflammasome Activation in the Brain of Mice
nodes.summary:
Space flight affects the immune response, making astronauts vulnerable to infections and diseases.
Inflammasome activation plays a significant role in regulating the inflammatory response.
This study aimed to determine the levels of inflammasome activation in the brains of mice housed in the ISS for 37 days.
The results showed decreased inflammasome activation in the brains of mice that were housed in the ISS.
No significant changes were detected in the expression levels of pro-inflammatory cytokines between the ground control and flight groups.
The study suggests that spaceflight results in a decrease in innate immune signaling molecules that govern inflammasome signaling in the brain of mice.
The findings have implications for understanding the effects of spaceflight on the immune response and developing countermeasures to protect astronauts' health.

nodes.title: The dynamics of protein-protein interactions between domains of MscL at the cytoplasmic-lipid interface
nodes.summary:
Protein-protein interactions between S1 and TM2 ci domains in E. coli MscL channel were studied using an in vivo disulfide trapping assay.
The assay involved screening 143 double-cysteine mutants to generate a map of interactions between these domains.
Results showed that interactions between S1 and TM2 ci domains are efficient and can be stabilized in a sub-conductive state.
Mutants M12C/N103C and I3C/I96C showed changes in channel activity under different redox conditions.
The study suggests a model consistent with a concerted motion of the S1 domain and TM2 ci during MscL gating.
The S1 domain serves as a stabilizer for the twisting and turning of the pore-forming transmembrane domain.
The findings are consistent with the model of S1 maintaining its association with the cytoplasmic side of the membrane.

nodes.title: Cell Structure and Function Cell Structure and Function
nodes.summary:
Anhydrobiosis is a phenomenon where organisms survive extreme dehydration by entering a reversible ametabolic state. 
Tardigrades utilize protective mechanisms against desiccation, including the expression of cytoplasmic abundant heat soluble (CAHS) proteins. 
CAHS proteins share similarities with late embryogenesis abundant (LEA) proteins but differ in amino acid sequences. 
This study explored the functionality of CAHS proteins in aggregation and tolerance to hyperosmotic stress in mammalian cells. 
The expression of CAHS1, CAHS3, and CAHS8 enhanced resilience to hyperosmotic conditions. 
CAHS proteins demonstrated reversible aggregation upon hyperosmotic stress, exhibiting granular and filamentous structures. 
The findings suggest a potential use of CAHS proteins as cryoprotectants and provide insights into the mechanism of desiccation tolerance in tardigrades.

nodes.title: Inhibition of SARS-CoV-2 wild-type (Wuhan-Hu-1) and Delta (B.1.617.2) strains by marine sulfated glycans
nodes.summary:
Marine sulfated glycans (MSGs) demonstrate inhibitory activity against SARS-CoV-2 via disruption of S-protein RBD-HSPG interactions.
Seven different MSGs were evaluated for their anti-SARS-CoV-2 activity against wild-type and Delta variant strains.
All tested MSGs showed strong inhibitory activity against both strains, with IC50 values ranging from 0.1-5.9 mg/L.
No correlations between MSG structural features and virus inhibition could be drawn.
The study provides evidence for the maintenance of inhibitory activity of MSGs against evolving SARS-CoV-2 strains.
MSGs exhibited no significant cell death even at high concentrations, indicating potential as prophylactic and therapeutic molecules.
The findings suggest that MSGs could be developed into effective anti-SARS-CoV-2 agents.

nodes.title: Ginsenoside Reshapes Intestinal Microecology to Alleviate Microgravity Stress
nodes.summary:
Ginseng total saponins (GTSs) alleviate microgravity stress by reshaping intestinal microecology.
GTSs improve intestinal injury caused by simulated weightlessness, reducing pathological damage and inflammatory factors.
GTSs restore intestinal immunity-related genes and remodel the gut microbiota, increasing beneficial bacteria.
The abundance of short-chain fatty acid metabolism-related bacteria is increased by GTSs, enhancing propionic acid, butyric acid, and isobutyric acid levels.
GTSs have a dual modulatory effect on gut microbial composition and abundance in simulated weightless rats.
The underlying mechanism of GTSs may be related to the "intestinal immune-microbiota-metabolic" pathway.
GTSs have potential therapeutic effects on intestinal microecological disorders and impaired immune function caused by weightlessness.

nodes.title: Modeling Host-Pathogen Interactions in the Context of the Microenvironment: Three-Dimensional Cell Culture Comes of Age
nodes.summary:
Three-dimensional cell culture models are being used to study host-pathogen interactions in the context of the microenvironment.
These models include rotating wall vessel bioreactors, extracellular matrix-embedded organoids, and organ-on-a-chip models.
Each model has its own advantages and limitations, and the choice of model depends on the experimental question being addressed.
Three-dimensional models have been used to study a variety of pathogens, including Salmonella, E. coli, and norovirus.
These models have the potential to revolutionize the field of infectious disease research by providing a more accurate representation of the in vivo environment.
The use of 3D models can help to reduce the reliance on animal models and improve the translation of research findings to humans.
Further development and refinement of 3D models are needed to fully realize their potential in infectious disease research.

nodes.title: Draft Genome Sequences of Two Fusarium oxysporum Isolates Cultured from Infected Zinnia hybrida Plants Grown on the International Space Station
nodes.summary:
Fusarium oxysporum isolates were cultured from infected Zinnia hybrida plants grown on the ISS.
The whole-genome sequences of these isolates were determined to understand their genetic makeup.
The genome sequences provide insights into the genetic adaptations of F. oxysporum in microgravity environments.
The draft genome sequences consist of 52 and 54 million bases for the two isolates.
The genomes contain 17,813 and 18,051 predicted protein-coding genes, respectively.
The sequences reveal genetic variations that may contribute to the isolates' pathogenicity and survival in space.
The genome sequences of these F. oxysporum isolates will facilitate further research on plant-microbe interactions in space.

nodes.title: Draft Genome Sequence of a Clinical Isolate of Fusarium fujikuroi Isolated from a Male Patient with Acute Myeloid Leukemia
nodes.summary:
Fusarium fujikuroi is a fungal pathogen that can infect humans.
A clinical isolate of Fusarium fujikuroi was obtained from a patient with acute myeloid leukemia.
The patient was undergoing chemotherapy for refractory acute myeloid leukemia.
The draft whole-genome sequence of the isolate was generated.
The genome sequence provides insight into the genetic makeup of the fungus.
This information can be used to understand the pathogenesis of Fusarium fujikuroi infections.
The genome sequence may also aid in the development of diagnostic and therapeutic strategies.

nodes.title: Draft Genome Sequences of Two Aspergillus fumigatus Strains, Isolated from the International Space Station
nodes.summary:
Aspergillus fumigatus strains ISSFT-021 and IF1SW-F4 were isolated from the International Space Station. 
These strains are opportunistic pathogens with potential to cause disease in humans. 
The draft genome sequences of these strains were assembled for further study. 
The goal is to investigate the virulence characteristics of the ISS strains. 
Comparison will be made to clinical strains isolated on Earth. 
Understanding the genetic basis of virulence is crucial for developing effective treatments. 
The genome sequences will facilitate investigations into the unique features of ISS-isolated Aspergillus fumigatus strains.

nodes.title: Draft Genome Sequences from a Novel Clade of Bacillus cereus Sensu Lato Strains, Isolated from the International Space Station
nodes.summary:
Draft genome sequences of six Bacillus strains are presented, isolated from the International Space Station. 
These strains belong to the Bacillus anthracis-B. cereus-B. thuringiensis group. 
The strains were isolated from various modules, including the Japanese Experiment Module and Russian Segment Zvezda Module. 
The research was funded by NASA, the Department of Homeland Security, and the European Space Agency. 
The genome sequences provide insight into the genetic makeup of these strains. 
The strains were collected during routine operation and maintenance of the modules. 
The research aims to understand the biology of microorganisms in space environments.

nodes.title: Draft Genome Sequence of Solibacillus kalamii, Isolated from an Air Filter Aboard the International Space Station
nodes.summary:
Solibacillus kalamii is a novel bacterial species isolated from a HEPA filter aboard the International Space Station. 
The draft genome sequence of S. kalamii ISSFR-015 contains 3,809,180 bp with an estimated G+C content of 38.61%. 
The Solibacillus genus was described as comprising Bacillus-like organisms with Gram-positive, rod-shaped cells. 
The genome was sequenced using the Illumina MiSeq platform with a paired-end module, generating 12,244,464 paired-end reads. 
The reads were assembled into 28 contigs with a total size of 3,809,180 bp and an N50 contig length of 199,024 bp. 
The genome contains 3,814 genes, of which 3,662 are protein-coding genes, including putative genes for stress resistance and survival. 
The draft genome provides insight into the bacterium's ability to survive in high-stress environments, such as the ISS.

nodes.title: Complete Genome Sequence of Carnobacterium gilichinskyi Strain WN1359 T (DSM 27470 T )
nodes.summary:
Carnobacterium gilichinskyi strain WN1359 was isolated from Siberian permafrost. 
It can grow in cold, anoxic, and CO2-dominated conditions. 
The strain is also capable of surviving low-pressure conditions. 
A simulation of the Mars atmosphere was used to test its growth. 
The strain WN1359 was found to thrive in 0Â°C temperatures. 
Its ability to grow in extreme conditions makes it of interest. 
The complete genome sequence of Carnobacterium gilichinskyi strain WN1359 has been reported.

nodes.title: Draft Genome Sequences of Biosafety Level 2 Opportunistic Pathogens Isolated from the Environmental Surfaces of the International Space Station
nodes.summary:
Draft genome sequences of 20 biosafety level 2 opportunistic pathogens were isolated. 
These pathogens were found on environmental surfaces of the International Space Station. 
The genomic sequences will aid in understanding microgravity's influence on pathogenicity. 
Comparison with Earth strains will provide insight into virulence factors. 
The International Space Station's unique environment may affect microbial behavior. 
Microgravity could potentially alter the genetic makeup of these pathogens. 
Understanding these changes is crucial for maintaining crew health and safety.

nodes.title: Draft Genome Sequences of Acinetobacter and Bacillus Strains Isolated from Spacecraft-Associated Surfaces
nodes.summary:
Draft genome sequences of four strains are reported, isolated from spacecraft-associated surfaces.
These strains exhibit increased resistance to stressors like UV radiation and H2O2 exposure.
The strains include 1P01SC T, FO-92 T, 50v1, and one other unnamed strain.
The research focused on understanding the genetic basis of their stress resistance.
The draft genomes provide insights into the genetic makeup of these strains.
The strains were isolated from surfaces associated with spacecraft, indicating their potential for survival in extreme environments.
The genome sequences can inform strategies for preventing microbial contamination of spacecraft and associated surfaces.

nodes.title: Cultivation in Space Flight Produces Minimal Alterations in the Susceptibility of Bacillus subtilis Cells to 72 Different Antibiotics and Growth-Inhibiting Compounds
nodes.summary:
Bacillus subtilis cells were cultivated in space flight microgravity and compared to ground control samples.
The susceptibility of these cells to 72 antibiotics and growth-inhibiting compounds was tested using the Omnilog phenotype microarray system.
Only 9 compounds showed significant differences in susceptibility between space flight and ground control samples.
However, when tested using a standard broth dilution assay, no statistically significant differences were found.
The results indicate that space flight does not dramatically alter the susceptibility of B. subtilis cells to antibiotics.
This study addresses concerns about the potential for increased antibiotic resistance in bacteria during long-duration space missions.
The findings suggest that the risk of antibiotic-resistant bacteria emerging during space flight may be lower than previously thought.

nodes.title: Draft Genome Sequences of Several Fungal Strains Selected for Exposure to Microgravity at the International Space Station
nodes.summary:
The whole-genome sequences of eight fungal strains are presented.
These strains were selected for exposure to microgravity at the ISS.
The baseline sequences will aid in understanding novel bioactive compounds.
The production of these compounds was observed in microgravity conditions.
The fungal strains were chosen for their potential to produce bioactive compounds.
The genome sequences will serve as a reference for future studies.
The data will help to elucidate the effects of microgravity on fungal metabolism.

nodes.title: The signaling lipid sphingosine 1phosphate regulates mechanical pain
nodes.summary:
Sphingosine 1-phosphate (S1P) regulates mechanical pain through its receptor S1PR3.
Mice lacking S1PR3 display impaired responses to noxious mechanical stimuli.
S1PR3 is expressed in A mechanonociceptors and thermal nociceptors.
S1P signaling via S1PR3 modulates KCNQ2/3 channels to regulate mechanonociceptor excitability.
Baseline levels of S1P are necessary for normal mechanical pain sensitivity.
Elevated S1P levels promote thermal hypersensitivity but not mechanical hypersensitivity.
S1PR3 is a potential target for treating mechanical pain and inflammatory disorders.

nodes.title: The AUX1-AFB1-CNGC14 module establishes a longitudinal root surface pH profile
nodes.summary:
The Arabidopsis root surface pH profile shows distinct acidic and alkaline domains. 
The alkaline domain in the transition zone is controlled by the AUX1-AFB1-CNGC14 module. 
This module is essential for the rapid auxin response pathway and root navigation. 
The AUX1 auxin influx carrier, AFB1 auxin co-receptor, and CNGC14 calcium channel work together to establish the alkaline domain. 
The alkaline domain is not directly determined by AHA activation or localization, but rather by auxin signaling. 
The AUX1-AFB1-CNGC14 module facilitates root navigation by enabling the root to rapidly respond to changes in auxin fluxes. 
This response is crucial for the root to adjust its growth direction and penetrate the soil efficiently.

nodes.title: The 14-3-3 proteins of Arabidopsis regulate root growth and chloroplast development as components of the photosensory system
nodes.summary:
The 14-3-3 proteins in Arabidopsis regulate root growth and chloroplast development.
These proteins are components of the photosensory system and influence root length.
The 14-3-3l-1 mutant has shorter roots than the wild type, especially under full-light conditions.
The root length of 14-3-3l-1 is influenced by light intensity, with shorter roots in full light.
The 14-3-3 T-DNA insertion mutants exhibit increased chloroplast numbers in the roots.

nodes.title: Natural variation in the expression of ORGANIC CATION TRANSPORTER 1 affects root length responses to cadaverine in Arabidopsis
nodes.summary:
Arabidopsis accessions exhibit varying root length responses to exogenous cadaverine.
The reduction in root length is due to a combination of reduced cell division and expansion.
A major QTL was identified on chromosome 1, which partially explains the root length difference.
OCT1 was identified as a key gene involved in the response to cadaverine.
Restoring OCT1 expression in the mutant background resulted in a positive correlation between OCT1 expression levels and cadaverine resistance.
Other genes are likely to contribute to the variation of this trait between Arabidopsis accessions.

nodes.title: Brassinazole resistant 1 (BZR1)-dependent brassinosteroid signalling pathway leads to ectopic activation of quiescent cell division and suppresses columella stem cell differentiation
nodes.summary:
Brassinosteroid signalling pathways regulate root growth and development.
BZR1-mediated signalling promotes ectopic activation of quiescent centre cell division.
BZR1 suppresses columella stem cell differentiation, opposite to BES1's action.
BRs exert opposite effects on distal CSC differentiation in a concentration-dependent manner.
BZR1-mediated BR signalling alters PIN protein expression and subcellular distribution.

nodes.title: Wortmannin-induced vacuole fusion enhances amyloplast dynamics in Arabidopsis zigzag1 hypocotyls
nodes.summary:
Gravitropism in Arabidopsis shoots depends on amyloplast sedimentation in endodermal cells.
The zig-1 mutant has fragmented vacuoles and impaired amyloplast movement, contributing to its agravitropic phenotype.
Wortmannin treatment induces vacuole fusion, enhances amyloplast sedimentation, and partially restores gravitropism in zig-1 mutants.
Young endodermal cells near the top of the hypocotyl are the graviperceptive cells, as shown by amyloplast sedimentation and response to wortmannin treatment.
The cytoskeleton is not involved in tethering amyloplasts to vacuoles in zig-1 mutants, suggesting a direct or indirect association between the two organelles.
Vacuole morphology plays a crucial role in regulating amyloplast sedimentation and gravitropism, with fragmented vacuoles impeding amyloplast movement.

nodes.title: Correction to: The Evolution of Temperature and Desiccation-Related Protein Families in Tardigrada Reveals a Complex Acquisition of Extremotolerance
nodes.summary:
The correction involves a change in color representation for protein families. 
CAHS is represented in red, not blue. 
MAHS is represented in purple, which remains correct. 
SAHS is represented in green, which also remains correct. 
EtAHS alpha is represented in yellow, not red. 
EtAHS beta is represented in pink, not orange. 
MRE11 is represented in blue, not black.

nodes.title: hypothalamic leptin gene Therapy reduces Bone Marrow adiposity in ob/ob Mice Fed regular and high-Fat Diets
nodes.summary:
Leptin-deficient ob/ob mice have increased bone marrow adiposity and reduced bone formation. 
Hypothalamic leptin gene therapy reduces marrow adiposity in ob/ob mice fed regular and high-fat diets. 
The reduction in marrow adiposity is accompanied by increased osteoblast and osteoclast perimeter. 
However, the increase in bone formation is matched by an increase in bone resorption, resulting in no change in cancellous bone volume fraction. 
Leptin plays a role in regulating the differentiation of mesenchymal stem cells to adipocytes and osteoblasts. 
Reducing marrow adiposity by increasing leptin levels does not necessarily result in increased bone mass. 
The findings suggest that interventions targeted at reducing marrow adiposity may not be an effective strategy for increasing bone mass.

nodes.title: The Role of Estrogen Receptor a in Response to Longitudinal Bone Growth in ob/ob Mice
nodes.summary:
Leptin deficiency in ob/ob mice results in contrasting growth patterns between axial and appendicular bones.
Ob/ob mice have shorter femoral length and longer spinal length compared to wild-type mice.
The growth plate (GP) thickness and expression of proliferative and hypertrophic markers differ between femoral and spinal GP in ob/ob mice.
Estrogen receptor alpha (ERa) expression is lower in femoral GP and higher in spinal GP of ob/ob mice.
ERa expression is positively correlated with axial and appendicular bone length.
Leptin deficiency disturbs the regulatory effects of ER antagonists on longitudinal bone growth.
The region-specific expression of ERa may contribute to the contrasting phenotypes of axial and appendicular bone growth in ob/ob mice.

nodes.title: Leptin and environmental temperature as determinants of bone marrow adiposity in female mice
nodes.summary:
Leptin and environmental temperature affect bone marrow adiposity in female mice.
Housing mice at thermoneutral temperature increases bone marrow adiposity and leptin levels.
Leptin supplementation decreases bone marrow adiposity in both wild-type and leptin-deficient mice.
The effects of leptin and temperature on bone marrow adiposity are independent and opposite.
