Leptin signaling and environmental temperature regulate bone marrow adiposity through different pathways.
The study's findings have implications for understanding the relationship between bone marrow adiposity and bone metabolism.

nodes.title: Effects of Simulated Microgravity on the Proteome and Secretome of the Polyextremotolerant Black Fungus Knufia chersonesos
nodes.summary:
The rock-inhabiting black fungus Knufia chersonesos was exposed to simulated microgravity. 
Proteomic analyses revealed alterations in cell physiology in response to low-shear simulated microgravity. 
Differential expression was observed for proteins involved in carbohydrate and lipid metabolic processes. 
No evidence of significant activation of stress components or starvation response was detected. 
The scytalone dehydratase enzyme was upregulated in the wild type and downregulated in the mutant. 
Differences in protein modulation were observed between the wild type and mutant strains. 
The study suggests that cell wall melanization may influence the metabolic response to microgravity. 
The findings have implications for astrobiological missions and the search for life beyond Earth.

nodes.title: Neutrophil-to-Lymphocyte Ratio: A Biomarker to Monitor the Immune Status of Astronauts
nodes.summary:
Spaceflight causes immune dysfunction, posing health risks for astronauts. 
Elevated neutrophil-to-lymphocyte ratio (NLR) is a potential biomarker for immune status. 
NLR is elevated in both spaceflight-exposed rodents and astronauts. 
Simulated microgravity models, such as HARV-RWV and hindlimb unloading, also show elevated NLR. 
Antioxidants, like N-acetyl cysteine, can mitigate NLR elevation and neutrophil activation. 
Elevated NLR may be a useful prognostic indicator for astronaut immune status and inflammation. 
Monitoring NLR and developing countermeasures to mitigate its elevation are essential for future long-duration space missions.

nodes.title: Cultivation of Staphylococcus epidermidis in the Human Spaceflight Environment Leads to Alterations in the Frequency and Spectrum of Spontaneous Rifampicin-Resistance Mutations in the rpoB Gene
nodes.summary:
Staphylococcus epidermidis was cultivated in the International Space Station for 122 hours.
The bacteria exhibited lower viable counts but higher frequencies of mutation to rifampicin resistance.
The spectrum of mutations in the rpoB gene was altered in space-grown isolates compared to ground controls.
Mutations occurred primarily in Cluster I of the rpoB gene, with changes at amino acids Q469, H482, and S487.
Double mutations were observed in space-grown samples, which may be indicative of ionizing radiation exposure.
The results suggest that the spaceflight environment induces unique physiologic stresses on bacteria, leading to changes in mutagenic potential.
The study has implications for understanding the emergence of antibiotic resistance in confined environments, such as space stations.

nodes.title: Alterations in the Spectrum of Spontaneous Rifampicin-Resistance Mutations in the Bacillus subtilis rpoB Gene after Cultivation in the Human Spaceflight Environment
nodes.summary:
Bacillus subtilis cells were cultivated in spaceflight and ground control environments.
No significant difference in growth or mutation frequency to rifampicin resistance was found.
However, the spectrum of mutations in the rpoB gene differed between spaceflight and ground control samples.
Two new rpoB alleles, Q137R and L489S, were discovered in spaceflight samples.
The results suggest that spaceflight environment causes unique stresses on bacteria, altering their mutagenic potential.
The study has implications for understanding microbial evolution in space and its potential consequences for long-duration missions.
The findings highlight the need for further research on microbial evolution in space to better cope with challenges in space exploration.

nodes.title: Proteomic and Metabolomic Characteristics of Extremophilic Fungi Under Simulated Mars Conditions
nodes.summary:
Fungal conidia from Chernobyl and ISS-isolated strains were exposed to UV-C and simulated Mars conditions (SMC).
Two strains, ISSFT-021 and IMV 00236, survived 30 min of SMC exposure, showing strain-dependent survival.
Proteomic analysis revealed differential expression of proteins involved in translation, ribosome biogenesis, and carbohydrate metabolism.
No significant metabolome alterations were observed in SMC-exposed strains.
SMC-exposed ISSFT-021-30 conidia exhibited increased UV-C resistance compared to unexposed conidia.
The study highlights the adaptability of fungi to extreme environments, including space conditions.
Fungal survival and adaptation to SMC have implications for planetary protection and future space missions.

nodes.title: In situ Linkage of Fungal and Bacterial Proliferation to Microbiologically Influenced Corrosion in B20 Biodiesel Storage Tanks
nodes.summary:
Biodiesel is a renewable fuel that can replace ultra-low sulfur diesel, 
but its use is offset by lower fuel stability and increased risk of biodegradation. 
Microorganisms can metabolize biodiesel, leading to fuel fouling and corrosion of storage tanks. 
A longitudinal study was conducted to link microbial community dynamics to corrosion in B20 biodiesel underground storage tanks. 
The study found that fungal and bacterial taxa, particularly Byssochlamys and acid-producing bacteria, were abundant in tanks with high corrosion rates. 
The presence of these microorganisms was linked to increased acidity and corrosion of steel surfaces. 
The study highlights the importance of monitoring and mitigating microbial contamination in biodiesel storage tanks to prevent corrosion and fuel degradation. 
Regular cleaning, water removal, and biocide treatment can help control fouling and corrosion. 
The use of biodiesel will likely continue to increase, and operator vigilance is required to address storage challenges and prevent contamination.

nodes.title: Metabolomic Analysis of Aspergillus niger Isolated From the International Space Station Reveals Enhanced Production Levels of the Antioxidant Pyranonigrin A
nodes.summary:
Aspergillus niger isolated from the International Space Station (ISS) produces enhanced levels of secondary metabolites.
The ISS isolate produces high levels of the antioxidant pyranonigrin A, as well as other bioactive compounds.
Genetic analysis revealed variants that may be responsible for the observed increase in secondary metabolite production levels.
The pyranonigrin A biosynthetic gene cluster was identified in A. niger, including a previously undescribed gene, pyrE.
Pyranonigrin A was found to confer UV resistance to A. niger, suggesting its importance in protecting the fungus from radiation.
The study highlights the potential of investigating metabolite production in microbes isolated from extreme environments.
The findings illustrate the therapeutic and economic potential of optimizing production yields of bioactive secondary metabolites.

nodes.title: Genomic and Functional Characterization of Enterococcus faecalis Isolates Recovered From the International Space Station and Their Potential for Pathogenicity
nodes.summary:
Enterococcus faecalis isolates were recovered from the International Space Station (ISS) 
and characterized for their potential pathogenicity and antibiotic resistance.
The isolates were compared to clinical and commensal reference strains using pangenomic 
and functional analyses, including genome sequencing, minimum inhibitory concentration 
of antibiotics, desiccation survival, and pathogenicity in a Caenorhabditis elegans model.
The results showed that the ISS isolates had similar antibiotic resistance profiles 
to the clinical isolates, but their pathogenicity was not significantly different 
from the commensal isolates in the C. elegans model.
The study highlights the need for improved methods to predict pathogenicity and 
antibiotic resistance in E. faecalis isolates, particularly in the context of space exploration.

nodes.title: Assessing the Risk of Transfer of Microorganisms at the International Space Station Due to Cargo Delivery by Commercial Resupply Vehicles
nodes.summary:
The study assesses the risk of microorganism transfer to the International Space Station (ISS) via commercial resupply vehicles (CRV).
CRV surfaces were found to have a low microbial burden, with an order of magnitude fewer microbes than ground support equipment.
The majority of cultivable microorganisms isolated from CRV surfaces were associated with soil or human skin.
Metagenome analysis revealed significant differences between CRV and ISS microbiomes, with CRV microbiomes dominated by bacteria and ISS microbiomes dominated by human-associated microorganisms.
The study suggests that CRV cleaning protocols are effective in controlling microbial contamination, and continued adherence to these protocols is recommended to limit forward contamination of the ISS.
The results have implications for the protection of extraterrestrial planets from contamination by terrestrial life forms during future interplanetary missions.

nodes.title: MARSBOx: Fungal and Bacterial Endurance From a Balloon-Flown Analog Mission in the Stratosphere
nodes.summary:
Microorganisms were exposed to Mars-like conditions on a balloon flight to the stratosphere.
The MARSBOx payload carried four microorganisms: Aspergillus niger, Staphylococcus capitis subsp. capitis, Salinisphaera shabanensis, and Buttiauxella sp. MASE-IM-9.
A. niger spores showed high endurance to combined stresses of stratospheric radiation and simulated martian conditions.
S. shabanensis and S. capitis subsp. capitis survived the UV-shielded Mars-like environment, but were sensitive to UV exposure.
Buttiauxella sp. MASE-IM-9 did not survive the flight or laboratory controls, indicating low resistance to desiccation.

nodes.title: Methylobacterium ajmalii sp. nov., Isolated From the International Space Station
nodes.summary:
Four strains of Methylobacterium were isolated from the International Space Station.
The strains were identified as Gram-negative, rod-shaped, catalase-positive, and oxidase-positive bacteria.
Phylogenetic analysis showed that three of the strains belonged to a novel species, 
with sequence similarity of <99.4% for 16S rRNA genes and <97.3% for gyrB genes.
The novel species was named Methylobacterium ajmalii sp. nov., with type strain IF7SW-B2 T.
The strain grew optimally at 25-30Â°C, pH 6.0-8.0, and 0-1% NaCl, and utilized various carbon sources.

nodes.title: Comparative genomic analysis of Cohnella hashimotonis sp. nov. isolated from the International Space Station
nodes.summary:
Cohnella hashimotonis sp. nov. is a novel species isolated from the International Space Station.
It is a gram-positive, rod-shaped, oxidase-positive, catalase-negative motile bacterium.
The strain is closely related to C. rhizosphaerae and C. ginsengisoli based on 16S rRNA gene sequence similarity.
Phylogenetic analysis reveals that C. hashimotonis forms a distinct clade with C. rhizosphaerae and C. ginsengisoli.
The genome of C. hashimotonis contains 309 genes not aligned with other Cohnella species, including genes for endospore formation and plant growth hormones.
The species is able to metabolize a wide range of carbon compounds and has a unique fatty acid profile.

nodes.title: Comparative genomic analysis of Cohnella hashimotonis sp. nov. isolated from the International Space Station
nodes.summary:
Cohnella hashimotonis sp. nov. is a novel species isolated from the International Space Station.
It is a gram-positive, rod-shaped, oxidase-positive, catalase-negative motile bacterium.
The strain is closely related to C. rhizosphaerae and C. ginsengisoli based on 16S rRNA gene sequence similarity.
Phylogenetic analysis reveals that C. hashimotonis forms a distinct clade with C. rhizosphaerae and C. ginsengisoli.
The genome of C. hashimotonis contains 309 genes not aligned with other Cohnella species, including genes for endospore formation and plant growth hormones.
The species is able to metabolize a wide range of carbon compounds and has a unique fatty acid profile.

nodes.title: Reviewing the state of biosensors and lab-on-a-chip technologies: opportunities for extreme environments and space exploration
nodes.summary:
Lab-on-a-chip technologies are emerging as a key tool for space exploration and extreme environment investigation.
These technologies have low footprint, high accuracy, and low payload requirements, making them ideal for space missions.
Current practices for analytical measurements in space are limited by the size and weight of instruments, as well as the need for specialized equipment and technicians.
Lab-on-a-chip nanobiosensors can perform in situ analytical measurements in real-time, enabling the detection of chemical and biological compounds in extreme environments.
The development of sensors for extreme temperature conditions, volcanics, environmental microbes, and H+ ions is crucial for space exploration and extreme environment investigation.
Nanobiosensors can be used to monitor astronaut health and life support systems, as well as detect radiation exposure and other hazards in space.
The use of lab-on-a-chip technologies has the potential to revolutionize space exploration and extreme environment investigation by enabling real-time monitoring and detection of various parameters.

nodes.title: Adaptive Changes in the Vestibular System of Land Snail to a 30-Day Spaceflight and Readaptation on Return to Earth
nodes.summary:
Land snails exposed to 30 days of microgravity on the Bion-M1 satellite showed adaptive changes in their vestibular system. 
The snails' statocyst, responsible for balance and equilibrium, exhibited increased sensitivity to tilt stimuli after spaceflight. 
This hypersensitivity was observed in both whole nerve and single unit recordings, with some sensory cells showing phasic-tonic reactions to specific directions of tilt. 
The unpaired sensory neuron at the anterior pole of the statocyst was found to contribute to the directional response with higher sensitivity to "head down" stimuli. 
Readaptation to normal gravity occurred within 20 hours after landing, with the statocyst response returning to normal levels. 
The study suggests that neural plasticity of statocyst sensory statoreceptors or central circuits may be responsible for the adaptation and readaptation processes. 
The findings have implications for understanding the effects of microgravity on the vestibular system and the mechanisms of adaptation and readaptation in both invertebrates and vertebrates.

nodes.title: Influence of Magnitude and Duration of Altered Gravity and Readaptation to 1 g on the Structure and Function of the Utricle in Toadfish, Opsanus tau
nodes.summary:
Toadfish utricular afferents exhibit a wide range of discharge rates and response sensitivities to linear acceleration.
Afferent sensitivity increases after 3-4 days of hypergravity exposure and returns to normal after 5-8 days.
Prolonged hypergravity exposure leads to a decrease in afferent sensitivity, which recovers after return to normal gravity.
Efferent vestibular system activation elevates afferent rate and reduces response sensitivity, but its role in adaptation to altered gravity is unclear.
Synaptic body counts in hair cells do not correlate with changes in afferent sensitivity, suggesting other mechanisms may be involved.
The utricle undergoes continuous plasticity based on the magnitude of the prevailing gravity, with potential implications for understanding vestibular function in microgravity and hypergravity environments.

nodes.title: Influence of Social Isolation During Prolonged Simulated Weightlessness by Hindlimb Unloading
nodes.summary:
Hindlimb unloading (HU) is a model used to simulate the effects of microgravity on the body. 
Researchers developed a refinement to the traditional NASA Ames HU system to accommodate paired housing of animals. 
The study found that HU led to expected musculoskeletal deficits in both singly and socially housed mice. 
However, select immune and hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal (HPA) axis responses were differentially impacted by the HU social environment. 
HU led to a reduction in CD4+ T cells in singly housed, but not in socially housed mice. 
The study suggests that social isolation can mask or exacerbate select responses to HU, and that the HU model can be used to study the effects of social interactions on the HPA axis and immune system. 
The findings have implications for the use of the HU model to simulate exposure to the spaceflight environment and for understanding the effects of social isolation on the body.

nodes.title: Simulated Microgravity Induces Regionally Distinct Neurovascular and Structural Remodeling of Skeletal Muscle and Cutaneous Arteries in the Rat
nodes.summary:
Hindlimb unloading induces contrasting structural and functional adaptations in forelimb and hindlimb skeletal muscle arteries.
HU exposure results in divergent alterations of forelimb and hindlimb skeletal muscle arteries, including lumen diameter and wall contractility.
The changes in contractility are independent of the vascular endothelium and not associated with the change in smooth muscle sensitivity to contractile stimulation.
HU impairs sympathetic nerve-mediated vasoconstriction while enhancing the sensitivity of smooth muscle to the adrenergic agonist noradrenaline in cutaneous arteries.
The higher constrictor sensitivity of cutaneous arteries is observed after endothelium removal and with the application of the non-adrenergic agonist serotonin.
HU reduces the density of adrenergic plexus in saphenous arteries, leading to non-specific hyper-sensitivity of the saphenous artery to constrictor stimulation.
The study's findings indicate that simulated microgravity differentially affects the skin and skeletal muscle arteries in the hindlimb, with functional alterations resulting from direct effects of physical forces and changes in sympathetic innervation.

nodes.title: Spaceflight-Associated Vascular Remodeling and Gene Expression in Mouse Calvaria
nodes.summary:
Mice exposed to 15 days of spaceflight showed a 30% increase in capillarization and reduced vessel diameter in their calvaria.
Vessel numbers and diameter remained unchanged in mice exposed to 30 days of spaceflight.
Pro-angiogenic VEGFA expression increased 15-fold in spaceflight mice compared to ground controls.
BMP-2 gene expression increased 11-fold in spaceflight mice, indicating a potential role in bone formation.
RUNX2 and DMP1 gene expression also increased in spaceflight mice, suggesting a link between angiogenesis and osteogenesis.
The study suggests that microgravity-associated alterations in gene expression may be important for understanding bone growth and vascular remodeling in non-load bearing regions.
The findings have implications for the development of countermeasures for long-duration spaceflight and extraterrestrial human habitation.

nodes.title: Proteomic and phosphoproteomic characterization of cardiovascular tissues after long term exposure to simulated space radiation
nodes.summary:
Mice exposed to Galactic Cosmic Ray (GCR) 5-ion exhibit cardiovascular dysfunction 12 months post-radiation.
Proteomic and phosphoproteomic analysis of heart tissue and plasma reveals differentially expressed proteins and pathways.
Inflammatory pathways, including coagulation cascade and complement cascade, are significantly perturbed in the heart and plasma.
Neutrophil extracellular traps (NETs) are elevated in the myocardium of GCR 5-ion irradiated mice 12 months post-irradiation.
The formation of NETs may contribute to the development of cardiovascular disease and thrombosis in space travelers.
The study highlights the need for further investigation into the effects of space radiation on the cardiovascular system.

nodes.title: Upregulation of Amy1 in the salivary glands of mice exposed to a lunar gravity environment using the multiple artificial gravity research system
nodes.summary:
Mice exposed to lunar gravity showed upregulation of Amy1, a gene encoding salivary amylase, in their submandibular glands. 
Vamp8, a v-SNARE gene involved in protein secretion, was also upregulated in the lunar gravity environment. 
Small G proteins, including Rap1 and Rab families, were upregulated and play a crucial role in salivary secretion. 
The expression of mechanosensitive ion channels was downregulated in the lunar gravity environment. 
Oxidative phosphorylation and ATP synthesis were upregulated in the submandibular glands under lunar gravity. 
The study suggests that lunar gravity induces qualitative changes in salivary secretion function and multiple genes are involved in maintaining salivary secretion homeostasis. 
The findings may contribute to the future monitoring of physical and mental health of humans living in space and improvement of oral medicine.

nodes.title: 4-3-3 Phosphoprotein interaction networks -does isoform diversity present functional interaction specification?
nodes.summary:
The 14-3-3 proteins are a family of regulatory proteins involved in protein interactions and signal transduction pathways.
They are present in all eukaryotes and have a conserved structure, but also exhibit diversity in their primary sequence.
This diversity can be amplified by phosphorylation and heterodimerization, leading to questions about functional specificity among isoforms.
The theory of specificity proposes that certain 14-3-3 isoforms have unique functions not present in other isoforms, even if they are present in the same cell.
Evidence from TDNA mutations, biochemical interactions, and subcellular localization supports this theory, suggesting that 14-3-3 isoforms can have distinct roles in different cellular contexts.

nodes.title: Genomic stability in response to high versus low linear energy transfer radiation in Arabidopsis thaliana
nodes.summary:
Arabidopsis thaliana mutants were exposed to high linear energy transfer (LET) radiation or low LET gamma radiation.
The relative biological effectiveness (RBE) of high LET radiation versus gamma radiation was estimated to be around 3:1.
Loss of somatic heterozygosity was induced at an RBE of about 2:1 for high LET radiation versus gamma radiation.
Checkpoint and repair defects enhanced sensitivity to both types of radiation.
The "replication fork" checkpoint governed by ATR played a slightly more important role in resistance to high LET radiation-induced mutagenesis.
High LET radiation caused more complex and clustered DNA damage than low LET radiation.
The increased sensitivity of plants to high LET radiation suggests that the complexity of DNA damage plays a crucial role in determining the efficiency and accuracy of DNA repair.

nodes.title: Phosphoinositide-signaling is one component of a robust plant defense response
nodes.summary:
Phosphoinositide-signaling is a component of plant defense responses.
InsP 5-ptase plants have reduced InsP 3 levels and are more susceptible to pathogens.
The plants show impaired Ca 2+ elevation and reduced expression of defense genes.
SA-mediated signaling is also affected, with lower basal SA levels and delayed PR-1 induction.
The SAR response is delayed in InsP 5-ptase plants, with reduced expression of SAR-related genes.
The results suggest that InsP 3 plays a role in plant defense, particularly in Ca 2+ signaling and SA-mediated responses.

nodes.title: Endoplasmic reticulum-shape and function in stress translation
nodes.summary:
The endoplasmic reticulum (ER) plays a crucial role in cellular homeostasis and stress response.
ER morphology is dynamic and changes in response to various cellular stresses.
Stress conditions trigger the activation of signaling pathways that regulate ER shape and function.
The unfolded protein response (UPR) is a key pathway that mitigates ER stress by enhancing protein folding capacity.
ER stress also induces changes in ER morphology, including expansion and fragmentation.
These changes enable the ER to adapt to stress conditions and maintain cellular homeostasis.
Dysregulation of ER shape and function contributes to various diseases, including neurodegenerative disorders and cancer.

nodes.title: Light and gravity signals synergize in modulating plant development
nodes.summary:
Plant development is influenced by environmental stimuli such as light and gravity.
Tropisms, including phototropism and gravitropism, are growth-mediated movements that help plants respond to these stimuli.
The starch-statolith hypothesis proposes that perception of gravity is mediated by dense starch-filled organelles interacting with cytoplasmic structures.
Light signals, particularly blue light, are sensed by photoreceptor proteins and mediate phototropic responses.
Auxin plays a key role in regulating cell cycle progression and coordinating cell growth and division in meristematic cells.
Altered gravity environments, such as microgravity, disrupt meristematic competence and affect cell proliferation and growth.
Red light stimulation can counteract the effects of gravitational stress on cell growth and proliferation.

nodes.title: Gravitropism and Lateral Root Emergence are Dependent on the Trans-Golgi Network Protein TNO1
nodes.summary:
The trans-Golgi network (TGN) protein TNO1 is required for gravitropism and lateral root emergence.
TNO1 associates with the membrane fusion protein SYP41 and is involved in protein trafficking to the vacuole.
The tno1 mutant has delayed lateral root emergence and decreased gravitropic bending of plant organs.
The mutant also exhibits increased sensitivity to the auxin analog 2,4-dichlorophenoxyacetic acid and the natural auxin 3-indoleacetic acid.
Auxin asymmetry at the tips of elongating stage II lateral roots is reduced in the tno1 mutant.
TNO1 is not required for bulk endocytosis, but may regulate gravitropic responses through trafficking of auxin transporters.

nodes.title: Corrigendum: High atomic weight, high-energy radiation (HZE) induces transcriptional responses shared with conventional stresses in addition to a core "DSB" response specific to clastogenic treatments
nodes.summary:
High atomic weight, high-energy radiation (HZE) induces transcriptional responses in plants. 
These responses are shared with conventional stresses and a core "DSB" response. 
The "DSB" response is specific to clastogenic treatments, causing DNA damage. 
The study aimed to investigate the effects of HZE radiation on plant transcriptional responses. 
A microarray dataset was used to analyze the transcriptional responses. 
The correct accession number for the microarray dataset was not provided in the original article. 
The correction provides the accurate information for the microarray dataset accession number.

nodes.title: RNAseq Analysis of the Response of Arabidopsis thaliana to Fractional Gravity Under Blue-Light Stimulation During Spaceflight
nodes.summary:
Arabidopsis thaliana seeds were germinated and grown on the International Space Station under different gravity levels. 
RNAseq analysis was performed to study the transcriptional response to partial gravity levels. 
Differential gene expression analysis revealed one differentially expressed gene across all gravity conditions. 
Fourteen genes were differentially expressed when comparing micro-g, low-g, or Moon g-level with 1g control conditions. 
Gene Ontology analysis showed different responses at each g-level, including light and photosynthesis under microgravity. 
The results suggest that blue-light phototropism may reduce the gravitational stress response in microgravity. 
The study provides insights into the transcriptional response of plants to partial gravity levels, which is crucial for future space missions.

nodes.title: Comparison of Microgravity Analogs to Spaceflight in Studies of Plant Growth and Development
nodes.summary:
Plant growth and development are affected by gravity, and understanding its effects requires changing the magnitude of this force. 
Microgravity analogs, such as clinostats and random positioning machines, are used to simulate microgravity conditions on Earth. 
These devices change the direction of gravity, rather than reducing its magnitude, and have limitations and artifacts. 
Random positioning machines are considered a better proxy for weightlessness, but are limited to small organisms. 
Magnetic levitation is another method that counteracts gravity using magnetic forces, but has its own set of complications. 
Centrifuges can be used to generate partial gravity conditions, and have been used on the International Space Station to study plant development. 
The comparison of microgravity analogs to spaceflight experiments is crucial to understanding plant biology in space and developing technologies for human habitation of other worlds.

nodes.title: Brassinosteroids Inhibit Autotropic Root Straightening by Modifying Filamentous-Actin Organization and Dynamics
nodes.summary:
Brassinosteroids inhibit autotropic root straightening by modifying filamentous-actin organization and dynamics.
Epi-brassinolide (eBL) enhances root gravitropism, similar to the actin inhibitor latrunculin B (LatB).
eBL-treated roots exhibit persistent curvature on a slowly rotating clinostat, similar to LatB-treated roots.
The effect of eBL on root gravitropism is explained by its inhibition of autotropic straightening, which results from modifications in F-actin organization and dynamics.
eBL modifies F-actin organization in maize roots, causing a significant reduction in density, but its effects are milder than those of LatB.
The study introduces a set of Medicago truncatula lines expressing fluorescent protein-based F-actin reporters, which can be used to study actin-mediated processes in legumes.

nodes.title: Test of Arabidopsis Space Transcriptome: A Discovery Environment to Explore Multiple Plant Biology Spaceflight Experiments
nodes.summary:
The Test Of Arabidopsis Space Transcriptome (TOAST) database is a relational database that links plant biology, spaceflight-related omics datasets, and their associated metadata. 
TOAST uses the Qlik database management software to visualize relationships across multiple levels of experiments in an easy-to-use gene-centric platform. 
The database draws on data from NASA's GeneLab and other data repositories, connecting results to a suite of web-based analytical tools. 
TOAST allows for quick comparisons between plant spaceflight experiments using real-time, gene-specific queries or functional gene ontology. 
The database confirms patterns of gene expression already highlighted in the literature, such as the modulation of oxidative stress-related responses. 
TOAST also enables cross-species comparisons, revealing fundamental elements of plant biology response to spaceflight, including alterations in mitochondrial function. 
The database provides a powerful tool for hypothesis generation and exploration of plant spaceflight data, facilitating the discovery of new insights into plant biology in space.

nodes.title: Microbiological and Nutritional Analysis of Lettuce Crops Grown on the International Space Station
nodes.summary:
Red romaine lettuce was grown on the International Space Station (ISS) using the Veggie plant growth chamber. 
The study compared the microbiological and nutritional quality of ISS-grown lettuce to ground controls. 
Microbiological analysis showed low bacterial and fungal counts on ISS-grown lettuce, with no detection of human pathogens. 
The dominant bacterial phyla were Proteobacteria, Bacteroidetes, Actinobacteria, and Chloroflexi. 
Elemental analysis revealed differences in Fe, K, Na, P, S, and Zn content between ISS-grown and ground control lettuce. 
Total phenolic levels were also different between the two groups, but no differences were found in anthocyanin and ORAC levels. 
The study indicates that lettuce can be safely grown on the ISS for consumption by astronauts, providing a fresh and nutritious supplement to their diet.

nodes.title: Root Skewing-Associated Genes Impact the Spaceflight Response of Arabidopsis thaliana
nodes.summary:
The APEX-03-2 study investigated the role of two skewing-associated genes, SPIRAL1 and SKU5, in the spaceflight response of Arabidopsis thaliana.
The study found that the spr1 mutant showed fewer differentially expressed genes than its Col-0 wild-type in spaceflight.
In contrast, the sku5 mutant showed a dramatic increase in differential gene expression in spaceflight, with many genes associated with stress responses and ABA signaling.
The data suggest that the SPR1 and SKU5 pathways have unique and opposite contributions to physiological adaptation to spaceflight.
The loss of SPR1 function may positively impact spaceflight adaptation, while the loss of SKU5 function initiates a more complex and stress-related response.
The study provides an initial functional dissection of the spaceflight response in roots, integrating pathways associated with root directionality, morphology, and physiological responses to spaceflight.

nodes.title: Competitive Growth Assay of Mutagenized Chlamydomonas reinhardtii Compatible With the International Space Station Veggie Plant Growth Chamber
nodes.summary:
Chlamydomonas reinhardtii is a model organism for unicellular algae with potential applications in space life support systems. 
A competitive growth assay was developed to identify genes required for growth in spaceflight conditions using breathable plastic tissue culture bags. 
The bags supported robust growth of Chlamydomonas without agitation or active mixing of gases with liquids. 
UVC mutagenesis was used to induce mutations, and whole genome sequencing identified novel variants enriched for non-synonymous mutations. 
Genes showing positive selection were enriched for information processing functions, including DNA repair, RNA processing, and signal transduction. 
The results suggest that modification of DNA repair, signal transduction, and metabolite transport may be needed to improve growth rates in spaceflight production systems. 
The study provides a foundation for understanding the genetic requirements for Chlamydomonas growth in spaceflight conditions.

nodes.title: Biomass Production of the EDEN ISS Space Greenhouse in Antarctica During the 2018 Experiment Phase
nodes.summary:
The EDEN ISS greenhouse in Antarctica produced over 268 kg of edible biomass in 2018. 
Cucumbers, lettuces, leafy greens, and tomatoes were the top-producing crops. 
The greenhouse operated for 9 months with a controlled environment and aeroponic system. 
LED lighting with adjustable spectrum and intensity was used for plant growth. 
The average yearly productivity was 27.4 kg/mÂ², equivalent to 0.075 kg/(mÂ²*d). 
The data collected can be used to improve simulation models for space greenhouses and cultivar selection. 
The EDEN ISS project aims to develop technologies for future human space missions and sustainable food production.

nodes.title: Hardware Validation of the Advanced Plant Habitat on ISS: Canopy Photosynthesis in Reduced Gravity
nodes.summary:
The Advanced Plant Habitat (APH) facility was designed to conduct plant research in reduced gravity on the International Space Station (ISS).
The APH has a controlled environment chamber with temperature, humidity, CO2 concentration, and light intensity control.
A hardware validation test was conducted to verify the APH's functionality and ability to grow plants in microgravity.
The test used two plant species, Arabidopsis and wheat, which were grown for 6 weeks and 33 days, respectively.
The APH successfully measured photosynthesis, respiration, and canopy quantum yield (CQY) of the plant canopy during spaceflight.
The results demonstrated the APH's capabilities for conducting fundamental plant research in microgravity.
The APH's ability to collect non-destructive data sets will expand our knowledge of plant growth during spaceflight, supporting sustainable human colonization of space.

nodes.title: A Conditional Mutation in SCD1 Reveals Linkage Between PIN Protein Trafficking, Auxin Transport, Gravitropism, and Lateral Root Initiation
nodes.summary:
The scd1-1 mutant exhibits impaired root elongation and gravity response at 25Â°C.
Lateral root formation is reduced in scd1-1 at 25Â°C compared to 18Â°C.
Auxin transport is impaired in scd1-1 at 25Â°C, with reduced rootward and shootward transport.
PIN2-GFP accumulates in endomembrane bodies in scd1-1 at 25Â°C, consistent with altered trafficking.
The endomembrane bodies colocalize with FM4-64 and ARA7, indicating late endosomal localization.
SCD1 functions as a RAB-GEF, regulating PIN2 trafficking and auxin transport.
Altered PIN2 trafficking precedes changes in auxin transport and dependent physiological processes.

nodes.title: Desiccation Mitigates Heat Stress in the Resurrection Fern, Pleopeltis polypodioides
nodes.summary:
Pleopeltis polypodioides, a resurrection fern, exhibits desiccation tolerance and can survive loss of 95% cellular water content. 
The study investigated the response of Pleopeltis to heat stress in dry and hydrated conditions. 
Dry fronds showed higher heat tolerance than hydrated fronds, with a threshold of 55Â°C for dry fronds and 40Â°C for hydrated fronds. 
The photosynthetic apparatus in dry fronds was heat-tolerant up to 60Â°C, while hydrated fronds experienced damage at temperatures above 40Â°C. 
The data suggest that dehydration protects Pleopeltis from heat damage, and the fern's adaptability enables it to cope with environmental stress. 
The study's findings have implications for understanding the mechanisms of desiccation tolerance and heat stress response in plants. 
Overall, the research provides insights into the complex responses of Pleopeltis to heat stress and desiccation.

nodes.title: New Insights Into Lignification via Network and Multi-Omics Analyses of Arogenate Dehydratase Knock-Out Mutants in Arabidopsis thaliana
nodes.summary:
Arogenate dehydratase (ADT) is an enzyme involved in lignin biosynthesis in plants.
ADT knockout mutants in Arabidopsis thaliana show reduced lignin content and altered metabolite profiles.
Multi-omics analysis, including transcriptomics, proteomics, and metabolomics, was used to study the effects of ADT knockout on Arabidopsis.
The analysis revealed changes in various metabolic pathways, including phenylpropanoid biosynthesis and photosynthesis.
Network analysis identified potential regulatory proteins and pathways involved in lignin biosynthesis, including a possible "ribocode" regulating lignin levels.
The study provides new insights into the complex regulation of lignin biosynthesis and its potential applications in bioengineering.

nodes.title: Epigenomic Regulators Elongator Complex Subunit 2 and Methyltransferase 1 Differentially Condition the Spaceflight Response in Arabidopsis
nodes.summary:
The Advanced Plant Experiment 04 -Epigenetic Expression (APEX-04-EPEX) investigated the role of cytosine methylation in spaceflight adaptation.
The experiment used Arabidopsis thaliana mutants met1-7 and elp2-5, and wild-type Col-0, to evaluate spaceflight responses.
Spaceflight increased genome-wide DNA methylation levels in met1-7 and elp2-5 but not in Col-0 plants.
The elp2-5 plants showed impaired growth in spaceflight, with roots failing to extend away from the seed.
The met1-7 plants exhibited a typical spaceflight growth morphology, similar to Col-0, with roots extending away from the seed.

nodes.title: Bundling up the Role of the Actin Cytoskeleton in Primary Root Growth
nodes.summary:
The actin cytoskeleton plays a crucial role in primary root growth by regulating cell elongation and division.
Actin organization is developmentally regulated in the growing root tip, with bundled and longitudinally oriented actin filaments characteristic of cell elongation.
Hormonal regulation of primary root growth occurs mainly through the coordination between auxin and cytokinin signaling, which contributes to the generation of developmental regions with specific actin organization.
Actin is involved in the direct sensing of gravity, controls the propagation of the hormone signal, and is likely involved in the subsequent regulation of cell elongation during root gravitropism.
The role of actin-binding proteins in regulating the actin network with regard to growth and development of the root meristem is not well understood due to genetic redundancy.
Recent advances in CRISPR multiplexing and live imaging techniques will help elucidate the roles of actin-binding proteins in root growth and development.
Optogenetic tools may provide a deeper understanding of how actin functions in regulating cell elongation in complex tissues such as the root.

nodes.title: The EXO70 inhibitor Endosidin2 alters plasma membrane protein composition in Arabidopsis roots
nodes.summary:
The plant exocyst complex plays a crucial role in mediating constitutive transport of proteins to the plasma membrane. 
Using the EXO70 inhibitor Endosidin2 (ES2), researchers identified 145 plasma membrane proteins with reduced abundance after ES2 treatment. 
These proteins are involved in various functions, including cell growth, cell wall biosynthesis, hormone signaling, and stress responses. 
The exocyst complex regulates the trafficking of proteins with diverse functions, highlighting its importance in plant growth and development. 
Live-cell imaging confirmed the reduction in plasma membrane abundance of specific proteins, such as PIN2, BRI1, and FER, after ES2 treatment. 
The study provides new insights into the role of the exocyst complex in plant plasma membrane protein dynamics and identifies novel cargo proteins.

nodes.title: Integrative transcriptomics and proteomics profiling of Arabidopsis thaliana elucidates novel mechanisms underlying spaceflight adaptation
nodes.summary:
Arabidopsis thaliana seedlings were grown in microgravity aboard the International Space Station.
The study combined transcriptomics and proteomics approaches to understand plant responses to spaceflight.
Results showed alterations in photosynthetic machinery, with changes in photosystem core-regulatory proteins.
The study also found changes in ionic, molecular, and vesicular transports in both root and shoot.
Proteins involved in cell wall synthesis, integrity, and maintenance were altered in spaceflight, indicating changes in cellulose metabolism.

nodes.title: Editorial: Revisiting the limits of plant life -plant adaptations to extreme terrestrial environments relating to astrobiology and space biology
nodes.summary:
Plants were essential to the early evolution of terrestrial life and colonization of the young Earth.
Plant communities continue to colonize and transform our planet, including the newest ecosystems formed post-glaciation.
Plants have evolved remarkable strategies to survive and thrive in harsh environments.
Humanity is on the verge of exploring our solar system and beyond, searching for extraterrestrial forms of life.
Plants are key organisms to successful deep space missions and independence from terrestrial resources.
Terrestrial bio-design principles can be employed to mimic plant colonization on Earth and explore adaptations to novel ecosystems.
This collective knowledge will advance the selection of desired plant characteristics relevant to human space missions.

nodes.title: Conserved plant transcriptional responses to microgravity from two consecutive spaceflight experiments
nodes.summary:
Two spaceflight experiments, Plant Signaling and Plant RNA Regulation, were conducted on the International Space Station to study the effects of microgravity on Arabidopsis seedlings. 
The experiments used the European Modular Cultivation System, which provided a controlled environment with lighting and centrifugal capabilities for 1g controls. 
RNA-Seq analysis revealed significant overlap in differentially expressed genes between the two experiments, with genes involved in transcriptional regulation, shoot development, and auxin response upregulated in microgravity. 
Conversely, genes involved in defense response, abiotic stress, and cell wall modification were downregulated in microgravity. 
The results suggest that microgravity has a profound impact on plant gene expression, with potential implications for plant growth and development in space. 
The study highlights the importance of onboard 1g controls in spaceflight experiments to distinguish microgravity-specific effects from other spaceflight-related stress responses. 
The findings provide valuable insights into the molecular mechanisms underlying plant adaptation to microgravity, which is essential for future long-duration space missions.

nodes.title: Network Analysis of Gene Transcriptions of Arabidopsis thaliana in Spaceflight Microgravity
nodes.summary:
Network analysis of Arabidopsis thaliana gene transcriptions in spaceflight microgravity identified hub genes with higher transcriptional abundance. 
The hub genes are involved in cell wall synthesis, protein transport, response to auxin, stress responses, and catabolic processes. 
Graph-based spectral analyses revealed distinct properties of spaceflight microgravity networks for different ecotypes. 
The weighted HITS algorithm was used to identify hub genes and target genes in the gene regulatory networks. 
Gene set enrichment analysis showed that the hub genes are involved in biological processes such as DNA integration and oxidation-reduction process. 
The study identified five significant hub genes with higher regulations in spaceflight microgravity, involved in cell wall biosynthesis. 
These genes encode nucleotide-diphospho-sugar interconversion enzymes, which are involved in building cell wall polysaccharides.

nodes.title: Detection of Genes in Arabidopsis thaliana L. Responding to DNA Damage from Radiation and Other Stressors in Spaceflight
nodes.summary:
Arabidopsis thaliana is a model organism used to study the effects of spaceflight on plants.
Ionizing radiation in space can cause DNA damage and affect plant growth and development.
Gene regulatory networks (GRNs) and causal relational networks were constructed to identify key genes involved in DNA damage response (DDR) processes.
Eighteen radiation-induced genes and sixteen non-radiation-induced genes were identified as key players in DDR processes.
The genes AT3G27060, AT1G07500, AT5G66140, and AT3G21280 were ranked as the most significant genes involved in DNA repair processes.
Network analysis revealed that low radiation doses result in sparse subnetworks, while very high radiation doses result in dense subnetworks with higher spectral gaps.

nodes.title: Detection of Target Genes for Drug Repurposing to Treat Skeletal Muscle Atrophy in Mice Flown in Spaceflight
nodes.summary:
Skeletal muscle atrophy is a condition that affects astronauts in spaceflight due to microgravity.
The study uses machine learning algorithms to identify key genes and drugs for treating muscle atrophy.
Seven GeneLab datasets were mined to identify 473 significantly regulated genes associated with muscle atrophy.
The genes are linked to various diseases, including metabolic and neurodegenerative diseases, cancer, and chronic inflammatory diseases.
The study uses graph convolutional neural networks (GCN) and other machine learning methods for link prediction in gene-disease and disease-drug networks.
The GCN method achieves the highest accuracy for link prediction, identifying potential drugs for repurposing, including L-carnitine, thiamine, and corticosteroids.

nodes.title: Simulated Microgravity Alters Gene Regulation Linked to Immunity and Cardiovascular Disease
nodes.summary:
Simulated microgravity alters gene regulation linked to immunity and cardiovascular disease.
The study used a rat hindlimb unloading model to examine cardiac responses to microgravity exposure.
Results showed sex-dependent changes in oxidative damage and antioxidant gene expression.
Young females displayed elevated oxidative damage after 14 days of microgravity exposure.
RNAseq analysis revealed upregulation of pathways involved in pro-inflammatory signaling and immune cell activation.
The study suggests that targeting antioxidant and immune pathways may help maintain cardiovascular health in space.

nodes.title: Simulated Microgravity Alters Gene Regulation Linked to Immunity and Cardiovascular Disease
nodes.summary:
Simulated microgravity alters gene regulation linked to immunity and cardiovascular disease.
The study used a rat hindlimb unloading model to examine cardiac responses to microgravity.
Results showed sex-dependent changes in oxidative damage and antioxidant gene expression.
Young females displayed elevated oxidative damage after 14 days of microgravity, while males did not.
RNAseq analysis revealed upregulation of pathways involved in pro-inflammatory signaling and immune cell activation.
The study's findings provide a rationale for targeting antioxidant and immune pathways to maintain cardiovascular health in space.

nodes.title: Celebr a ting 30 years of access to NASA Space Life Sciences data
nodes.summary:
NASA's space life sciences research programs have generated valuable data over the decades. 
The NASA Ames Life Sciences Data Archive (ALSDA) was established in 1994 to collect and store life sciences data. 
ALSDA was tasked with providing representation for Space Life Sciences to the Consultative Committee for Space Data Systems. 
The Open Archival Information System (OAIS) Reference Model was developed as a result of this effort. 
In 2014, NASA initiated the GeneLab project to provide open access to omics data generated from biological experiments in space. 
The integration of ALSDA with GeneLab has resulted in the creation of the Open Science Data Repository (OSDR). 
OSDR hosts over 500 studies across all life forms, with curated metadata and accessible raw and processed data files.

nodes.title: Celebr a ting 30 years of access to NASA Space Life Sciences data
nodes.summary:
NASA's space life sciences research programs have generated valuable data over the decades. 
The NASA Ames Life Sciences Data Archive (ALSDA) was established in 1994 to collect and store life sciences data. 
ALSDA was tasked with providing representation for Space Life Sciences to the Consultative Committee for Space Data Systems. 
The Open Archival Information System (OAIS) Reference Model was developed as a result of this effort. 
In 2014, NASA initiated the GeneLab project to provide open access to omics data generated from biological experiments in space. 
The integration of ALSDA with GeneLab has resulted in the creation of the Open Science Data Repository (OSDR). 
OSDR hosts over 500 studies across all life forms, with curated metadata and accessible raw and processed data files.

nodes.title: NASA GeneLab: interfaces for the exploration of space omics data
nodes.summary: NASA's GeneLab database collects and provides access to genomic, transcriptomic, proteomic, and metabolomic data from biospecimens flown in space or exposed to simulated space stressors. The database enables the exploration of molecular network responses to space environments using a systems biology approach. GeneLab has developed a new data repository web interface and the GeneLab Online Data Entry (GEODE) web portal to support data submission and curation. The database has implemented the FAIR principles to ensure findability, accessibility, interoperability, and reusability of the data. GeneLab has also established an Application Programming Interface (API) to support tools for the visualization of processed omics data. The database contains data from 271 studies, including investigations of spaceflight experimental factors such as gravity level and ionizing radiation. GeneLab's outreach efforts aim to generate novel discoveries and develop new hypotheses using the data in the repository.

nodes.title: NASA open science data repository: open science for life in space
nodes.summary:
NASA's Open Science Data Repository integrates life sciences and biomedical data from space experiments.
The repository combines 'omics and non-omics data, enhancing access to diverse data types.
It features a biological data management environment, controlled data access, and an enhanced API.
The repository promotes global collaboration, transparency, and inclusivity in research.
It supports the scientific community in advancing understanding of spaceflight's impact on biological systems.
The repository has enabled 92 publications and has a growing collection of over 500 studies.
It provides a platform for data sharing, analysis, and visualization, facilitating discoveries in space biology.

nodes.title: MnSOD Overexpression Reduces Fibrosis and Pro-Apoptotic Signaling in the Aging Mouse Heart
nodes.summary:
MnSOD overexpression reduces fibrosis and pro-apoptotic signaling in the aging mouse heart.
Oxidative stress markers, such as total hydroperoxides and 4-HNE, are decreased in old MnSOD Tg mice.
MnSOD overexpression attenuates age-induced remodeling, including increased extramyocyte space and collagen-I.
TGF-Î²1, a pro-fibrotic protein, is reduced in old MnSOD Tg mice, suggesting a regulatory role of MnSOD on fibrosis.
MnSOD overexpression also reduces mitochondrial-mediated apoptotic signaling, including Bax and cleaved caspase-3.
Apoptosis is mitigated in old MnSOD Tg mice, as indicated by reduced TUNEL-positive myonuclei and DNA fragmentation.

nodes.title: Transcriptomics, NF-ÎºB Pathway, and Their Potential Spaceflight-Related Health Consequences
nodes.summary:
Spaceflight exposes humans to multiple stress factors, including microgravity and space radiation, which can cause negative health impacts. 
The NF-ÎºB pathway is commonly affected by spaceflight conditions and is associated with many spaceflight-related health consequences. 
NF-ÎºB is a protein complex that controls transcription of DNA, cytokine production, and cell survival. 
Alterations in the NF-ÎºB pathway have been linked to diseases such as immune dysfunction, bone loss, and muscle atrophy. 
Studies have shown that NF-ÎºB is activated or inhibited in space, depending on the cell type, and that this alteration can impact health negatively. 
Investigations using cells or animals deficient in certain subunits of NF-ÎºB are needed to determine whether manipulation of the NF-ÎºB pathways can reduce spaceflight-related health risks. 
More research on NF-ÎºB is necessary to fully understand its role in spaceflight-related health consequences and to develop effective countermeasures.

nodes.title: Spaceflight Activates Autophagy Programs and the Proteasome in Mouse Liver
nodes.summary:
Spaceflight activates autophagy programs and the proteasome in mouse liver.
Exposure to space environment leads to increased oxidative stress and impaired oxidative defense.
Autophagy-related genes are upregulated, and the proteasome is activated to degrade damaged proteins.
Mitochondrial dysfunction and accumulation of oxidized proteins contribute to hepatocyte senescence.
Spaceflight causes broad alterations in transcriptome profiles, including changes in metabolism and cellular processes.
The ubiquitin-proteasome system and autophagy are essential for maintaining cellular homeostasis in response to spaceflight.
Impaired liver function and increased risk of liver damage are potential concerns for long-duration space exploration.

nodes.title: Dose-and Ion-Dependent Effects in the Oxidative Stress Response to Space-Like Radiation Exposure in the Skeletal System
nodes.summary:
Space radiation exposure impairs osteoblastogenesis in an ion-type specific manner. 
High-LET 56 Fe ions cause more damage than low-LET protons at the same dose. 
A high dose of 56 Fe (200 cGy) inhibits osteoblastogenesis by over 90%. 
Low doses of radiation (below 50 cGy) do not elicit widespread responses. 
Exogenous superoxide dismutase (SOD) protects marrow-derived osteoprogenitors from low-LET radiation. 
However, SOD has limited protective effects on high-LET 56 Fe-exposed cells. 
High-LET irradiation at 200 cGy impairs osteoblastogenesis and regulates redox-related gene expression.

nodes.title: Redox Signaling and Its Impact on Skeletal and Vascular Responses to Spaceflight
nodes.summary:
Spaceflight exposes individuals to environmental challenges that can lead to musculoskeletal and vascular dysfunction.
Oxidative stress and damage are implicated in tissue dysfunction during and after spaceflight.
Reactive oxygen species (ROS) and reactive nitrogen species (RNS) can stimulate bone resorption and impair vascular function.
Nitric oxide (NO) signaling is critical for vascular health, and its bioavailability is reduced in conditions of oxidative stress.
Genetic models have shown that antioxidant defenses, such as NRF2 and SOD1, play a crucial role in maintaining skeletal and vascular health.
Pharmacologic interventions targeting ROS and inflammation may mitigate radiation-induced bone loss.
Antioxidant-based countermeasures may be effective in preventing tissue dysfunction during spaceflight, but their development requires further research.

nodes.title: Impact of Spaceflight and Artificial Gravity on the Mouse Retina: Biochemical and Proteomic Analysis
nodes.summary:
Spaceflight induces apoptosis in retinal vascular endothelial cells and alters protein expression profiles in mouse ocular tissue. 
The application of 1g artificial gravity during spaceflight mitigates these changes. 
Proteomic analysis revealed significant changes in canonical pathways responsible for cell death, cell repair, inflammation, and metabolic function. 
The study used a mouse model to investigate the effects of spaceflight on the retina. 
Twelve mice were flown to the International Space Station for a 35-day mission. 
The mice were divided into two groups: one exposed to microgravity and the other to artificial gravity. 
The results showed that microgravity induced significant apoptosis in retinal endothelial cells. 
Artificial gravity reduced the detrimental effects of microgravity on the retina.

nodes.title: Reactivation of Latent Epstein-Barr Virus: A Comparison after Exposure to Gamma, Proton, Carbon, and Iron Radiation
nodes.summary:
Astronauts are exposed to multiple stressors during spaceflight, including cosmic radiation.
Cosmic radiation may lead to decreased immunity and reactivation of latent herpes viruses.
Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) is one of the eight human herpes viruses known to infect over 90% of human adults.
Four types of radiation (gamma, proton, carbon, and iron) were studied for their effect on EBV reactivation.
All four types of radiation induced EBV lytic gene transcription and reactivation at doses of 0.1-2.0 Gy.

nodes.title: Synergistic Effects of Weightlessness, Isoproterenol, and Radiation on DNA Damage Response and Cytokine Production in Immune Cells
nodes.summary:
The study investigates the synergistic effects of weightlessness, isoproterenol, and radiation on DNA damage response and cytokine production in immune cells.
Isoproterenol prevents microgravity-mediated effects on DNA damage response and cytokine production.
Radiation-induced cytokine production is only detectable in cells incubated in simulated microgravity.
The combination of microgravity and radiation reduces the rate of apoptosis induced by radiation alone.
The study suggests a novel potential player in the regulation of radiation-induced DNA damage response, namely the involvement of Î²2-adrenergic receptor activation.
The results have implications for the development of countermeasures for space medicine and cancer treatment.

nodes.title: Effects of Space Flight on Mouse Liver versus Kidney: Gene Pathway Analyses
nodes.summary:
Mouse liver and kidney tissues were analyzed after 12 days in space to determine genome-wide gene expression changes.
The study used gene array analysis and Gene Set Enrichment Analysis (GSEA) to identify tissue-specific and shared responses to spaceflight.
Both liver and kidney overexpressed genes in four areas: cellular responses, apoptosis, fat cell differentiation, and negative regulation of protein kinase.
GSEA analysis identified 764 pathways with concordant changes in liver and kidney, and 21 pathways with discordant changes.
The study confirmed previous findings of changes in lipid metabolism, apoptosis, and protein kinase activity in liver tissue.
Kidney tissue showed changes in peptide binding, amine receptor, and amino acid catabolism pathways.
The results suggest that spaceflight induces both tissue-specific and shared responses in liver and kidney tissues.

nodes.title: Proteomic Analysis of Mouse Brain Subjected to Spaceflight
nodes.summary:
Spaceflight poses risks to the central nervous system, and proteomic changes in mouse brain after spaceflight were characterized.
Twenty-six proteins were significantly altered after spaceflight in gray and/or white matter.
No overlap was found between white and gray matter in terms of individual proteins, but overlap was found in terms of function.
Proteins related to synaptic plasticity, vesicle formation, and endocytosis were upregulated in gray matter.
Proteins involved in myelination, protein transport, and metabolism were also altered after spaceflight.
Changes in protein expression may lead to significant impacts on brain structural and functional integrity.
The study's findings provide new insights into the biological response to space environment and may inform risk assessment for future long-term space travel.

nodes.title: HSFA2 Functions in the Physiological Adaptation of Undifferentiated Plant Cells to Spaceflight
nodes.summary:
HSFA2 plays a crucial role in the physiological adaptation of undifferentiated plant cells to spaceflight.
The HSF network is essential for spaceflight adaptation, and HSFA2 has specific roles in cell wall remodeling and signal perception.
Disabling HsfA2 alters the physiological state of cells and impacts mechanisms induced to adapt to spaceflight.
HSFA2-dependent genes are important for the adaptation of wild-type cells to spaceflight.
The endoplasmic reticulum stress and unfolded protein response define the HSFA2 KO cells' physiological state.
HSFA2 has a role in the regulation of cell wall and plasma membrane signaling, as well as starch biosynthesis.
The HSFA2 KO cells helped to identify a set of genes with a required expression level for a cell to achieve the spaceflight-adapted state.

nodes.title: GeneLab Database Analyses Suggest Long-Term Impact of Space Radiation on the Cardiovascular System by the Activation of FYN Through Reactive Oxygen Species
nodes.summary:
Space radiation has a long-term impact on the cardiovascular system by activating FYN through reactive oxygen species.
The GeneLab database was used to analyze the effects of space radiation on cardiomyocytes and endothelial cells.
The analysis suggests that FYN is the central driver for the cardiovascular response to space radiation.
The activation of FYN reduces reactive oxygen species levels, protecting the cardiovascular system.
The study also found that protons have a stronger overlap with spaceflight samples than 56 Fe ions.
The key driving genes associated with space radiation provide a direct connection to ROS and the cardiovascular system.
The predicted circulating miRNA signature is associated with space radiation cardiovascular risk.

nodes.title: Mice Exposed to Combined Chronic Low-Dose Irradiation and Modeled Microgravity Develop Long-Term Neurological Sequelae
nodes.summary:
Mice were exposed to chronic low-dose irradiation (LDR) and/or modeled microgravity via hindlimb unloading (HLU) for 21 days. 
The effects of LDR and HLU on the central nervous system (CNS) were assessed after 4 months of readaptation. 
Gene expression and epigenetic modifications in brain samples were analyzed using RNA-seq and reduced representation bisulfite sequencing (RRBS). 
Minimal gene expression and cytosine methylation alterations were observed in single treatment conditions of HLU or LDR. 
In contrast, combined HLU+LDR exposure resulted in multiple altered pathways involved in neurogenesis, neuroplasticity, and cellular signaling. 
The results suggest that neurological readaptation following combined chronic LDR and HLU is a dynamic process that may lead to late-onset neurological sequelae. 
Brain-related transcriptional changes during readaptation from exposure to spaceflight-like conditions may lead to long-term neurological consequences.

nodes.title: Cell Type-Specific Imaging of Calcium Signaling in Arabidopsis thaliana Seedling Roots Using GCaMP3
nodes.summary:
Arabidopsis thaliana lines expressing GCaMP3 in specific root cell types were generated.
These lines allow for cell-type specific imaging of calcium signaling in roots.
The GCaMP3 lines were tested with various chemical treatments, including ATP, glutamate, and aluminum.
The lines showed similarities and differences in calcium signatures in response to these treatments.
The cell-type specific GCaMP3 lines provide a new resource for studying calcium signaling in roots.
These lines can be used to investigate the role of calcium in root development and stress response.
The lines can also be used to study the direction of calcium signal propagation within roots.

nodes.title: Changes in Nuclear Shape and Gene Expression in Response to Simulated Microgravity Are LINC Complex-Dependent
nodes.summary:
The LINC complex plays a crucial role in regulating nuclear morphology in breast epithelial cells exposed to simulated microgravity.
Nuclear shape changes in response to simulated microgravity depend on the LINC complex.
The LINC complex is required for the normal nuclear shape change to simulated microgravity.
Disruption of the LINC complex leads to a lack of nuclear shape change normally observed in cells with intact LINC function.
The LINC complex plays a role in regulating gene expression in response to simulated microgravity.
LINC-dependent genes are up- and down-regulated in response to simulated microgravity, depending on the duration of exposure.
The LINC complex may be required for maintaining transcriptional homeostasis of some genes in the presence of simulated microgravity.

nodes.title: Spaceflight Modulates the Expression of Key Oxidative Stress and Cell Cycle Related Genes in Heart
nodes.summary:
Spaceflight alters the expression of key genes related to oxidative stress and cell cycle regulation in the heart.
The study found that 15 days of spaceflight changed the expression of 37 out of 168 genes tested in mouse heart tissue.
Spaceflight downregulated the transcription factor Nfe2l2 and upregulated Nox1, suggesting increased oxidative stress.
The study also found changes in cell cycle-related genes, including upregulation of Cdkn1a and Myc.
These changes may contribute to cardiac dysfunction during long-duration spaceflight.
The findings provide new insights into the molecular mechanisms underlying cardiac responses to spaceflight.
The study's results have implications for the development of countermeasures to mitigate the effects of spaceflight on the heart.

nodes.title: Mammalian and Invertebrate Models as Complementary Tools for Gaining Mechanistic Insight on Muscle Responses to Spaceflight
nodes.summary:
Spaceflight leads to shared and discrete molecular responses between muscle types. 
The EDL muscle showed more robust growth signals and Pde2a downregulation, possibly underlying its resistance to atrophy. 
Spaceflight responses of C. elegans were more similar to EDL, while discrete life stages of D. melanogaster have distinct utility in anticipating EDL and soleus responses. 
Invertebrate models may augment mechanistic knowledge gained from rodent spaceflight and ground-based studies. 
Shared gene regulation in muscles of humans on bedrest and space-flown rodents suggest targets for mitigating muscle atrophy in space and on Earth. 
The life stage of invertebrate models appears to impact the degree by which they recapitulate the responses of mammalian tissues to spaceflight. 
Differential regulation of ECM-related processes was observed in C. elegans, D. melanogaster, and rodent EDL in response to spaceflight.

nodes.title: Extraterrestrial Gynecology: Could Spaceflight Increase the Risk of Developing Cancer in Female Astronauts? An Updated Review
nodes.summary:
Spaceflight poses significant risks to female astronauts, including increased exposure to ionizing radiation and microgravity. 
These factors can potentially increase the risk of developing cancer, particularly gynecological cancers. 
The female reproductive system is highly sensitive to radiation, and exposure can lead to temporary or permanent infertility. 
Microgravity can also affect the female reproductive system, with studies showing altered cell morphology and gene expression in ovarian and endometrial cells. 
Current research is limited, and more studies are needed to understand the effects of spaceflight on gynecological cancer risk. 
The development of countermeasures, such as shielding and pharmacological interventions, is crucial to protecting female astronauts from the harmful effects of space radiation. 
Further research is necessary to ensure the safety and health of female astronauts on long-duration space missions.

nodes.title: Space Microgravity Alters Neural Stem Cell Division: Implications for Brain Cancer Research on Earth and in Space
nodes.summary:
Space microgravity alters neural stem cell division, leading to abnormal cell division.
This abnormal cell division includes incomplete cell division and multi-daughter cell division.
The secretome produced by neural stem cells in space induces similar effects on naive cells.
Abnormal cell division increases over time after space flight, with significant differences at two weeks post-flight.
The secreted protein acidic and rich in cysteine (SPARC) is the most enriched molecule in the secretome.
SPARC may play a role in cancer, and its expression is affected by microgravity.
Understanding the effects of microgravity on neural stem cells is crucial for long-term space travel and brain cancer research.

nodes.title: A New Role of NAP1L1 in Megakaryocytes and Human Platelets
nodes.summary:
NAP1L1 is expressed in human platelets and megakaryocytes, 
with alternative transcript variants and protein isoforms present. 
NAP1L1 interacts with PDC-E2, a subunit of the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex. 
In septic platelets, NAP1L1 expression increases, 
while PDC-E2 expression decreases, and pyruvate dehydrogenase complex activity increases. 
Overexpression of NAP1L1 in megakaryocytes reduces proplatelet formation, 
suggesting a role for NAP1L1 in regulating energy metabolism and thrombopoiesis. 
These findings provide new insights into the functions of NAP1L1 in platelets and megakaryocytes.

nodes.title: Low-Speed Clinorotation of Brachypodium distachyon and Arabidopsis thaliana Seedlings Triggers Root Tip Curvatures That Are Reminiscent of Gravitropism
nodes.summary:
Low-speed clinorotation triggers root tip curvatures in Arabidopsis thaliana and Brachypodium distachyon seedlings. 
The direction and degree of curvature are dictated by the polarity and period of rotation. 
Mutations affecting early steps of gravity sensing and signal transduction alter the clinostat effect on root growth direction. 
The clinostat effect is associated with the formation of a lateral auxin gradient across the root tip. 
PIN3 protein relocalization occurs on the side of the columella cells directed toward gravity during the first half-turn of clinorotation. 
The realization time, defined as the minimal period of half-turn clinorotation needed to set up a polarity of tip curvature response, is estimated to be around 35 s. 
The results suggest that gravitropism contributes to the clinostat effect on root growth direction under low-speed clinorotation.

nodes.title: Evidence of Spaceflight-Induced Adverse Effects on Photoreceptors and Retinal Function in the Mouse Eye
nodes.summary:
Spaceflight induces oxidative stress and damage to photoreceptors and retinal function in mice.
The study used a mouse model to investigate the effects of spaceflight on the retina and retinal function.
Mice were flown aboard the International Space Station for 35 days and received a weekly injection of an antioxidant.
The results showed significant increases in retinal oxidative stress and apoptotic cell death after spaceflight.
Electroretinogram (ERG) data revealed decreased amplitudes of a- and b-waves, indicating photoreceptor damage and retinal function impairment.
The antioxidant treatment reduced oxidative stress but had limited effects on apoptosis and retinal function.
The study suggests that spaceflight-induced oxidative stress may lead to long-term effects on visual acuity and retinal health.

nodes.title: The Impact of SRT2104 on Skeletal Muscle Mitochondrial Function, Redox Biology, and Loss of Muscle Mass in Hindlimb Unloaded Rats
nodes.summary:
SRT2104 preserves mitochondrial function in unloaded skeletal muscle.
It reduces integrative proton leak in unloaded gastrocnemius muscles.
SRT2104 increases cytochrome c oxidase activity compared to unloaded gastrocnemius.
Intrinsic O2 flux is increased by SRT2104 and FCR leak is reduced.
H2O2 flux and concentration increase with SRT2104 intervention, concomitant with increased superoxide dismutase.
SRT2104 attenuates skeletal muscle atrophy during unloading, suggesting its potential to support healthy muscle cells in microgravity.

nodes.title: Spaceflight-Induced Gene Expression Profiles in the Mouse Brain Are Attenuated by Treatment with the Antioxidant BuOE
nodes.summary:
Spaceflight affects the central nervous system and poses a health risk. 
Gene expression profiles in the mouse brain are altered by spaceflight. 
Four brain regions were analyzed: Cortex, Frontal Cortex, Corunu Ammonis I, and Dentate Gyrus. 
The antioxidant BuOE attenuates spaceflight-induced gene expression changes. 
BuOE reduces oxidative stress-induced brain damage caused by spaceflight. 
Pathways sensitive to oxidative stress are enriched in the four brain regions due to spaceflight. 
BuOE treatment may mitigate the effects of spaceflight on the brain.

nodes.title: Bone Marrow Adipose Tissue Is Not Required for Reconstitution of the Immune System Following Irradiation in Male Mice
nodes.summary:
Bone marrow adipose tissue (BMAT) is not required for reconstitution of the immune system following irradiation in male mice.
Adoptive transfer of WT hematopoietic stem cells (HSCs) was effective in reconstituting the immune systems of both WT and BMAT-deficient mice.
The absence of BMAT had little or no influence on the reconstitution of immune, osteoblast, or osteoclast cell populations following lethal radiation.
BMAT-deficient mice had lower body weight, white adipose tissue weight, and seminal vesicle weight compared to WT mice.
There were few differences in bone parameters, including length, mass, density, and microarchitecture, between WT and BMAT-deficient mice.
The findings suggest that BMAT is not essential for recovery from severe bone marrow injury and that kit signaling plays a crucial role in bone turnover balance.

nodes.title: Effect of Simulated Cosmic Radiation on Cytomegalovirus Reactivation and Lytic Replication
nodes.summary:
Galactic cosmic radiation (GCR) may cause adverse health effects in astronauts. 
Cytomegalovirus (CMV) reactivation is a concern due to its prevalence and potential consequences. 
This study examined the effect of simulated GCR on CMV reactivation and lytic replication. 
Latently infected Kasumi cells were irradiated with various types of radiation, including GCR. 
The results showed a significant increase in CMV viral load in irradiated cells compared to controls. 
Transcriptome analysis revealed upregulation of the UL49 gene, which may play a role in CMV reactivation. 
These findings suggest that GCR may contribute to CMV reactivation in astronauts during space missions.

nodes.title: Effect of Simulated Cosmic Radiation on Cytomegalovirus Reactivation and Lytic Replication
nodes.summary:
Galactic cosmic radiation (GCR) may cause adverse health effects in astronauts. 
Cytomegalovirus (CMV) reactivation is a concern due to its prevalence and potential consequences. 
This study examined the effect of simulated GCR on CMV reactivation and lytic replication. 
Latently infected Kasumi cells were irradiated with various types of radiation, including GCR. 
The results showed a significant increase in CMV viral load in irradiated cells compared to controls. 
Transcriptome analysis revealed upregulation of the UL49 gene, which may play a role in CMV reactivation. 
These findings suggest that GCR may contribute to CMV reactivation in astronauts during space missions.

nodes.title: Artificial Gravity Attenuates the Transcriptomic Response to Spaceflight in the Optic Nerve and Retina
nodes.summary:
Spaceflight induces transcriptomic changes in the optic nerve and retina of mice.
These changes involve oxidative stress, inflammation, apoptosis, and lipid metabolic stress.
Artificial gravity (AG) attenuates the transcriptomic response to spaceflight in a dose-dependent manner.
AG at 1 G provides the strongest attenuation of spaceflight-induced gene expression changes.
The p53 signaling pathway is among the top pathways enriched by pathway analysis in the optic nerve and retina.
AG attenuates the alteration of genes within the p53 signaling pathway and other pathways.
The use of AG may help mitigate the effects of microgravity on ocular tissue during spaceflight.

nodes.title: Genome-Wide Analysis of the PERK Gene Family in Brassica napus L. and Their Potential Roles in Clubroot Disease
nodes.summary:
Fifty PERK genes were identified in Brassica napus, 
exhibiting significant structural diversity and potential functional specialization.
These genes were grouped into four classes and unevenly distributed across 18 chromosomes.
Phylogenetic studies revealed purifying selection during evolution, 
with conserved tyrosine kinase domains suggesting functional importance.
Expression profiling showed diverse patterns across tissues and hormone treatments, 
highlighting potential roles in growth regulation and hormone signaling.
The transcriptional downregulation of four BnPERK genes upon Plasmodiophora brassicae infection 
implied a role in clubroot disease response, with potential applications in crop improvement.

nodes.title: Microgravity and Cellular Biology: Insights into Cellular Responses and Implications for Human Health
nodes.summary:
Microgravity significantly impacts biological systems, including the immune system, by disrupting key mechanisms such as T cell activation and cytokine production. 
It promotes the formation of spheroids in cancer stem cells, providing insights into tumor dynamics and potential therapeutic approaches. 
Microgravity enhances tissue regeneration by modulating critical pathways, improving stem cell differentiation into various lineages. 
At the organ level, microgravity induces changes in hepatic metabolism, endothelial function, and bone mechanotransduction, contributing to lipid dysregulation and bone loss. 
Cardiomyocytes derived from human pluripotent stem cells exhibit enhanced mitochondrial biogenesis and improved calcium handling under microgravity conditions. 
These findings have implications for space medicine and terrestrial health, highlighting the potential of microgravity to drive advances in regenerative therapies and oncology.
