Overall, microgravity research underscores the need for continued investigation into its effects on human biology to protect astronaut health and foster biomedical innovations.

nodes.title: Molecular Mechanism of Microgravity-Induced Intestinal Flora Dysbiosis on the Abnormalities of Liver and Brain Metabolism
nodes.summary:
Microgravity affects the gut microbiota of mice, leading to changes in lipid and amino acid metabolism.
The altered gut microbiota causes metabolic disorders in the liver and brain.
Fecal microbiota transplantation reproduces the characteristics of gut microbiota under microgravity.
The study suggests that microgravity-induced gut microbiota imbalance leads to liver and brain metabolic disorders.
Valeric acid, a metabolite of gut microbiota, may be a key factor in microgravity-induced metabolic disorders.

nodes.title: New perspectives on viable microbial communities in low-biomass cleanroom environments
nodes.summary:
investigated the viable microbial communities in low-biomass cleanroom environments.
The research used propidium monoazide (PMA) treatment coupled with pyrosequencing and PhyloChip DNA microarray analyses.
Results showed that only 1% to 10% of pyrosequencing reads originated from viable bacterial lineages.
The viable bacterial population in cleanrooms without spacecraft hardware was more diverse than in those with hardware.
Hardy, robust organisms dominated the population in cleanrooms with spacecraft hardware.
The study demonstrated the effectiveness of PMA treatment in assessing viability of microbial cells in low-biomass environments.

nodes.title: Ionizing Radiation Stimulates Expression of Pro-Osteoclastogenic Genes in Marrow and Skeletal Tissue
nodes.summary:
Ionizing radiation stimulates expression of pro-osteoclastogenic genes in marrow and skeletal tissue.
Exposure to ionizing radiation causes rapid mineral loss and increases bone-resorbing osteoclasts.
The study examined the temporal expression of Rankl and select pro-osteoclastogenic cytokines following exposure to low- or high-LET species of radiation.
Radiation exposure increased gene expression for the canonical osteoclastogenic factor, Rankl, as well as other pro-osteoclast cytokines.
Changes in cytokine expression were temporally related to changes in several indices of bone resorption, including gene expression and a serum biomarker.
The results demonstrate that radiation-induced structural changes were associated with a marrow environment favoring stimulation of osteoclast differentiation and activity.

nodes.title: Bone shaft bending strength index is unaffected by exercise and unloading in mice
nodes.summary:
Mice were treated with treadmill exercise or hindlimb unloading to simulate high- and low-activity lifestyles. 
Exercise increased femoral mid-shaft I max and I min, but not the I max /I min bending strength index. 
Unloading stunted bone growth, resulting in diminished I max and I min, but did not alter the I max /I min index. 
The results suggest that activity level does not have a predictable effect on the shaft bending strength index. 
This challenges the common assumption in anthropological analyses that elliptical shafts indicate high activity levels. 
The findings imply that caution is needed when using the bone shaft bending strength index to infer activity levels in past humans. 
The study's results have implications for the interpretation of human skeletal remains and the reconstruction of past human activity levels.

nodes.title: Genomic Characterization of the Titan-like Cell Producing Naganishia tulchinskyi, the First Novel Eukaryote Isolated from the International Space Station
nodes.summary:
Naganishia tulchinskyi is a novel yeast species isolated from the International Space Station.
It exhibits Titan-like cell morphology under simulated microgravity and 5% CO2 conditions.
Phylogenetic analysis reveals it is closely related to Naganishia diffluens but distinct enough to be a new species.
The species has a genome size of ~19.4 Mbp with a GC content of 53-56%.
Genomic analysis suggests the presence of genes related to cold resistance, radiation tolerance, and microgravity.
The species can assimilate various carbon sources and has distinct biochemical characteristics.
It has been isolated from different locations on the ISS across multiple sampling sessions.

nodes.title: Real-time In Vivo Recording of Arabidopsis Calcium Signals During Insect Feeding Using a Fluorescent Biosensor
nodes.summary:
Calcium ions play a key role in plant defense responses to biotic interactions, including insect feeding.
A genetically-encoded calcium sensor, GCaMP3, is used to detect calcium signals in Arabidopsis plants during aphid feeding.
The sensor allows for real-time imaging of plant calcium dynamics with high spatial and temporal resolution.
Aphid feeding induces a highly-localized rapid calcium elevation around the feeding site within a few minutes.
The protocol can be adapted to study other biotic stresses, such as additional insect species and microbial pathogens.
The use of Arabidopsis thaliana enables rapid generation of mutants for molecular analysis of the phenomenon.
The method provides a relative measurement of calcium concentration, allowing for characterization of calcium signals during biotic stress.

nodes.title: Multi-analyte Biochip (MAB) Based on All-solid-state Ion-selective Electrodes (ASSISE) for Physiological Research
nodes.summary:
The multi-analyte biochip (MAB) is a lab-on-a-chip device that utilizes all-solid-state ion-selective electrodes (ASSISE) for physiological research.
It consists of a noble-metal electrode layer, a transduction layer, and an ion-selective membrane (ISM) layer.
The MAB can monitor pH, CO3 2-, and Ca 2+ ions in a lab-on-a-chip format.
Calibrations in test solutions demonstrated that the MAB can provide near-Nernstian slope responses for pH and log-linear range responses for Ca 2+.
The MAB conveys an advantage in size, versatility, and multiplexed analyte sensing capability.
The biochip design includes 9 ASSISEs and 5 Ag/AgCl reference electrodes, with each working electrode connected to electrical contact pads.
The MAB has potential applications in environmental, biomedical, agricultural, biological, and spaceflight research.

nodes.title: Multiparameter Behavioral Analyses Provide Insights to Mechanisms of Cyanide Resistance in Caenorhabditis elegans
nodes.summary:
Cyanide toxicity affects development, behavior, and survival in Caenorhabditis elegans.
EGL-9 oxygen sensing enzyme deficiency confers resistance to hydrogen cyanide gas.
HIF-1 hypoxia-inducible factor mediates cyanide resistance in egl-9 mutants.
Cysl-2 cysteine synthase expression correlates with cyanide resistance in egl-9 mutants.
Microfluidic assays provide high spatiotemporal resolution for analyzing cyanide toxicity.
Real-time imaging and worm tracking software enable quantitative analysis of behavior.

nodes.title: The fast and the furious: rapid long-range signaling in plants
nodes.summary:
Plants have evolved complex systems to monitor and respond to their environment, 
integrating local and systemic signaling to coordinate physiology and development. 
Rapid long-range signaling in plants involves electrical, ionic, and hydraulic signals, 
including action potentials and variation potentials that propagate through the plant. 
GLRs and CNGCs are critical elements in systemic wound signaling, 
with GLRs acting as ligand-gated cation channels and CNGCs as Ca2+ permeable channels. 
ROS waves also play a key role in systemic signaling, 
with RBOHD and RBOHF producing ROS that propagate through the plant. 
Systemic signals trigger various responses, including stomatal closure and gene expression changes, 
with Ca2+ and ROS acting as key signaling molecules. 
Further research is needed to fully understand the molecular mechanisms underlying systemic signaling in plants.

nodes.title: The vacuolar H + /Ca transporter CAX1 participates in submergence and anoxia stress responses
nodes.summary:
CAX1, a vacuolar H+/Ca transporter, plays a crucial role in plant responses to anoxia and submergence.
Cax1 mutants exhibit enhanced tolerance to anoxic conditions and submergence due to altered metabolic processes.
The cax1 mutants display reduced reactive oxygen species production and altered hormone signaling post-anoxia.
Transcriptomic and proteomic analyses reveal changes in gene expression and protein abundance in cax1 mutants.
CAX1 regulates cytosolic Ca levels during reoxygenation, influencing anoxia tolerance and stress responses.
The study highlights the importance of tonoplast-localized Ca transport in plant stress responses and anoxia tolerance.
CAX1's role in anoxia tolerance is complex, involving multiple signaling pathways and metabolic processes.

nodes.title: Spatial and temporal localization of SPIRRIG and WAVE/SCAR reveal roles for these proteins in actin-mediated root hair development
nodes.summary:
Root hairs in Arabidopsis thaliana undergo tip growth, a process mediated by the actin cytoskeleton and endomembrane systems. 
SPIRRIG (SPI) and the WAVE/SCAR (W/SC) complex are involved in this process, with SPI localizing to the root hair tip and W/SC components BRK1 and SCAR2 marking the root hair initiation domain. 
SPI is transported to the root hair tip via post-Golgi compartments and maintains the tip-focused fine F-actin meshwork, which is essential for root hair elongation. 
BRK1 and SCAR2 are molecular determinants of the root hair initiation domain, specifying the position of root hair emergence. 
The depletion of BRK1 from the root hair initiation domain is mediated by SPI, suggesting a functional relationship between SPI and the W/SC complex during root hair development. 
Overall, the study reveals the spatial and temporal localization of SPI and W/SC components in root hairs, shedding light on their roles in actin-mediated root hair development.

nodes.title: Host-Microbe Interactions in Microgravity: Assessment and Implications
nodes.summary:
Spaceflight imposes unique stresses on biological life, including microgravity, which alters host-microbe interactions at genetic and physiological levels. 
Microgravity affects both pathogenic and mutualistic microbes, with changes in growth rate, membrane integrity, and gene expression. 
In animal-microbe associations, microgravity can increase pathogenicity and alter the host's immune response. 
Mutualistic interactions, such as the squid-vibrio symbiosis, are also affected by microgravity, with changes in colonization and morphogenesis. 
Plant-microbe associations are impacted by microgravity, with increased susceptibility to plant pathogens and altered rhizosphere microbiome. 
Understanding the effects of microgravity on host-microbe interactions is crucial for maintaining a healthy homeostasis between humans, plants, and their respective microbiomes. 
Further research is needed to elucidate the mechanisms underlying these changes and to develop strategies for mitigating the negative effects of microgravity on host-microbe interactions.

nodes.title: Simultaneous Exposure of Cultured Human Lymphoblastic Cells to Simulated Microgravity and Radiation Increases Chromosome Aberrations
nodes.summary:
Astronauts on deep-space missions are exposed to microgravity and ionizing radiation, which can increase cancer risk and negatively affect various bodily systems. 
This study investigated the combined effects of simulated microgravity and radiation on human lymphoblastic TK6 cells. 
Cells were exposed to X-ray or carbon ion radiation under microgravity or static conditions, and chromosome aberrations were analyzed. 
The results showed a higher frequency of chromosome aberrations in cells exposed to radiation and microgravity simultaneously. 
The study suggests that space radiation risk assessment based on experiments at 1G may underestimate astronauts' potential risk for cancer and other health conditions. 
Carbon ion irradiation induced a higher frequency of complex chromosome aberrations compared to X-ray irradiation at the same cell survival fraction dose. 
The occurrence of complex chromosome aberrations was higher in TK6 cells than in human fibroblasts used in similar studies.

nodes.title: Approaching Gravity as a Continuum Using the Rat Partial Weight-Bearing Model
nodes.summary:
The rat partial weight-bearing model is used to study the effects of partial gravity on physiology.
This model is essential for understanding the risks and consequences of space travel.
The model has been adapted from a mouse model and has undergone technical adjustments for use with rats.
It allows for the investigation of gravity as a continuum and the simulation of partial gravity environments.
The model has been used to study the effects of partial gravity on the musculoskeletal, skeletal, and cardiovascular systems.
It has also been used to investigate the effects of partial gravity on behavior, stress, and food intake.
The model provides a reliable and adaptable method for studying the effects of partial gravity on physiology.
It will play a critical role in unraveling the complex relationships between human physiology and spaceflight.

nodes.title: Mechanotransduction in Prokaryotes: A Possible Mechanism of Spaceflight Adaptation
nodes.summary:
Prokaryotes have been found to possess structures analogous to mechanosensitive structures in eukaryotes.
These structures include cytoskeletal proteins and nucleoid-associated proteins that play a role in mechanosensing and mechanotransduction.
Mechanosensing in prokaryotes involves the perception of mechanical forces such as fluid flow, pressure, and contact with surfaces or other cells.
Prokaryotic cytoskeletal proteins are involved in cell growth, division, and DNA segregation, and may play a role in mechanotransduction.
The prokaryotic nucleoid is a highly condensed structure that must allow the replication and transcription machinery to access specific genes.
DNA supercoiling and epigenetic modification of DNA are also important mechanisms that may be involved in prokaryotic mechanotransduction.
The authors propose a model of prokaryotic mechanotransduction that involves the cytoskeletal apparatus, nucleoid architecture, and global transcriptional apparatus.

nodes.title: Knowledge Network Embedding of Transcriptomic Data from Spaceflown Mice Uncovers Signs and Symptoms Associated with Terrestrial Diseases
nodes.summary:
NASA GeneLab provides a repository of multi-omics data from spaceflight studies to understand physiological changes during space travel.
The Scalable Precision Medicine Oriented Knowledge Engine (SPOKE) is a knowledge graph that connects biological and clinical data from over 30 databases.
SPOKE was used to integrate data from six NASA GeneLab datasets to identify critical symptoms and physiological changes incurred during spaceflight.
The study found that spaceflight alters gene expression in mice, leading to changes in biological processes, cellular components, and molecular functions.
The top nodes identified in the study were enriched for phenotypes and physiological changes known to be impacted by spaceflight, such as space motion sickness and regulation of blood vessel diameter.
The results suggest that SPOKE can be used to gain a deeper understanding of the health hazards associated with spaceflight and provide a proof of concept for its broader utilization to integrate space and terrestrial biological data.
The study's findings have implications for the development of personalized risk predictions and treatments for astronauts on long-duration deep space missions.

nodes.title: Growth and Antifungal Resistance of the Pathogenic Yeast, Candida Albicans, in the Microgravity Environment of the International Space Station: An Aggregate of Multiple Flight Experiences
nodes.summary:
Candida albicans grows to a higher density in microgravity than in terrestrial control conditions.
The yeast exhibits increased resistance to the antifungal agent Amphotericin B in microgravity.
Cells cultivated in microgravity do not exhibit a significant filamentation response.
Colony architecture is similar between samples cultivated in microgravity and terrestrial controls.
Yeast cells grown in microgravity are more susceptible to freeze damage in the absence of a cryopreservation agent.
The microgravity environment does not induce a complex colony morphology in Candida albicans.
The increased resistance to Amphotericin B is not broad-spectrum, as cells remain susceptible to Caspofungin.

nodes.title: Evaluating Ocular Response in the Retina and Optic Nerve Head after Single and Fractionated High-Energy Protons
nodes.summary:
Proton radiation exposure induced significant changes in oxidative stress, apoptosis, and blood-retina barrier integrity in the mouse retina. 
A single dose of 0.5 Gy proton radiation caused increased apoptosis and oxidative damage in the retina and optic nerve head. 
Fractionated doses of proton radiation also induced apoptosis and oxidative damage, but to a lesser extent than the single dose. 
The expression of blood-retina barrier biomarkers, including AQP-4, PECAM-1, and ZO-1, was altered in the retina after proton radiation exposure. 
The optic nerve head region showed limited immunoreactivity for AQP-4 and ZO-1, indicating possible lack of blood-retina barrier properties. 
Proton radiation exposure disrupted the integrity of the blood-retina barrier, leading to potential edema formation and inflammation. 
The study's findings have implications for understanding the effects of space radiation on the ocular tissue and developing countermeasures for deep-space missions.

nodes.title: Simulated Microgravity Promotes Horizontal Gene Transfer of Antimicrobial Resistance Genes between Bacterial Genera in the Absence of Antibiotic Selective Pressure
nodes.summary:
Bacteria can adapt to harsh environments through horizontal gene transfer (HGT), a process that spreads antimicrobial resistance (AMR) genes.
Simulated microgravity (SMG) promotes HGT of AMR genes between bacterial genera in the absence of antibiotic selective pressure.
Four strains of Staphylococcus aureus acquired resistance to oxacillin after co-culture with Acinetobacter pittii under SMG.
The efficiency of gene transfer under SMG was higher than under normal gravity conditions.
The acquired resistance was stable even after multiple sub-cultures, posing a significant threat to astronaut health on long-duration space missions.
Increased HGT under SMG could be due to increased competence or transduction, but the exact mechanism needs further investigation.
The findings have significant implications for understanding bacterial interactions in space and developing countermeasures for long-duration space missions.

nodes.title: Uncovering Transcriptional Responses to Fractional Gravity in Arabidopsis Roots
nodes.summary:
Plant growth in space is crucial for long-duration missions to supplement crew nutrition and provide psychological benefits. 
The European Modular Cultivation System onboard the International Space Station was used to study Arabidopsis roots under microgravity and fractional gravity conditions. 
A gradient of fractional gravity from 0.53 to 0.88 g was applied to the roots, and transcriptional profiling was performed to identify differentially expressed genes. 
101 genes showed a response to fractional gravity, including transcription factors, defense-related genes, cell wall-related genes, and heat shock proteins. 
These genes exhibited different patterns of expression, including linear, peak, and threshold responses to fractional gravity. 
The results highlight the importance of understanding plant responses to altered gravity for future space missions and potential colonization of the Moon and Mars. 
The study provides valuable insights into how plants sense and respond to gravity, which can inform strategies for optimizing plant growth in space.

nodes.title: Spatial Characterization of Microbial Communities on Multi-Species Leafy Greens Grown Simultaneously in the Vegetable Production Systems on the International Space Station
nodes.summary:
Microbial communities on leafy greens grown in the Veggie facility on the ISS were characterized.
The study found low bacterial and fungal counts on the leaves and surfaces of the Veggie facility.
Burkholderia, Pseudomonas, and Ralstonia were among the dominant bacterial genera identified.
Fungal species such as Aspergillus, Fusarium, and Penicillium were also detected.
The results suggest that the microbiome of the ISS-grown crops is influenced by the ISS environment.
The study highlights the importance of characterizing the microbiome of space-grown crops for food safety and sustainability.

nodes.title: Response of Arabidopsis thaliana and Mizuna Mustard Seeds to Simulated Space Radiation Exposures
nodes.summary:
Arabidopsis thaliana and Mizuna mustard seeds were exposed to simulated space radiation.
The seeds were exposed to protons, titanium ions, and simulated galactic cosmic rays (GCR).
The effects of radiation on seed germination, viability, and morphology were evaluated.
Hydrated seeds were more sensitive to radiation damage than dry seeds.
The extent of damage depended on the seed type, dose, and radiation quality.
Heavier ions caused more severe damage, and low-dose rate exposures had less impact.
The study's findings have implications for long-duration space missions and food production in space.

nodes.title: Understanding the Complexities and Changes of the Astronaut Microbiome for Successful Long-Duration Space Missions
nodes.summary:
Astronauts face unique challenges during space missions, including changes to their microbiome. 
The human microbiome plays a crucial role in regulating health and behavior, and alterations can lead to various diseases. 
Spaceflight conditions, such as microgravity and radiation, can induce changes in microbiome composition and function. 
These changes can affect immune function, metabolism, and overall health, making it essential to understand the impact of space travel on the microbiome. 
Research has shown that spaceflight can alter the gut microbiome, leading to changes in bacterial diversity and abundance. 
The skin, oropharyngeal, and nasal microbiomes are also affected, with changes in microbial composition and diversity. 
Understanding the effects of spaceflight on the microbiome is critical for maintaining astronaut health and preventing disease during long-duration missions.

nodes.title: CAMDLES: CFD-DEM Simulation of Microbial Communities in Spaceflight and Artificial Microgravity
nodes.summary:
CAMDLES is a computational model that simulates microbial communities in spaceflight and artificial microgravity.
It integrates fluid and particle dynamics with biological metabolism and growth to predict community dynamics.
The model was tested on a community of Escherichia coli and Salmonella enterica, which exchange metabolites for growth.
Results showed that co-localization of species is necessary for high growth rates in microgravity.
The model also demonstrated that rotating wall vessels can increase metabolite utilization rates, but may not accurately replicate microgravity conditions.
Overall, CAMDLES provides a framework for understanding microbial community behavior in microgravity environments.
It has the potential to serve as a basis for demystifying inconsistencies between rotating wall vessels and microgravity.

nodes.title: Enabling Clonal Analyses of Yeast in Outer Space by Encapsulation and Desiccation in Hollow Microparticles
nodes.summary:
Desiccated PicoShells enable clonal analyses of yeast in outer space by encapsulating single cells in hollow microparticles.
The desiccation method preserves particle morphology and yeast health after storage and rehydration.
PicoShells can withstand physical manipulations and maintain similar porosity and diffusion characteristics as non-desiccated particles.
Yeast desiccated and rehydrated in PicoShells show high viability over 8.5 weeks of storage but a decline in growth potential.
The technology offers a simple and low-resource workflow for single-cell analysis in space biology research.
Desiccated PicoShells can be used for various applications, including strain engineering and model organism studies.
The method has potential for automated and autonomous workflows, making it suitable for uncrewed missions.

nodes.title: Simulated Micro-, Lunar, and Martian Gravities on Earth-Effects on Escherichia coli Growth, Phenotype, and Sensitivity to Antibiotics
nodes.summary:
Escherichia coli growth dynamics were studied under simulated micro-, lunar, and Martian gravities.
The study used inclined clinostats and a code to determine optimal clinorotation angular speed.
Three E. coli strains were examined, including a uropathogenic strain, under different gravitational conditions.
Results showed increased growth under simulated micro- and lunar gravities for some strains.
Higher concentrations of antibiotics were needed under simulated lunar gravity compared to micro- and Martian gravities.
The study's findings suggest potential implications for bacterial behavior in space environments and antibiotic efficacy.

nodes.title: Red Light Enhances Plant Adaptation to Spaceflight and Mars g-Levels
nodes.summary:
Plants can survive and grow in space, but microgravity alters their development and physiology.
Red light enhances plant adaptation to spaceflight and Mars g-levels by reverting gene reprogramming.
The combination of microgravity and red light photoactivation is not recognized as stressful by seedlings.
Mutant lines of nucleolin exhibit differential requirements in response to red light photoactivation.
Red light photoactivation can improve seedling viability in space by counteracting gravitational stress.
The Mars gravity level induces a more adaptive response than microgravity, with upregulation of stress-related genes.
Red light illumination can be used to improve plant culture in space and enhance plant adaptation to microgravity.

nodes.title: Lipid Rafts and Plant Gravisensitivity
nodes.summary:
Plant cells have complex mechanisms to sense and respond to gravity and other environmental stimuli.
Lipid rafts are membrane microdomains that play a crucial role in cell signaling and responses to stress.
The composition and structure of lipid rafts are affected by changes in gravity and mechanostimulation.
Clinorotation increases the cholesterol and saturated fatty acid content of lipid rafts in plant cells.
This increase in cholesterol and saturated fatty acids leads to changes in membrane permeability and fluidity.
The altered membrane properties affect cell metabolism and responses to environmental stimuli.
Lipid rafts are involved in the regulation of mechanosensitive ion channels and the organization of the cytoskeleton.

nodes.title: Mitochondria-Targeted Human Catalase in the Mouse Longevity MCAT Model Mitigates Head-Tilt Bedrest-Induced Neuro-Inflammation in the Hippocampus
nodes.summary:
Microgravity experienced during spaceflight results in neurological consequences and CNS dysfunction.
Hindlimb unloading in mice leads to increased microglial activation in the hippocampus, indicated by elevated CD68 levels.
Mitochondrial ROS quenching in MCAT mice mitigates HU-induced microglial activation and reduces cytokine expression.
Correlations between microglial activation, cytokine expression, and behavior were observed, with exploratory behavior negatively correlated with pro-inflammatory cytokines.
HU mice exhibit changes in behavior, including reduced social behavior and increased non-directed movement during rest.
ROS quenching may be a potential target for countermeasures to prevent cognitive changes in astronauts.
The study sheds light on the underlying mechanism of simulated microgravity-induced neuroinflammation and its link to behavioral consequences.

nodes.title: Utilizing the KSC Fixation Tube to Conduct Human-Tended Plant Biology Experiments on a Suborbital Spaceflight
nodes.summary:
Suborbital spaceflights enable human-tended research on biological systems, eliminating the need for automation.
KSC Fixation Tubes (KFTs) can carry and fix plant biology samples during suborbital flights.
RNA-seq analysis showed consistent plant behavior in KFTs compared to petri-plates.
Plants in KFTs responded to hypoxia and changes in photosynthesis during a simulated flight.
The KFTs provided a suitable microenvironment for short-term plant growth.
Plant responses to gravity alteration in the KFTs were captured using clinostat experiments.

nodes.title: A Compact Imaging Platform for Conducting C. elegans Phenotypic Assays on Earth and in Spaceflight
nodes.summary:
Caenorhabditis elegans is a model organism used in various applications, including biological studies and space-biology investigations.
A compact imaging platform (CIP) was developed for whole-organism phenotyping of C. elegans.
The CIP is integrated with a smart-device camera and has no external optical elements, simplifying its optical configuration.
The system is powered by USB and can be housed in standard incubators, allowing for temperature control and parallel operation.
The CIP is compatible with different C. elegans substrates, including agar plates, liquid droplets, and microfluidic chips.
Validation studies were conducted on Earth, demonstrating the system's ability to distinguish between wild-type and mutant C. elegans strains.
The CIP's compactness, portability, and ease of use make it suitable for research and educational applications on Earth and in space.

nodes.title: Designing a Novel Monitoring Approach for the Effects of Space Travel on Astronauts' Health
nodes.summary:
Astronauts are at high risk of developing diseases due to space travel's effects on their health. 
Space travel decreases genome regulation and gene correlations across the entire genome and individual signaling pathways. 
A microarray dataset of 10 astronauts was analyzed to identify differentially expressed genes between In-flight and Pre-flight conditions. 
218 differentially expressed genes were identified, and their signaling pathways and disease networks were analyzed. 
A shortlist of 32 genes was systematically developed for a rapid assay to monitor astronauts' health in space. 
These genes are involved in various biological processes, including signal transduction, immune system, and metabolism. 
The proposed assay could be a novel and effective way to continuously monitor astronauts' health in space.

nodes.title: Brachypodium distachyon Seedlings Display Accession-Specific Morphological and Transcriptomic Responses to the Microgravity Environment of the International Space Station
nodes.summary:
Brachypodium distachyon seedlings exhibit accession-specific morphological and transcriptomic responses to microgravity.
The roots of all three accessions grow more slowly under microgravity conditions.
Shoots of Bd21-3 and Gaz-8 accessions grow at similar rates under microgravity and ground control conditions.
The three accessions display distinct transcriptomic responses to microgravity, with Gaz8 showing the largest number of differentially expressed genes.
Only a few genes are shared between accessions, including those involved in oxidative stress response and photosynthesis.
The study highlights the need to evaluate crop responses to microgravity to develop effective cultivation strategies for space exploration.

nodes.title: Morphology of Penicillium rubens Biofilms Formed in Space
nodes.summary:
Penicillium rubens biofilms were grown on seven materials in space and on Earth for 10, 15, and 20 days. 
Microgravity did not induce changes in biofilm shape, but affected growth in some cases, depending on material and incubation time. 
Nanograss was the material with significantly less biofilm formation, both in microgravity and on Earth. 
A decrease in biofilm formation at 20 days was observed in some space and Earth samples, potentially due to nutrient depletion. 
The results suggest mixed effects of microgravity on biofilm growth, dependent on material surface and incubation time. 
No consistent visual trends in morphological shape were observed across gravity conditions. 
The mechanisms behind the changes in fungal biofilm formation in microgravity are still unclear and need further investigation.

nodes.title: Correction: Tran et al. Delayed Maturation of Oligodendrocyte Progenitors by Microgravity: Implications for Multiple Sclerosis and Space Flight. Life 2022, 12, 797
nodes.summary:
The authors correct Figure 10 in their original publication due to mistakes in the bar graph. 
The correction involves the expression of Tf and GPDH markers in oligodendrocyte progenitors. 
Tf was expressed in the nuclei of all cells, not the cytoplasm. 
GPDH was weakly labeled in most cells, with nuclear expression only in cells undergoing karyokinesis or cytokinesis. 
The bar graph shows the percentage of markers expressed alone or coexpressed by OLPs. 
In the GC group, 34% co-expressed both OL markers, while 51% expressed transferrin alone and 41% expressed GPDH only. 
Statistical significance was assessed by one-way ANOVA with p < 0.05 defined as statistically significant.

nodes.title: Burn Injury-Associated MHCII + Immune Cell Accumulation Around Lymphatic Vessels of the Mesentery and Increased Lymphatic Endothelial Permeability Are Blocked by Doxycycline Treatment
nodes.summary:
Burn injury increases MHCII + immune cells around lymphatic vessels in the mesentery.
The size and shape of these cells change significantly after burn injury, indicating activation.
Serum from burn animals increases lymphatic endothelial permeability and disrupts cellular junctions.
Doxycycline treatment blocks the accumulation of immune cells and reduces lymphatic endothelial permeability.
Doxycycline inhibits the increase in lymphatic endothelial permeability and prevents disruption of junctional components.
The chemoattractive force for immune cells to migrate to lymphatic vessels primarily originates in the lymph.
Burn injury leads to the development of toxic lymph, which can cause dysfunction in various organs and cell types.

nodes.title: Metag enomic int errog ation of urban Superfund sit e reveals antimicrobial resistance reservoir and bioremediation potential
nodes.summary:
The Gowanus Canal, a Superfund site in Brooklyn, NY, hosts a diverse microbial population.
The microbiome encodes antimicrobial resistance genes and bioremediation pathways for degrading contaminants.
The canal's environment is a unique reservoir for novel biosynthetic gene clusters (BGCs) and secondary metabolites.
Microbes in the canal have evolved to survive in extreme conditions, degrading complex hydrocarbons and fixing heavy metals.
The study highlights the potential for biotechnological applications, such as bioremediation and resource recovery.
The co-occurrence of antimicrobial resistance genes and bioremediation metabolisms raises questions about the impact of industrial contaminants on ARG persistence.
The research suggests a need to redefine human relationships with microorganisms and consider collaborative survival strategies.

nodes.title: Contributions of Spore Secondary Metabolites to UV-C Protection and Virulence Vary in Different Aspergillus fumigatus Strains
nodes.summary:
Aspergillus fumigatus produces secondary metabolites that protect its spores from UV-C radiation.
DHN-melanin is a UV-C protectant in some A. fumigatus isolates, but not all.
Fumiquinazoline provides protection from UV radiation in Af293.
The role of DHN-melanin in virulence varies between A. fumigatus isolates.
The loss of DHN-melanin affects virulence in CEA17 and IF1SW-F4, but not Af293.
Other conidial metabolites, such as fumigaclavine and trypacidin, do not protect against UV-C radiation.
The study highlights the importance of understanding the role of secondary metabolites in protecting A. fumigatus from environmental stresses.

nodes.title: Characterization of Aspergillus niger Isolated from the International Space Station
nodes.summary:
Aspergillus niger was isolated from the International Space Station (ISS) and characterized.
The ISS isolate, JSC-093350089, exhibited increased growth rate and pigment distribution.
Proteome analysis revealed differential abundance of proteins involved in starvation response and oxidative stress resistance.
The ISS isolate showed increased abundance of proteins involved in cell wall modulation and nutrient acquisition.
Phylogenetic analysis placed JSC-093350089 within the A. niger/welwitschiae/lacticoffeatus clade.
The genome of JSC-093350089 was similar in size to other A. niger genomes, with 223 scaffolds and 12,532 coding sequences.
The study provides insight into the characteristics of melanized fungal species inhabiting spacecraft environments.

nodes.title: KatharoSeq Enables High-Throughput Microbiome Analysis from Low-Biomass Samples
nodes.summary:
KatharoSeq is a high-throughput protocol for microbiome analysis from low-biomass samples.
It incorporates positive and negative controls to reveal the whole bacterial community.
The protocol can process at least five times as fast as single-tube extractions.
KatharoSeq correctly identifies 90.6% of the reads from 500 cells.
It has been applied to three unique low-biomass environments: a spacecraft assembly facility, a neonatal intensive care unit, and an endangered-abalone-rearing facility.
The protocol enables spatially resolved, unique microbiomes reproducible across hundreds of samples.

nodes.title: Genomic Characterization and Virulence Potential of Two Fusarium oxysporum Isolates Cultured from the International Space Station
nodes.summary:
Two Fusarium oxysporum isolates, ISS-F3 and ISS-F4, were cultured from the International Space Station.
Genomic analysis revealed they are genomically different from 65 known sequenced strains.
ISS-F3 and ISS-F4 have higher relative abundances of polyketide synthase domains than other strains.
They may produce yet-unreported polyketides and nonribosomal peptides.
Virulence assays showed ISS-F3 and ISS-F4 are virulent in an immunocompromised Caenorhabditis elegans model.
ISS-F4 was the most virulent, causing death by both hypha piercing-related and -unrelated mechanisms.

nodes.title: Phenotypic characterization of an Arabidopsis T-DNA insertion line SALK_063500
nodes.summary:
A T-DNA insertion line, SALK_063500, was identified in the Arabidopsis genome, disrupting the AT1G05290 gene.
The T-DNA insertion is located within exon one of the AT1G05290 gene, making it impossible to obtain a homozygous T-DNA allele.
Heterozygous SALK_063500 plants exhibited an aberrant silique phenotype due to reduced pollen tube germination rates.
The expression levels of AT1G05290 in heterozygous SALK_063500 plants were compared to wild-type Arabidopsis.
No homozygous T-DNA alleles were found after screening over a thousand SALK_063500 progeny.
The silique phenotype and pollen tube germination rates were analyzed in both Col-0 and heterozygous SALK_063500 plants.
The data suggest that the T-DNA insertion in the AT1G05290 gene affects pollen tube germination and silique development in Arabidopsis.

nodes.title: Asparagine biosynthesis as a mechanism of increased host lethality induced by Serratia marcescens in simulated microgravity environments
nodes.summary:
Serratia marcescens exhibits increased virulence in simulated microgravity environments.
The asparagine biosynthesis pathway is upregulated in S. marcescens under microgravity conditions.
Asparagine synthetase B (asnB) is overexpressed, leading to increased asparagine production.
The addition of aspartate and glutamine to minimal media recapitulates the increased virulence.
L-asparaginase treatment mitigates the increased host mortality caused by microgravity-treated S. marcescens.
The asparagine pathway plays a critical role in the increased virulence of S. marcescens under microgravity conditions.
The study provides a potential therapeutic target for mitigating the effects of microgravity on bacterial virulence.

nodes.title: Drosophila parasitoids go to space: Unexpected effects of spaceflight on hosts and their parasitoids
nodes.summary:
Drosophila melanogaster and its parasitoid wasps were sent to space to study the effects of spaceflight on hosts and parasites.
The study found that spaceflight compromises the emergence of healthy flies but not tumor-bearing flies.
Parasitoid wasps developed normally in space and retained their virulence, with minimal changes in gene expression.
The venom activity of wasps from space was comparable to those from ground controls.
Mutant wasps with visible alterations were isolated post-flight, which will be valuable for host-parasite studies on Earth.

nodes.title: Drosophila parasitoids go to space: Unexpected effects of spaceflight on hosts and their parasitoids
nodes.summary:
Drosophila melanogaster and its parasitoid wasps were sent to space to study the effects of spaceflight on hosts and parasites.
The study found that spaceflight compromises the emergence of healthy flies but not tumor-bearing flies.
Parasitoid wasps developed normally in space and retained their virulence, with minimal changes in gene expression.
The venom activity of wasps from space was comparable to those from ground controls.
Mutant wasps with visible alterations were isolated post-flight, which will be valuable for host-parasite studies on Earth.

nodes.title: Amelioration of the physio-biochemical responses to salinity stress and computing the primary germination index components in cauliflower on seed priming
nodes.summary:
Salinity affects nearly 20% of the world's agricultural land, impacting crop production. 
Seed priming is a technique used to combat salinity-induced growth limitations in plants. 
This study investigated the effects of hydro-, halo-, and osmo-priming on cauliflower seed germination under salt stress. 
The results showed that all priming agents enhanced germination indices and growth parameters. 
Proline accumulation and total soluble protein content increased in primed seedlings, while MDA levels decreased. 
The study concluded that seed priming is a cost-effective and eco-friendly method to improve cauliflower crop performance under salt stress. 
Further research is needed to explore the scalability of priming approaches for sustainable production and to develop salt-tolerant cauliflower varieties. 
The findings of this study can contribute to the development of strategies to achieve sustainable crop yields under adverse conditions.

nodes.title: Over-activation of iNKT cells aggravate lung injury in bronchopulmonary dysplasia mice
nodes.summary:
Bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD) is a severe lung disease in preterm infants.
The abnormal proliferation and differentiation of type II epithelial cells (AEC II) is key to BPD's pathological basis.
Invariant natural killer T (iNKT) cells play a role in lung disorder in BPD, with increased iNKT cells in BPD patients.
Hyperoxia exposure promotes the accumulation and activation of iNKT cells in the lungs of mice, leading to disordered lung development.
Inhibition of iNKT cell activation alleviates abnormal lung development in BPD mice, while specific activation of iNKT cells aggravates lung disorders.

nodes.title: Recent transcriptomic studies to elucidate the plant adaptive response to spaceflight and to simulated space environments
nodes.summary:
Plant transcriptomic studies in spaceflight and simulated microgravity environments have advanced our understanding of plant adaptation mechanisms. 
Cell wall remodeling, oxidative stress, defense reaction, and photosynthesis are common processes affected in plants grown in space. 
The absence of gravity triggers a stress response, leading to adaptation reactions in plants. 
Light quality and day length regulate plant development and flowering time in spaceflight environments. 
Genetic background and organ-specific responses are crucial factors in plant adaptation to spaceflight. 
Transcriptomic studies have identified key genes and pathways involved in plant adaptation to microgravity. 
Understanding plant adaptation to space is essential for successful life support systems in future space missions. 
European scientists have made significant contributions to this field, particularly in the use of simulated microgravity facilities and cell cultures.

nodes.title: The Importance of Earth Reference Controls in Spaceflight -Omics Research: Characterization of Nucleolin Mutants from the Seedling Growth Experiments
nodes.summary:
Understanding plant adaptive responses to space environment is crucial for space farming.
Spaceflight affects plant cells, particularly ribosome biogenesis, a complex process.
Nucleolin mutants from Arabidopsis were used to study adaptive response mechanisms to stress.
The NUC2 protein can compensate for environmental stress in nuc1 plants, but not fully.
Red light stimulation affects ribosome biogenesis and cell proliferation in plants.
The study highlights the importance of Earth reference controls in spaceflight -omics research.
The results may lead to more efficient agriculture and plant cultivation in bioregenerative life support systems.

nodes.title: Microbial isolation and characterization from two flex lines from the urine processor assembly onboard the international space station
nodes.summary:
Microorganisms were isolated from two flex lines of the Urine Processor Assembly onboard the International Space Station. 
The isolates included Burkholderia, Paraburkholderia, Leifsonia, and fungi such as Fusarium and Lecythophora. 
Genomic analysis revealed chromate-resistance gene clusters in the Burkholderia isolates, distinguishing them from previously studied isolates. 
Environmental scanning electron microscopy showed fungal-bacterial biofilm formation in the flex lines, a first for this area of the system. 
The Burkholderia isolates demonstrated significant biofilm formation potential, with some isolates producing antifungal compounds. 
The study highlights the unique ecological niche of the flex lines and the need for further investigation into microbial communities in space-based water systems. 
Understanding these communities is crucial for developing effective biofilm prevention strategies for future space missions.

nodes.title: Routine omics collection is a golden opportunity for European human research in space and analog environments
nodes.summary:
The European Space Agency (ESA) has a unique opportunity to develop a routine omics collection program for astronauts and spaceflight participants.
This program would involve collecting and analyzing various types of omics data, such as genomics, transcriptomics, and proteomics.
The goal is to improve our understanding of the effects of spaceflight on the human body and to develop personalized medicine approaches.
A routine omics program would require careful consideration of factors such as data storage, sampling methods, and ethical and legal implications.
The program would also need to balance the need for open science with the need to protect personal data and ensure participant privacy.

nodes.title: Muscle atrophy phenotype gene expression during spaceflight is linked to a metabolic crosstalk in both the liver and the muscle in mice
nodes.summary:
Muscle atrophy during spaceflight is linked to metabolic changes in both the liver and muscle.
Lipid metabolic processes are the most affected biological processes in mice quadriceps and liver.
Glucose metabolic genes are the most differentially expressed in mice quadriceps during spaceflight.
Hypoglycemic signaling pathways are downregulated in mice quadriceps, indicating insulin resistance.
Liver lipid metabolism gene expression correlates with muscle glucose transport and atrophy phenotype.
A cluster of lipid metabolism-related genes in the liver correlates with muscle gene expression.
Hepatokines are likely the effector of liver-muscle crosstalk, influencing energy metabolism and muscle atrophy.

nodes.title: Turbidity matters: differential effect of a 2,4-D formulation on the structure of microbial communities from clear and turbid freshwater systems
nodes.summary:
The effect of AsiMax 50, a commercial formulation of 2,4-D, on freshwater microbial communities was evaluated.
The study used microcosms with water from clear and turbid freshwater systems, with seven concentration levels of 2,4-D.
The impact of AsiMax 50 was greater in the turbid system, with changes in micro and nano phytoplankton abundance and species composition.
The abundance of micro and nano phytoplankton increased at lower 2,4-D concentrations and decreased at higher concentrations.
The study suggests that 2,4-D may mimic hormonal function, with some species responding differently to herbicide exposure between water systems.
The results highlight the importance of using community-scale approaches in ecotoxicological studies to predict changes in freshwater ecosystems.

nodes.title: Telomere length assessments of muscle stem cells in rodent and human skeletal muscle sections Protocol Telomere length assessments of muscle stem cells in rodent and human skeletal muscle sections
nodes.summary:
Reductions in telomere length in muscle stem cells have been discovered in chronic muscle injury conditions.
The quantitative fluorescent in-situ hybridization technique allows for assessment of telomere length based on fluorescence intensity.
This protocol provides a method for telomere length assessment in muscle stem cells using cryosections of murine skeletal muscle.
The method can be beneficial for telomere length quantitation of archival samples and can be adapted for other muscle-resident cell types.
The protocol utilizes skeletal muscle tissue from research animals and human cohorts, with proper approval and guidelines.
Telomere length is measured using a semi-automated ImageJ-based platform known as Telometer, providing robust information on telomere length.
The protocol can be applied to additional resident skeletal muscle populations, with appropriate markers and testing for compatibility.

nodes.title: Hypotheses about sub-optimal hydration in the weeks before coronavirus disease (COVID-19) as a risk factor for dying from COVID-19
nodes.summary:
Suboptimal hydration may increase the risk of dying from COVID-19 by promoting fluid retention in the lungs. 
Chronic hypertonicity and hypovolemia can lead to adaptations that increase the abundance of ACE2 receptors, making it easier for the virus to infect cells. 
Infection triggers an inflammatory response, which can cause fluid to leak into the airway space, leading to acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). 
Hypertonicity can also suppress the initial immune response, allowing the virus to replicate and infect more cells. 
Interventions to improve hydration, such as drinking water and hypertonic saline treatment, may reduce the risk of ARDS and mortality. 
Biomarkers such as SGK1 and saliva osmolality may be used to identify individuals at risk of severe COVID-19 infection. 
Tailoring treatment to the pre-infection hydration status may improve outcomes for COVID-19 patients.

nodes.title: NASA GeneLab RNA-seq consensus pipeline: standardized processing of short-read RNAseq data
nodes.summary:
The NASA GeneLab RNA-seq consensus pipeline is a standardized process for analyzing RNA-seq data from spaceflight studies.
It consists of three main steps: data preprocessing, data processing, and differential gene expression calculation.
The pipeline uses various tools, including FastQC, TrimGalore, STAR, and DESeq2, to ensure accurate and reliable results.
The pipeline is designed to handle sequencing experiments with or without ERCC RNA spike-in mix.
It provides output files, including unnormalized and normalized counts tables, and differential gene expression results.
The pipeline enables users to perform downstream analyses, such as gene ontology and pathway analysis, using various software tools.
The pipeline's results can be used to identify differentially expressed genes and understand the effects of spaceflight on gene expression.

nodes.title: Challenges and considerations for single-cell and spatially resolved transcriptomics sample collection during spaceflight
nodes.summary:
Single-cell RNA sequencing and spatially resolved transcriptomics are crucial for understanding gene expression in spaceflight.
These methods require high-quality sample preservation, which is challenging in spaceflight due to limited resources and equipment.
Current preservation methods, such as freezing and fixation, have limitations and may not be suitable for all types of samples.
New technologies, such as cloud labs and automated sample processing, are being developed to improve sample preservation and analysis in spaceflight.
These advancements will enable researchers to conduct high-quality omics experiments in spaceflight, leading to a better understanding of the effects of spaceflight on living organisms.
The development of standardized protocols and analysis pipelines for single-cell RNA sequencing and spatially resolved transcriptomics is essential for advancing the field of space biosciences.
Improved understanding of gene expression in spaceflight will facilitate the development of countermeasures against spaceflight-associated dysregulation and disease.

nodes.title: Beyond Low-Earth Orbit: Characterizing Immune and microRNA Differentials following Simulated Deep Spaceflight Conditions in Mice
nodes.summary:
Mice were exposed to simulated deep spaceflight conditions, including galactic cosmic rays and solar particle events, to analyze immune and microRNA differentials. 
The results showed reduced immune organ weights and total leukocyte populations after exposure to these conditions. 
Innate immune profiles revealed distinct populations following simulated deep space exposures, with elevated neutrophil and eosinophil populations. 
Adaptive immune profiles showed reduced T helper and T cytotoxic lymphocytes, indicating impaired adaptive immunity. 
Circulating microRNAs played a role in regulating immune responses, with unique microRNA signatures produced by each exposure group. 
The study's findings have implications for understanding the effects of deep spaceflight on the immune system and developing countermeasures for future missions. 
Overall, the results suggest that deep spaceflight exposures can have significant effects on the immune system, highlighting the need for further research in this area.

nodes.title: RNAseq Analysis of Rodent Spaceflight Experiments Is Confounded by Sample Collection Techniques
nodes.summary:
RNAseq analysis of rodent spaceflight experiments is confounded by sample collection techniques.
Preservation methods used on the International Space Station (ISS) introduce confounding factors.
Changes due to preservation method eclipse those between flight and ground samples.
Follow-on experiments suggest that differences due to preservation protocols are exacerbated when coupled with polyA selection.
Ribodepletion methods are more effective on degraded RNA samples and reduce bias.
Carcass preservation by LN2 or RNAlater immersion most closely mimics standard tissue preservation protocols.
The impact of preservation method on gene expression is tissue-dependent, with liver samples being more sensitive than quadriceps.

nodes.title: Sex differences in muscle health in simulated micro-and partial-gravity environments in rats
nodes.summary:
Females lost more muscle strength and size than males in microgravity and partial-gravity environments.
Females had greater loss in dorsiflexion and plantar flexion strength compared to males at both 0g and 0.4g.
The presence or absence of sex steroid hormones did not influence the sex differences in muscle loss.
Females had greater loss in muscle fiber cross-sectional area and muscle mass compared to males.
The study suggests that female astronauts may be at increased risk for muscle loss and related functional outcomes after exposure to reduced gravity.
Interventions to mitigate muscle loss may need to be sex-specific to ensure astronaut safety and mission success.
The findings have implications for space agencies and commercial spaceflight companies to develop targeted countermeasures for female astronauts.

nodes.title: Sex differences in muscle health in simulated micro-and partial-gravity environments in rats
nodes.summary:
Females lost more muscle strength and size than males in microgravity and partial-gravity environments.
Females had greater loss in dorsiflexion and plantar flexion strength compared to males at both 0g and 0.4g.
The presence or absence of sex steroid hormones did not influence the sex differences in muscle loss.
Females had greater loss in muscle fiber cross-sectional area and muscle mass compared to males.
The study suggests that female astronauts may be at increased risk for muscle loss and related functional outcomes after exposure to reduced gravity.
Interventions to mitigate muscle loss may need to be sex-specific to ensure astronaut safety and mission success.
The findings have implications for space agencies and commercial spaceflight companies to develop targeted countermeasures for female astronauts.

nodes.title: Blood Flow Restriction Training: A Tool to Enhance Rehabilitation and Build Athlete Resiliency
nodes.summary:
Blood flow restriction training (BFRT) is a tool used in rehabilitation and injury prevention to improve muscle strength and size. 
BFRT facilitates gains in muscular strength and hypertrophy at lower loads, allowing for accelerated recovery and less disuse atrophy. 
It must be applied appropriately and with caution, particularly in individuals with cardiovascular concerns. 
BFRT has applications across a wide spectrum of human performance training and in rehabilitation of both lower and upper extremity conditions. 
The primary pathways to achieve muscle hypertrophy are metabolic stress, muscle damage, and mechanical tension. 
BFRT is a modality that can achieve these results in load-compromised individuals, enabling them to train at lighter loads while still achieving metabolic stress. 
BFRT can be used as a progressive training stimulus in load-compromised individuals or healthy athletes to drive muscular hypertrophy and improve sport performance.

nodes.title: Reanalysis of the Mars500 experiment reveals common gut microbiome alterations in astronauts induced by long-duration confinement
nodes.summary:
The Mars500 experiment isolated six astronauts for 520 days to study long-duration health effects.
Astronauts experienced uniform strength and lean body mass losses, and increased fasting plasma glucose.
Previous analyses found no significant changes in gut microbiota, but reanalysis identified 408 exact sequence variants.
Thirty-two ESVs were significantly differentially abundant over time, including depletion of anti-inflammatory species.
Enriched taxa included poorly characterized organisms, while depleted taxa were well-known species like Faecalibacterium prausnitzii.
Comparison of astronaut and habitat microbiomes revealed 49% and 12% of species were shared, respectively.
These findings highlight the impact of long-term confinement on the human microbiome and its potential effects on health.

nodes.title: Caenorhabditis elegans in microgravity: An omics perspective
nodes.summary:
Caenorhabditis elegans is a model organism used to study spaceflight-induced physiological changes.
Omics technologies, including transcriptomics and proteomics, have been applied to study C. elegans in microgravity.
These studies have revealed robust metabolic and neuromuscular changes in response to spaceflight.
Transcriptional and proteomic analyses have identified altered gene and protein expression related to muscle locomotion and metabolism.
Epigenetic changes, including microRNA and DNA methylation, have also been observed in response to microgravity.
Future research should focus on integrating multi-omics approaches and spatial transcriptomics to understand tissue-specific responses to microgravity.
The use of C. elegans as a model organism can provide valuable insights into the mechanisms of spaceflight-induced health declines and contribute to the development of countermeasures.

nodes.title: Effects of spaceflight on cancellous and cortical bone in proximal femur in growing rats â
nodes.summary:
Spaceflight results in cancellous osteopenia in the femoral head of growing rats.
The effects of spaceflight on bone microarchitecture were evaluated in archived proximal femora from two spaceflight missions.
Cancellous bone volume fraction was lower in flight animals compared to flight controls and baseline in ovx female rats.
Cortical thickness did not differ among groups in either experiment.
The observed osteopenia in the femoral head supports the results of a previous 4-day study in male Sprague-Dawley rats.
Spaceflight resulted in osteopenia in the femoral head in male Fisher 344 rats and ovx female Fisher 344 rats.
The magnitude of response appeared to be smaller in the latter two studies compared to the initial 4-day study.

nodes.title: Small changes in thermoregulation influence cancellous bone turnover balance in distal femur metaphysis in growing female mice
nodes.summary:
Mice housed at room temperature (~22Â°C) experience cold stress, leading to cancellous bone loss.
A small increase in temperature (4Â°C) to 26Â°C attenuates but does not prevent bone loss in distal femur metaphysis.
Group housing with nestlets at 22Â°C also moderates the effect of room temperature housing on bone.
Cancellous bone volume fraction in distal femur metaphysis decreases significantly in mice single housed at 22Â°C.
Mice single housed at 26Â°C have higher cancellous bone volume fraction and trabecular number than those at 22Â°C.
Group housing with nestlets results in similar bone outcomes as single housing at 26Â°C.
Modest differences in housing conditions can influence bone mass and architecture, affecting experimental results.

nodes.title: Spaceflight affects neuronal morphology and alters transcellular degradation of neuronal debris in adult Caenorhabditis elegans
nodes.summary:
Spaceflight affects neuronal morphology in adult Caenorhabditis elegans, inducing hyperbranching in PVD sensory neurons. 
Touch receptor neurons exhibit modest morphological changes, with increased branching in some neurons. 
Proteostressed touch neurons in space-flown animals accumulate neuronal debris in surrounding tissues. 
The hypodermal tissue, analogous to mammalian glia, fails to efficiently clear neuronal waste in space-flown animals. 
This failure leads to the accumulation of impaired degradative organelles, such as lysosomes. 
The inability to clear neuronal trash is associated with the aging process, as young adult animals do not exhibit this accumulation. 
Overall, spaceflight impairs neuronal proteostasis and clearance pathways, with potential implications for long-duration spaceflights.

nodes.title: Toward countering muscle and bone loss with spaceflight: GSK3 as a potential target
nodes.summary:
GSK3 is a potential target for countering muscle and bone loss with spaceflight.
Spaceflight reduces bone mineral density in mice and GSK3 muscle knockdown preserves muscle strength.
GSK3 muscle knockdown increases FNDC5 expression and tibia bone mineral density.
Muscle-specific GSK3 inhibition increases soleus muscle size and strength under simulated microgravity conditions.
GSK3 inhibition may also help maintain bone mass by increasing PGC-1a and FNDC5.
Future studies are needed to examine the effects of pharmacological GSK3 inhibition on musculoskeletal health during spaceflight.

nodes.title: Preclinical development of TAK-754, a high-performance AAV8-based vector expressing coagulation factor VIII
nodes.summary:
TAK-754 is a gene therapy vector designed to treat hemophilia A by expressing human factor VIII.
The vector uses the AAV8 capsid and a liver-specific promoter to deliver the factor VIII transgene.
Preclinical studies in mice showed a dose-dependent increase in plasma factor VIII activity and a decrease in blood loss.
Long-term expression of factor VIII was demonstrated in immunologically tolerant transgenic mice.
Toxicology and biodistribution studies found no adverse effects and minimal vector integration.
The vector's design and preclinical data support its potential as a treatment for hemophilia A.
The studies provide a foundation for further clinical development of TAK-754.

nodes.title: Preclinical development of TAK-754, a high-performance AAV8-based vector expressing coagulation factor VIII
nodes.summary:
TAK-754 is a gene therapy vector designed to treat hemophilia A by expressing human factor VIII.
The vector uses the AAV8 capsid and a liver-specific promoter to deliver the factor VIII transgene.
Preclinical studies in mice showed a dose-dependent increase in plasma factor VIII activity and a decrease in blood loss.
Long-term expression of factor VIII was demonstrated in immunologically tolerant transgenic mice.
Toxicology and biodistribution studies found no adverse effects and minimal vector integration.
The vector's design and preclinical data support its potential as a treatment for hemophilia A.
The studies provide a foundation for further clinical development of TAK-754.

nodes.title: NASA GeneLab RNA-seq consensus pipeline: standardized processing of short-read RNAseq data
nodes.summary:
The NASA GeneLab RNA-seq consensus pipeline is a standardized process for analyzing RNA-seq data from spaceflight studies.
It consists of three main steps: data preprocessing, data processing, and differential gene expression calculation.
The pipeline uses various tools, including FastQC, TrimGalore, STAR, and DESeq2, to ensure accurate and reliable results.
The pipeline is designed to handle sequencing experiments with or without ERCC RNA spike-in mix.
It provides output files, including unnormalized and normalized counts tables, and differential gene expression results.
The pipeline enables users to perform downstream analyses, such as gene ontology and pathway analysis, using various software tools.
The pipeline's results can be used to identify differentially expressed genes and understand the effects of spaceflight on gene expression.

nodes.title: A New Era for Space Life Science: International Standards for Space Omics Processing
nodes.summary:
Space agencies plan to send humans to the Moon and Mars, but space environment stressors pose risks to human health. 
Understanding these effects is crucial for safe space exploration, and scientists are conducting space omics experiments on model organisms. 
However, optimal extraction of scientific insights from these datasets requires improved standardization and communication at the international level. 
The International Standards for Space Omics Processing (ISSOP) consortium aims to develop and share sample-processing standardization and metadata normalization guidelines. 
ISSOP's mission is to enhance guidelines for space biologists globally and allow for better harmonization of data and increased knowledge gain. 
The consortium will develop recommendations for individual assays, including proteomics and metabolomics, and propose best practices for various organisms. 
ISSOP's standardization efforts will be crucial for understanding the effects of spaceflight on biological organisms and preparing for safe and effective crewed space exploration.

nodes.title: NASA GeneLab RNA-seq consensus pipeline: standardized processing of short-read RNAseq data
nodes.summary:
The NASA GeneLab RNA-seq consensus pipeline is a standardized process for analyzing RNA-seq data from spaceflight studies.
It consists of three main steps: data preprocessing, data processing, and differential gene expression calculation.
The pipeline uses various tools, including FastQC, TrimGalore, STAR, and DESeq2, to ensure accurate and reliable results.
The pipeline is designed to handle sequencing experiments with or without ERCC RNA spike-in mix.
It provides output files, including unnormalized and normalized counts tables, and differential gene expression results.
The pipeline enables users to perform downstream analyses, such as gene ontology and pathway analysis, using various software tools.
The pipeline's results can be used to identify differentially expressed genes and understand the effects of spaceflight on gene expression.

nodes.title: Data for characterization of SALK_084889, a T-DNA insertion line of Arabidopsis thaliana
nodes.summary:
The SALK_084889 Arabidopsis mutant line has T-DNA insertions in the 3' UTR of DREB2A and the promoter of LOX1. 
The expression of DREB2A is not downregulated under normal growth conditions but is affected in roots under drought treatment. 
LOX1 is significantly downregulated in both roots and shoots under all tested conditions. 
The T-DNA insertion sites were determined by DNA-PCR and Sanger sequencing. 
The expression levels of DREB2A and LOX1 were analyzed using quantitative real-time PCR. 
The drought and heat tolerance of SALK_084889 was compared to wild-type Arabidopsis. 
The data provides valuable information for mutation analysis of DREB2A and LOX1 in Arabidopsis.

nodes.title: High-precision method for cyclic loading of small-animal vertebrae to assess bone quality
nodes.summary:
A new method for cyclic loading of small-animal vertebrae has been developed to assess bone quality.
The method uses 3D-printed support jigs and pivotable loading platens to ensure uniform contact and loading.
Specimen-specific micro-CT-based finite element analysis is used to measure stiffness and prescribe individualized cyclic forces.
The new method produced lower variation in fatigue life compared to two existing methods from the literature.
The standard deviation of fatigue life was 5-fold lower for the new method compared to the existing methods.
The new method also provided measurements of effective tissue elastic modulus and strain to failure with high uniformity across specimens.
The method can help elucidate aspects of bone quality and improve statistical power in small-animal experiments.

nodes.title: Cryptococcus albidus meningitis A case report and literature review
nodes.summary:
Cryptococcus albidus is a rare species that causes life-threatening central nervous system (CNS) infections. 
A 25-year-old female patient was diagnosed with C albidus meningitis after undergoing a craniotomy. 
The patient was treated with liposomal-amphotericin B (liposomal-AmB) and 5-fluorocytosine for 6 weeks. 
The use of ideal bodyweight to calculate the dose of liposomal-AmB is recommended for severely obese patients. 
C albidus infections are often associated with high mortality rates and are commonly found in immunocompromised patients. 
The identification of C albidus requires analysis of rRNA sequences due to phenotypic similarities with other species. 
AmB-based treatment is the first choice, and subsequent treatment should be guided by susceptibility testing.

nodes.title: Mannose Receptor Deficiency Impacts Bone Marrow and Circulating Immune Cells during High Fat Diet Induced Obesity
nodes.summary:
Mannose receptor deficiency impacts bone marrow and circulating immune cells during high-fat diet-induced obesity.
Mrc1 -/- mice fed a high-fat diet for 20 weeks presented impaired medullary hematopoiesis with reduced myeloid progenitors and mature cells.
The lack of Mrc1 resulted in an increased presence of adipocytes in the bone marrow and a reduced number of circulating myeloid inflammatory cells.
Mrc1 deficiency was associated with reduced infiltration of monocyte-derived macrophages in visceral adipose tissue and the liver.
The improved inflammatory response in Mrc1-deficient mice was paralleled by reduced body weight gain and improved glucose and insulin response.
Liver histological profiling and untargeted proteomic analysis revealed decreased liver steatosis and downregulation of proteins involved in liver dysfunction.
Mrc1 deficiency resulted in a protective bone marrow phenotype and reduced leukocyte infiltration, associating with overall protection from obesity-related dysfunctions.

nodes.title: Three-Dimensional Kidney-on-a-Chip Assessment of Contrast-Induced Kidney Injury: Osmolality and Viscosity
nodes.summary:
Contrast-induced nephropathy (CIN) is a major health problem that occurs after iodine contrast exposure.
CIN is known to be caused by various factors including vasoconstriction, medullary hypoxia, and direct cytotoxicity.
The physicochemical properties of iodinated contrast materials, such as osmolality and viscosity, may be related to nephrotoxicity.
A three-dimensional kidney-on-a-chip model was used to evaluate the effects of low-osmolar contrast media (LOCM) and iso-osmolar contrast media (IOCM) on renal tubules.
The results showed that LOCM had a significant dose-dependent cytotoxic effect, while IOCM caused renal tubular cell damage under high-shear-stress conditions.
The study highlights the importance of considering the rheological effects of contrast media in the pathogenesis of CIN.

nodes.title: Microbial Burden Estimation of Food Items, Built Environments, and the International Space Station Using Film Media
nodes.summary:
Film media, such as Easy Plates and Petrifilm, are viable alternatives to agar plates for low-biomass built environments and food samples.
They offer advantages like lower costs, increased inoculation speed, and reduced experimental preparation time.
The study compared the performance of film media with agar media for cultivable microbial counts in food items, built environments, and the International Space Station (ISS).
Results showed that film media performed comparably to agar media for bacterial counts, with R2 values of 0.94-0.96 for food items and 0.96-0.97 for built environments.
Fungal counts had lower correlations between film and agar media, with R2 values of 0.72-0.73 for built environments and 0.73 for ISS samples.
The species composition of isolates from film media and agar media were similar, with some differences in the isolation of rare species.

nodes.title: Sequencing the Genomes of the First Terrestrial Fungal Lineages: What Have We Learned?
nodes.summary:
The first genome sequenced of a zygomycete fungus was from a clinical strain of Rhizopus delemar. 
Over 1000 zygomycete genomes have been sequenced, with 70% still in the draft stage. 
The majority of zygomycete genomes are assembled de novo, with choice of assembly software depending on data type. 
Genome quality is improved by increasing sequence coverage, with some zygomycete genomes sequenced at a depth of 500-700Ã. 
The number of scaffolds in zygomycete genomes varies, with some having as few as 12 and others having over 373,000. 
Zygomycete genomes contain a wide range of gene numbers, from 4,000 to over 30,000. 
The study of zygomycete genomes has provided insights into their evolution, adaptation to terrestrial life, and interactions with hosts and environments.

nodes.title: Draft genome sequence of Sphingomonas paucimobilis strain Sph5, isolated from tap water filtration membrane
nodes.summary:
Sphingomonas paucimobilis strain Sph5 was isolated from a tap water filtration membrane.
The strain was identified through whole genome sequencing and de novo assembly.
Sphingomonadaceae are common membrane colonizers and biofilm formers in drinking water systems.
The draft genome sequence of Sph5 was obtained using Illumina short-read sequencing.
The assembly was performed with SPADES and completeness was estimated using BUSCO.
Average nucleotide identity (ANI) scores confirmed Sph5 as Sphingomonas paucimobilis with 99.77%-99.95% similarity.
The genome sequence of Sph5 provides insights into strain-specific traits associated with membrane biofouling.

nodes.title: Draft Genome Sequences of Fungi Isolated from the International Space Station during the Microbial Tracking-2 Experiment
nodes.summary:
Fungal strains were isolated from the International Space Station during the Microbial Tracking-2 Experiment.
94 fungal strains were isolated and whole-genome sequences were assembled.
The draft genomes represent 10 ascomycetous and 1 basidiomycetous species.
Aspergillus, Aureobasidium, Cladosporium, Fusarium, Penicillium, and Rhodotorula species were identified.
These fungi can affect astronaut health and spacecraft functioning through opportunistic infections and biofouling.
The characterization of these draft genomes will allow evaluation of microgravity adaptation and biotechnological applications.
The identified fungi have potential uses as sources of nutrients and bioactive compounds during long-term spaceflight.

nodes.title: Correction for Vangay et al., "Microbiome Metadata Standards: Report of the National Microbiome Data Collaborative's Workshop and Follow-On Activities"
nodes.summary:
The article byline and affiliation line require correction. 
The original publication contained errors in the author affiliations. 
A workshop was held by the National Microbiome Data Collaborative. 
The goal was to establish microbiome metadata standards. 
Standardization is crucial for data sharing and comparison. 
The correction aims to provide accurate author information. 
Accurate metadata is essential for reliable microbiome research.

nodes.title: From the international space station to the clinic: how prolonged unloading may disrupt lumbar spine stability
nodes.summary:
Prolonged microgravity exposure is associated with localized low back pain and an elevated risk of post-flight disc herniation.
Astronauts experience spinal lengthening and decreased lumbar lordosis after spaceflight, which may increase the risk of disc herniation.
This study compared quantitative measures of lumbar spine anatomy, health, and biomechanics in astronauts before and after 6 months of microgravity exposure.
The results showed that lumbar lordosis decreased and intersegmental range of motion decreased after spaceflight.
Muscle atrophy, specifically of the multifidus, was strongly associated with post-flight decreases in lumbar lordosis and intersegmental range of motion.
The study suggests that microgravity-induced lumbar spine flattening is linked to multifidus atrophy rather than disc swelling.
The risk of post-flight symptoms may relate to pre-existing spinal pathology, such as end plate irregularities and Modic changes.

nodes.title: Fish Oil Increases Specialized Pro-resolving Lipid Mediators in PAD (The OMEGA-PAD II Trial)
nodes.summary:
The OMEGA-PAD II trial investigated the effects of 3 months of high-dose n-3 PUFA supplementation on inflammation and vascular function in patients with PAD.
The trial found no significant change in hsCRP levels after intervention in the fish oil or placebo group.
The omega-3 index increased more than two-fold in the fish oil group, with no significant changes in the placebo group.
Fish oil supplementation resulted in increases in total plasma DHA and EPA, with significant increases in SPM biosynthesis pathways.
The trial identified several downstream EPA and DHA products that serve as SPM biosynthesis pathway markers, including 15-HEPE and 18-HEPE.
The levels of 15-HEPE and 18-HEPE increased significantly after 3 months of fish oil supplementation, with no change in the placebo group.
The results suggest that n-3 PUFA supplementation may play a role in increasing time to claudication and walking distance in patients with PAD.
