nodes.title: Maintenance of Near Normal Bone Mass and Architecture in Lethally Irradiated Female Mice following Adoptive Transfer with as few as 750 Purified Hematopoietic Stem Cells
nodes.summary:
Lethal total-body irradiation (TBI) can lead to irreversible osteopenia and bone loss.
Adoptive transfer of purified hematopoietic stem cells (HSCs) can reconstitute the hematopoietic compartment.
As few as 750 purified HSCs can maintain near-normal bone mass and architecture in lethally irradiated mice.
The approach allows for a better-defined model system without potential confounding factors.
Purified HSCs can selectively reconstitute hematopoietic lineage cells, making it useful for genetic studies.
The method can be used to investigate mechanisms by which hematopoietic lineage cells regulate bone metabolism.

nodes.title: Knee and Hip Joint Cartilage Damage from Combined Spaceflight Hazards of Low-Dose Radiation Less than 1 Gy and Prolonged Hindlimb Unloading
nodes.summary:
Knee and hip joint cartilage damage is caused by combined spaceflight hazards of low-dose radiation and prolonged hindlimb unloading.
The study examined the individual and combined effects of low-dose radiation and reduced weight bearing on cartilage in mice.
Results showed significant differences in cartilage volume and thickness between treatment groups and the control group.
Low-dose radiation caused a decrease in cartilage compositional proteins, indicative of osteoarthritis.
The study suggests that both reduced weight bearing and low-dose radiation lead to cartilage degradation and an arthritic phenotype.
Early administration of low-dose irradiation causes an active catabolic response in cartilage 24 days post-irradiation.
Further research is needed to prevent cartilage degradation from long-term periods of reduced weight bearing and spaceflight-relevant low doses of radiation.

nodes.title: International Space Station conditions alter genomics, proteomics, and metabolomics in Aspergillus nidulans
nodes.summary:
Aspergillus nidulans grown on the International Space Station (ISS) exhibited alterations in genomics, proteomics, and metabolomics.
ISS conditions altered the A. nidulans genome in specific regions, including intergenic mutations and missense mutations.
Proteomic analysis revealed differential abundance of proteins involved in stress response, carbohydrate metabolism, and secondary metabolite biosynthesis.
The laeA overexpression strain exhibited a mutation that resulted in the loss of the laeA stop codon, potentially curtailing enhanced secondary metabolite production.
ISS conditions increased production of asperthecin, an anthraquinone pigment, in two mutant strains, potentially serving as a protective mechanism against radiation.
The study highlights the potential of A. nidulans as a therapeutic production host in space and identifies specific genetic mutations involved in adaptive mechanisms.

nodes.title: Human Neural Stem Cells Flown into Space Proliferate and Generate Young Neurons
nodes.summary:
Human neural stem cells (NSCs) proliferate in space and express specific NSC markers.
These cells display higher oxygen consumption and glycolysis than ground controls.
NSCs in space maintain their ability to become young neurons.
Electrophysiological recordings show immature cell membrane properties and incipient action potential.
No spontaneous synaptic events are detected, suggesting an immature status.
The increased energy requirement of NSCs in space needs to be studied to design effective countermeasures for astronauts.
Understanding NSC behavior in microgravity can help develop countermeasures for astronauts and benefit patients on Earth with neurodegenerative disorders.

nodes.title: Structural and functional properties of bone are compromised in amyotrophic lateral sclerosis mice
nodes.summary:
Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is associated with increased incidence of skeletal fractures.
The SOD1 G93A mouse model exhibits decreased bone mass and compromised bone microarchitecture.
Trabecular bone mass and microarchitecture were deficient in SOD1 G93A mice, with 54% lower trabecular BV/TV.
Femoral cortical bone thickness and area were lower by 17% and 18% in ALS mice.
Bone functional properties, including bending stiffness and fracture toughness, were reduced in ALS SOD1 G93A mice.
The effective modulus and cortical micromechanical properties were similar in ALS SOD1 G93A mice and controls.
The study's findings imply multiple mechanisms for increased skeletal fragility and fracture risk in ALS patients.

nodes.title: The multiscale structural and mechanical effects of mouse supraspinatus muscle unloading on the mature enthesis
nodes.summary:
Muscle unloading affects the mature enthesis, increasing the risk of mechanical failure.
Unloading has minimal effects on the load-deformation behavior and elastic properties of the enthesis.
However, it compromises the failure properties, including strength and toughness of the attachment.
Changes in bone architecture, mineral crystal size, and orientation contribute to decreased energy absorption.
Unloading leads to a decrease in trabecular bone volume, thickness, and an increase in trabecular spacing.
Mineral crystal size and alignment are affected, potentially decreasing the toughness of the enthesis.

nodes.title: Proteomic characterization of Aspergillus fumigatus isolated from air and surfaces of the International Space Station
nodes.summary:
Proteomic characterization of Aspergillus fumigatus isolated from the International Space Station (ISS) revealed variations in the proteome compared to clinical isolates. 
ISS-isolated strains showed increased abundance of proteins involved in stress responses and carbohydrate metabolism. 
Proteins involved in trypacidin biosynthesis and toxin production were more abundant in ISS-isolated strains. 
The increased abundance of these proteins may contribute to the reported increased virulence of ISS-isolated strains. 
ISS-isolated strains also showed increased abundance of proteins involved in oxidative stress response. 
The study suggests that A. fumigatus adapts to the unique environment of the ISS by modulating its proteome. 
The findings have implications for understanding the behavior of microorganisms in space and potential risks to astronaut health.

nodes.title: Proteomic characterization of Aspergillus fumigatus isolated from air and surfaces of the International Space Station
nodes.summary:
Proteomic characterization of Aspergillus fumigatus isolated from the International Space Station (ISS) revealed variations in the proteome compared to clinical isolates. 
ISS-isolated strains showed increased abundance of proteins involved in stress responses and carbohydrate metabolism. 
Proteins involved in trypacidin biosynthesis and toxin production were more abundant in ISS-isolated strains. 
The increased abundance of these proteins may contribute to the reported increased virulence of ISS-isolated strains. 
ISS-isolated strains also showed increased abundance of proteins involved in oxidative stress response. 
The study suggests that A. fumigatus adapts to the unique environment of the ISS by modulating its proteome. 
The findings have implications for understanding the behavior of microorganisms in space and potential risks to astronaut health.

nodes.title: The Ca V 1.2 L-type calcium channel regulates bone homeostasis in the middle and inner ear
nodes.summary:
The L-type calcium channel CaV1.2 regulates bone homeostasis in the middle and inner ear.
It affects the development of the auditory ossicles and otic capsule through increased Ca2+ signaling.
Mice with the CaV1.2 TS mutant channel exhibit abnormal bone growth and reduced osteoclast function.
This leads to hearing impairment and vestibular dysfunction due to excessive bone formation and decreased bone resorption.
The CaV1.2 channel modulates the OPG/RANKL/RANK pathway, which is crucial for osteoclastogenesis.
Increased Ca2+ signaling through CaV1.2 upregulates OPG expression, inhibiting osteoclast formation.
The study provides insights into the pathophysiology of otosclerosis and potential therapeutic strategies.

nodes.title: Effects of ex vivo Ionizing Radiation on Collagen Structure and Whole-Bone Mechanical Properties of Mouse Vertebrae
nodes.summary:
Ionizing radiation exposure can cause bone to become brittle, leading to increased risk of fracture.
The effects of radiation on bone material were studied using ex vivo x-ray radiation on mouse vertebrae.
Radiation doses of 0, 50, 1,000, 17,000, and 35,000 Gy were used to assess changes in collagen structure and whole-bone mechanical properties.
Collagen fragmentation was found to be the primary molecular mechanism causing mechanical degradation at high radiation doses.
Non-enzymatic collagen crosslinks increased with radiation dose but did not coincide with reduced mechanical strength.
The study's findings have implications for safe sterilization of allografts and potential radioprotectants to preserve bone mechanics.

nodes.title: Multiscale effects of spaceflight on murine tendon and bone
nodes.summary:
Spaceflight affects the composition and structure of murine tendon and bone at the nanoscale. 
Decreased carbonate levels in bone and smaller collagen fibril diameters in tendons were observed. 
Gene expression changes indicated increased bone remodeling and collagen degradation. 
However, these changes did not result in significant alterations to the micro- and milliscale structure and mechanics of the tendon enthesis. 
The tendon enthesis appears to be robust against the negative effects of spaceflight. 
Increased expression of genes related to osteoclastogenesis and mature osteoblasts suggests increased bone remodeling. 
The lack of change in tendon enthesis mechanics may be due to the anatomy of the extremities being less sensitive to spaceflight than central locations such as vertebrae.

nodes.title: Effects of Spaceflight on the Mouse Submandibular Gland
nodes.summary:
Spaceflight affects the morphology and biochemistry of the mouse submandibular gland.
No significant changes in protein expression occurred in female mice flown for 13-15 days.
In male mice, increased labeling for salivary androgen binding protein alpha was seen after 30 days in space.
Epidermal growth factor and nerve growth factor labeling also increased in male mice after 30 days.
The response of the submandibular gland to spaceflight varies among glands and cell types.
The length of the flight and the sex of the animals may affect the response to spaceflight.
The findings suggest that evaluating changes in saliva protein levels may be useful for monitoring astronaut health during long-term spaceflights.

nodes.title: Effects of Spaceflight on the Mouse Submandibular Gland
nodes.summary:
Spaceflight affects the morphology and biochemistry of the mouse submandibular gland.
No significant changes in protein expression occurred in female mice flown for 13-15 days.
In male mice, increased labeling for salivary androgen binding protein alpha was seen after 30 days in space.
Epidermal growth factor and nerve growth factor labeling also increased in male mice after 30 days.
The response of the submandibular gland to spaceflight varies among glands and cell types.
The length of the flight and the sex of the animals may affect the response to spaceflight.
The findings suggest that evaluating changes in saliva protein levels may be useful for monitoring astronaut health during long-term spaceflights.

nodes.title: MetaMiner: A Scalable Peptidogenomics Approach for Discovery of Ribosomal Peptide Natural Products with Blind Modifications from Microbial Communities
nodes.summary:
MetaMiner is a software tool for discovering ribosomally synthesized and post-translationally modified peptides (RiPPs) from microbial communities. 
It integrates genome mining and computational mass spectrometry to identify RiPPs with unknown post-translational modifications. 
MetaMiner analyzes paired genome/metagenome assemblies and tandem mass spectra to identify putative biosynthetic gene clusters and precursor peptides. 
It constructs target and decoy databases of putative RiPP structures and matches tandem mass spectra against these databases. 
MetaMiner identified 31 known and seven unknown RiPPs from diverse microbial communities, including human microbiome and microorganisms from the International Space Station. 
The tool enables rapid search of large mass spectral and genomic/metagenomic datasets to discover novel RiPPs with potential applications in pharmaceutical and food industries. 
MetaMiner's performance was validated by the isolation and identification of the RiPP wewakazole from a cyanobacterial strain.

nodes.title: Comprehensive Multi-Omics Analysis Reveals Mitochondrial Stress as a Central Biological Hub for Spaceflight Impact
nodes.summary:
Spaceflight imposes significant changes on human physiology, 
with mitochondrial stress being a central biological hub. 
Multi-omics analysis reveals alterations in mitochondrial function, 
innate immunity, lipid metabolism, and gene regulation. 
These changes occur in both mice and humans, with evidence 
from NASA's GeneLab and the Twin Study supporting the findings. 
Mitochondrial dysfunction may lead to various health issues, 
including cardiovascular disease, muscle wasting, and immune dysregulation. 
Understanding the effects of spaceflight on mitochondria is crucial 
for developing effective countermeasures for long-term space missions.

nodes.title: Prolonged Exposure to Microgravity Reduces Cardiac Contractility and Initiates Remodeling in Drosophila
nodes.summary:
Prolonged exposure to microgravity reduces cardiac contractility and initiates remodeling in Drosophila.
Microgravity exposure resulted in significant reductions in end-diastolic diameters and cardiac output.
Hearts from flies exposed to microgravity showed myofibrillar remodeling and decreased sarcomere count.
Transcriptomic analysis revealed differential expression in extracellular matrix and proteasome regulatory genes.
Proteasome numbers were significantly increased in hearts from microgravity-exposed flies.
Microgravity exposure caused myofibrillar and extracellular matrix remodeling of the heart.
The study's findings have implications for understanding the effects of microgravity on human cardiac health.

nodes.title: Circulating miRNA Spaceflight Signature Reveals Targets for Countermeasure Development
nodes.summary:
Researchers identified a spaceflight-associated microRNA signature 
shared by rodents and humans in response to spaceflight conditions.
The signature includes 15 microRNAs that regulate various biological processes.
These microRNAs are involved in cell-cycle pathways, protein kinase activity, 
and hematopoiesis, and are associated with diseases such as cancer and cardiovascular disorders.
The study validated the signature using simulated microgravity, 
deep space radiation, and true spaceflight conditions in rodents and humans.
The results suggest that the microRNA signature can be used as a biomarker 
for spaceflight-induced damage and as a target for countermeasure development.

nodes.title: Plasma membrane disruption (PMD) formation and repair in mechanosensitive tissues
nodes.summary:
Plasma membrane disruptions (PMD) are a mechanism by which cells detect and respond to mechanical loading.
PMD formation and repair are critical for cell survival and tissue adaptation.
Mechanosensitive tissues, including skin, muscle, and bone, utilize PMD to coordinate cellular responses to mechanical stimuli.
PMD initiate signaling cascades that promote tissue adaptation and repair.
The rate of PMD repair can affect downstream cellular signaling and tissue adaptation.
Dysregulation of PMD formation and repair has been implicated in various diseases, including muscular dystrophy and cancer.
Understanding PMD mechanisms may lead to the development of novel therapeutic strategies for diseases related to mechanical loading and tissue adaptation.

nodes.title: Persistent NF-ÎºB activation in muscle stem cells induces proliferation-independent telomere shortening
nodes.summary:
Persistent NF-ÎºB activation in muscle stem cells leads to telomere shortening.
This shortening is independent of cell proliferation and occurs in response to chronic injury.
NF-ÎºB activation regulates Ku80 expression, a key component of the non-homologous end-joining pathway.
Downregulation of Ku80 results in telomere shortening in muscle stem cells.
Telomere shortening contributes to muscle stem cell exhaustion and impaired muscle regeneration.
NF-ÎºB-dependent telomere shortening is observed in both mouse models and human Duchenne muscular dystrophy patients.
This mechanism may contribute to the progression of muscular dystrophy and other diseases characterized by chronic inflammation.

nodes.title: THE INDIVIDUAL AND COMBINED EFFECTS OF SPACEFLIGHT RADIATION AND MICROGRAVITY ON BIOLOGIC SYSTEMS AND FUNCTIONAL OUTCOMES
nodes.summary:
Microgravity and radiation exposure are two major hazards to astronaut health during spaceflight. 
Prolonged exposure to microgravity can lead to muscle atrophy, bone loss, and vision impairment. 
Radiation exposure can cause damage to the central nervous system, cardiovascular system, and increase the risk of cancer. 
The combined effects of microgravity and radiation on the human body are not well understood and require further research. 
Ground-based analogues, such as hind limb unloading (HLU) and partial weight-bearing (PWB), are used to study the effects of microgravity on the body. 
These models have shown that microgravity can lead to bone loss, cardiovascular changes, and immune system suppression. 
Radiation exposure has also been shown to cause damage to the bone, cardiovascular system, and central nervous system. 
Further research is needed to understand the combined effects of microgravity and radiation on the human body and to develop effective countermeasures.

nodes.title: Dichotomous effects on lymphatic transport with loss of caveolae in mice
nodes.summary:
Lymphatic vessels play a crucial role in maintaining tissue homeostasis by transporting fluid and macromolecules from the interstitium. 
Caveolae, plasma membrane domains stabilized by caveolin-1, are involved in various cellular processes, including transport and signaling. 
Mice lacking caveolin-1 (CavKO) exhibit increased lymphatic conductance and permeability to macromolecules. 
However, the transport of macromolecules to the sentinel lymph node is reduced in CavKO mice due to impaired intrinsic contractility of collecting lymphatic vessels. 
Lymphatic-specific deletion of caveolin-1 (LyCav) recapitulates the lymphatic phenotypes observed in CavKO mice, including increased lymphatic conductance and reduced contractility. 
The reduced contractility in CavKO and LyCav mice is partially mediated by excessive nitric oxide production, which can be rescued by inhibiting nitric oxide synthase. 
Overall, caveolae play a critical role in regulating lymphatic function, and their loss leads to a dichotomous effect on lymphatic transport.

nodes.title: A Region of UNC-89 (obscurin) Lying Between Two Protein Kinase Domains is a Highly Elastic Spring Required for Proper Sarcomere Organization
nodes.summary:
The UNC-89 protein in C. elegans contains a region between two protein kinase domains called the interkinase (IK) region.
This region has low sequence complexity, high proline content, and lacks predicted secondary structure elements.
Single molecule force spectroscopy shows that the IK region behaves like an entropic spring.
Deletion of the IK region in UNC-89 results in disorganization of sarcomeres in body wall muscle.
The IK region is required for proper organization of sarcomeres and muscle function.
Mutants with the IK region deleted show defects in locomotion and muscle force generation.

nodes.title: Inter-agency perspective: Translating advances in biomarker discovery and medical countermeasures development between terrestrial and space radiation environments
nodes.summary:
The US government has made significant strides in radiation research, with NASA, NIAID, and NCI working together to develop medical countermeasures. 
NASA's primary concern is protecting astronauts from radiation exposure during long-duration space flights. 
NIAID focuses on developing medical countermeasures for radiation injuries following a radiological or nuclear incident. 
NCI's interest in radiation stems from its use in cancer treatments, with a goal of minimizing damage to surrounding normal tissues. 
The three agencies have overlapping research areas, including biomarker identification and product development. 
Collaboration between the agencies is crucial to accelerate progress and ensure the development of effective medical countermeasures. 
By working together, NASA, NIAID, and NCI can leverage their investments and expertise to address the challenges of radiation exposure.

nodes.title: Artificial Gravity Partially Protects Space-induced Neurological Deficits in Drosophila melanogaster
nodes.summary:
Drosophila melanogaster flies were studied on the International Space Station to understand spaceflight's effects on the central nervous system.
The study used a centrifuge to simulate Earth's gravity, allowing comparison between microgravity and artificial gravity conditions.
Flies in microgravity showed increased activity, behavioral deficits, and changes in brain morphology, including reduced neuronal cortex area.
Artificial gravity partially protected against these changes, suggesting its potential as a countermeasure for spaceflight-induced neurological deficits.
Proteomic and transcriptomic analyses revealed alterations in metabolic pathways, oxidative phosphorylation, and synaptic transmission in spaceflight flies.

nodes.title: An Analysis of the Effects of Spaceflight and Vaccination on Antibody Repertoire Diversity
nodes.summary:
analyzed the effects of spaceflight and vaccination on antibody repertoire diversity in mice.
The research used five datasets from four experiments to examine the impact of spaceflight on antibody repertoire diversity.
A trend toward lower diversity was found in flight animals, but no significant difference was detected.
The study also compared the effects of a physiological model of microgravity and spaceflight on antibody repertoire diversity.
The results showed that the bone marrow repertoire had lower diversity than the spleen repertoire in all animals.
The study found that vaccination with tetanus toxoid reduced diversity in the bone marrow, but not in the spleen.
The research highlights the importance of considering individual variability in antibody repertoire diversity.

nodes.title: 3D Oral and Cervical Tissue Models to Study Papillomavirus Host-Pathogen Interactions
nodes.summary:
Human papillomavirus (HPV) infection occurs in differentiating epithelial tissues. 
Two distinct methods are described to grow differentiating epithelial tissues: 
organotypic rafting and rotating wall vessel bioreactor. 
These approaches are applied to epithelial cells derived from HPV-positive and -negative oral and cervical tissues. 
The methods described allow for the generation of 3D tissues that mimic many critical morphological and biochemical aspects of in vivo tissue. 
The 3D tissue models can be used to study host-pathogen interactions and the viral life cycle. 
The protocols outlined provide a framework for establishing and analyzing 3D tissues to study HPV and its interactions with host tissues.

nodes.title: Evaluation of in vitro macrophage differentiation during space flight
nodes.summary:
Macrophage differentiation was evaluated during space flight on STS-126.
Mouse bone marrow cells were differentiated with recombinant M-CSF for 14 days.
Flow cytometry and gene microarray analysis were used to assess differentiation.
Significant differences in cell proliferation and gene expression were found.
1678 genes had altered transcript levels, including those involved in coagulation.
The coagulation pathway was broadly impacted, with 16 genes downregulated.
These changes may have implications for astronaut health and recovery from injury.

nodes.title: IRE1: ER stress sensor and cell fate executor
nodes.summary:
IRE1 is an ER transmembrane sensor that activates the unfolded protein response (UPR) to maintain ER and cellular function.
IRE1 promotes cell survival but can initiate apoptosis via decay of anti-apoptotic microRNAs.
The IRE1 signaling model involves splicing and RIDD to direct cell fate throughout ER stress.
IRE1Î± employs RIDD to degrade anti-Casp2 microRNAs, leading to activation of apoptotic initiator Casp2.
The phosphor-transfer function of IRE1Î± is essential for cell fate determination during ER stress.
IRE1 perceives developmental cues and protein folding homeostasis distinctly, and alterations of IRE1Î± substrate specificity determine cell fates.
Conserved and unique features exist between plant and mammalian IRE1, with IRE1Î± being a key regulator of ER stress-induced apoptosis in mammals.

nodes.title: Acute Exposure to High Dose Î³-Radiation Results in Transient Activation of Bone Lining Cells
nodes.summary:
High dose whole-body Î³-radiation results in a dramatic bone turnover response.
The increased turnover is temporally associated with bone marrow failure.
Bone marrow transplantation restores normal bone marrow function and bone turnover.
Radiation-induced bone loss is associated with increased osteoblast and osteoclast activity.
Bone lining cells are activated to express the osteoblast phenotype after irradiation.
The increase in osteoblast-lined bone perimeter is well established within 1 day of irradiation.
Bone marrow transplantation minimizes the development of skeletal abnormalities in lethally irradiated mice.

nodes.title: SIMULATED MICROGRAVITY ENHANCES OLIGODENDROCYTE MITOCHONDRIAL FUNCTION AND LIPID METABOLISM
nodes.summary:
Simulated microgravity enhances oligodendrocyte mitochondrial function and lipid metabolism.
Oligodendrocytes in simulated microgravity exhibit higher respiratory activity and glycolytic reserve capacity.
The increase in lipids suggests membrane synthesis, allowing more cell processes necessary for progression to the pre-myelinating stage.
Microgravity positively impacts lipid synthesis by oligodendrocytes, triggering their production faster than in 1G oligodendrocytes.
The study reveals significant changes in oligodendrocyte energetics and lipid metabolism in simulated microgravity.
The increase in cholesterol and other lipids in the secretome of oligodendrocytes after 3 days in microgravity indicates preparation for myelinogenesis.
The findings have implications for understanding the effects of microgravity on the central nervous system and for developing therapies for myelin-related disorders.

nodes.title: Maintaining the Factory: The Roles of the Unfolded Protein Response in Cellular Homeostasis in Plants
nodes.summary:
The unfolded protein response (UPR) is a signaling mechanism that maintains endoplasmic reticulum (ER) homeostasis in plants. 
The UPR is activated in response to environmental stresses, such as heat, oxidative stress, and chemical inhibitors. 
ER stress leads to the accumulation of unfolded proteins, which triggers the activation of UPR master regulators, including IRE1 and bZIP28. 
IRE1 mediates the splicing of bZIP60, a transcription factor that regulates UPR target genes. 
bZIP28 is trafficked to the Golgi apparatus, where it is cleaved and released to act as a transcription factor. 
The UPR has been implicated in various plant processes, including heat stress adaptation, defense against pathogens, and developmental regulation. 
Overall, the UPR plays a critical role in maintaining ER homeostasis and promoting plant survival under adverse environmental conditions.

nodes.title: A comparison of unamplified and massively multiplexed PCR amplification for murine antibody repertoire sequencing
nodes.summary:
Sequencing antibody repertoires has become cheaper and easier, often relying on PCR amplification prior to sequencing.
This study compared unamplified sequencing results from the murine splenic heavy-chain repertoire to those processed through commercial applications.
The use of mRNA for cDNA synthesis resulted in higher read counts, but reverse transcriptase and primer usage had no statistical effects.
Unamplified profiling detected more unique V-gene segments and high-frequency clones in the repertoire.
Amplified data sets had higher total read numbers and unique CDR3 numbers, but the unamplified data set captured 98% of the high-frequency CDR3s.
The study demonstrates that unamplified RNA sequencing can provide a realistic snapshot of the total splenic B cell repertoire.

nodes.title: NADPH Oxidase activity is required for ER stress survival in plants
nodes.summary:
NADPH Oxidase activity is required for ER stress survival in plants.
ER stress induces the accumulation of superoxide by NADPH Oxidases.
RBOHD and RBOHF contribute to the production of ROS during ER stress.
The UPR regulators influence RBOHD and RBOHF expression during adaptive UPR.
RBOHD and RBOHF are necessary for recovery from short-term and chronic ER stress.
RBOHD and RBOHF contribute to preventing ER stress-induced cell death.
The production of ROS is antagonized by IRE1 and the bZIP60/bZIP28 transcription factors.

nodes.title: In vitro generation of mechanically functional cartilage grafts based on adult human stem cells and 3D-woven poly(Îµcaprolactone) scaffolds
nodes.summary:
Three-dimensionally woven poly(Îµ-caprolactone) scaffolds were combined with adult human mesenchymal stem cells to engineer cartilage constructs in vitro.
The study aimed to produce mechanically functional cartilage constructs within 21 days, with effects of scaffold structure, culture vessel, and medium composition analyzed.
Aggregate moduli of 21-day constructs approached normal articular cartilage values for tightly woven scaffolds cultured in bioreactors.
Constructs cultured in bioreactors had higher aggregate modulus, total collagen content, and more homogeneous tissue development than static cultures.
Chondrogenic additives without serum yielded constructs with higher GAG content, earlier expression of collagen II mRNA, and more homogeneous immunostaining for Coll-II.
The GAG/DNA ratio exceeded previously reported values after prolonged in vitro cultivation, indicating efficient chondrogenic differentiation.
The study demonstrates the feasibility of functional cartilage tissue engineering from human mesenchymal stem cells and 3D-woven poly(Îµ-caprolactone) scaffolds.

nodes.title: nihms196166
nodes.summary:
The author's research spans over thirty years, focusing on the theory of tensegrity architecture in cells. 
The concept of tensegrity suggests that cells use tensional integrity to stabilize their shape and sense mechanical signals. 
This idea led to the discovery of the critical role of physical forces in developmental control and cellular mechanotransduction. 
The author's laboratory has demonstrated that many types of cells behave mechanically like tensegrity structures. 
Integrins have been identified as mechanoreceptors that transmit mechanical forces across the cell surface. 
The author's work has also led to the development of new technologies, including micromagnetic actuators and microfluidic systems. 
These technologies have the potential to transform medicine, particularly in the areas of tissue engineering and regenerative medicine. 
The author's research has also led to a deeper understanding of the importance of mechanical forces in cell function and tissue development.

nodes.title: DEVELOPMENT OF OTOLITH RECEPTORS IN JAPANESE QUAIL
nodes.summary:
The development of otolith receptors in Japanese quail was examined.
Morphological development of the otolith vestibular receptors was studied.
Epithelial growth, hair cell density, and stereocilia polarization were analyzed.
Afferent nerve innervation was also examined during development.
The study found that hair cell density and stereocilia polarization develop 
in a specific pattern during embryonic development. 
Afferent innervation patterns also develop in a specific sequence.

nodes.title: Spatial and temporal characteristics of vestibular convergence
nodes.summary:
Convergent neurons in the vestibular nuclear complex of pigeons receive inputs from both semicircular canals and otolith organs.
These neurons are sensitive to both rotational and linear translational motion, with spatial preferences that vary widely in head-centered space.
The canal and otolith response components of these neurons are spatially aligned, but have different gains and phases relative to the rotational stimulus.
The linear combination of canal and otolith response components does not predict the actual net response to earth-horizontal axis rotation.
The phase of the actual response is approximately in-phase with angular velocity, despite the phase offset introduced by the otolith response.
The spatial alignment of convergent inputs supports the idea that otolith signals cooperate with canal-driven reflexes to stabilize gaze during rotation relative to gravity.

nodes.title: Three Routes to Modulate the Pore Size of the MscL Channel/ Nanovalve
nodes.summary:
MscL is a bacterial mechanosensitive channel that can be used as a triggered nanovalve in various applications. 
The channel's pore size and conductance can be modulated through three routes: shortening the TM2/CB linker, 
constraining the region by cross-linking, or heavy metal coordination. 
Deletions within the TM2/CB linker lead to channels with decreased conductance. 
Disulfide cross-linking of the TM2/CB linker also decreases channel conductance, which can be restored by cleaving the disulfide bridges. 
Engineering a heavy metal binding site within the TM2/CB linker allows for reversible decreases in channel conductance. 
These modifications can be used to create MscL nanovalves with specific properties for use in nanodevices.

nodes.title: Increasing the Number of Unloading/Reambulation Cycles does not Adversely Impact Body Composition and Lumbar Bone Mineral Density but Reduces Tissue Sensitivity
nodes.summary:
Mice were exposed to one, two, or three cycles of hindlimb unloading and reambulation.
The final unloading cycle resulted in similar losses in total adipose tissue and vertebral bone mineral density across groups.
Previous exposure to unloading cycles attenuated the change in adipose, lean, and bone tissue during the last unloading cycle.
Four weeks of reambulation were sufficient for complete normalization of adipose and bone tissue to age-matched controls.
Upper hindlimb muscle cross-sectional area was significantly lower in all unloaded groups than in controls after reambulation.
The tissue volume at the beginning of the unloading period was highly predictive of the response to unloading.
Multiple unloading/reambulation cycles did not alter body mass, total adipose tissue, or vertebral bone density compared to a single unloading period.

nodes.title: Failure to Generate Bone Marrow Adipocytes Does Not Protect Mice from Ovariectomy-Induced Osteopenia
nodes.summary:
Ovariectomy (ovx) in mice leads to increased body fat and decreased bone mass.
Bone marrow adiposity increases after ovx in wild-type (WT) mice.
Kit W/W-v mice lack bone marrow adipocytes and have lower body fat than WT mice.
Ovx-induced changes in bone mass and architecture are similar in WT and kit W/W-v mice.
The absence of bone marrow adipocytes does not protect kit W/W-v mice from ovx-induced osteopenia.
Ovx results in increased bone turnover and decreased bone mass in both WT and kit W/W-v mice.
The findings suggest that bone marrow adipose tissue is not required for the development of osteopenia after ovx in growing mice.

nodes.title: Ehrlichia chaffeensis replication sites in adult Drosophila melanogaster
nodes.summary:
Ehrlichia chaffeensis is a Gram-negative bacterium that causes human monocytic ehrlichiosis.
It replicates in monocytes and macrophages in vertebrates, but its replication sites in arthropods are unknown.
Researchers used the UAS-GAL4 RNAi system in Drosophila melanogaster to silence two host genes, Uck2 and san.
Silencing these genes in hemocytes and fat body impaired E. chaffeensis infection, while silencing in eyes, wings, and salivary glands had no effect.
The results suggest that E. chaffeensis replicates in hemocytes and fat body in adult D. melanogaster.
This study provides insights into E. chaffeensis replication in arthropods and may help in understanding the tissue targets of the bacterium.

nodes.title: Chimeras reveal a single lipid-interface residue that controls MscL channel kinetics as well as mechanosensitivity
nodes.summary:
MscL is a bacterial mechanosensitive channel that serves as an osmotic emergency release valve.
The periplasmic region of the protein influences both open dwell time and threshold of channel opening.
A single residue at the TM1/periplasmic loop lipid interface controls channel kinetics and mechanosensitivity.
Hydrophobicity of this residue affects channel function, with more hydrophobic residues leading to longer open times.
Mutations at this site can cause severe hysteresis and delay in channel opening and closing.
The residue acts like a spring, adjusting the resistance for obtaining and stabilizing an open or closed channel structure.
The hydrophobicity of this spring element defines channel mechanosensitivity and kinetics in both Sa- and Eco-MscL.

nodes.title: Understanding macrophage differentiation during space flight: The importance of ground-based experiments before space flight
nodes.summary:
Macrophage differentiation was investigated in two in vitro culture systems, 
the Techshot Cell Cult Bioreactor and the BioServe Fluid Processing Apparatus (FPA). 
The devices were operated in different orientations to determine their impact on macrophage growth and differentiation. 
Results showed significant differences in macrophage recovery and cell surface molecule expression. 
The bioreactor and FPA orientations affected cell recovery, with horizontal orientations yielding more viable cells. 
The expression of F4/80 and other differentiation markers varied depending on the culture device and orientation. 
These findings highlight the importance of understanding the impact of culture systems on experimental outcomes, particularly in space flight research.

nodes.title: Chronic Skeletal Unloading of the Rat Femur: Mechanisms and Functional Consequences of Vascular Remodeling
nodes.summary:
Chronic skeletal unloading diminishes hindlimb bone blood flow and induces vascular remodeling.
Seven and 14 days of skeletal unloading alter femoral bone and marrow blood flow and vascular resistance during reloading.
The principal nutrient artery of the femur undergoes remodeling, with decreased intraluminal diameter and medial wall thickness.
This remodeling normalizes shear stress and circumferential wall stress in the artery during unloading.
However, it may limit bone and marrow blood flow capacity and contribute to elevated vascular resistance during reloading.
The study suggests that chronic skeletal disuse can have adverse effects on bone structure and health due to insufficient perfusion.
Vascular remodeling in response to unloading may impair the ability to increase blood flow and nutrient delivery to bone and marrow upon return to weight-bearing activity.

nodes.title: INTER-REGULATION OF THE UNFOLDED PROTEIN RESPONSE AND AUXIN SIGNALING
nodes.summary:
The unfolded protein response (UPR) is a signaling network triggered by overload of protein-folding demand in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER). 
The UPR is critical for growth and development, but connections between the UPR and other cellular regulatory processes remain largely unknown. 
This study identifies a link between the UPR and the phytohormone auxin, a master regulator of plant physiology. 
ER stress triggers down-regulation of auxin sensors and transporters in Arabidopsis thaliana. 
The plant UPR has evolved a hormone-dependent strategy for coordinating ER function with physiological processes. 
IRE1, an ER stress sensor, is required for auxin response and homeostasis, and ER-localized auxin regulators are involved in UPR activation. 
The inter-regulation between the UPR and auxin response opens a new area of investigation in plant physiology, highlighting a plant-specific strategy to maintain balance between stress response and growth regulation.

nodes.title: Altered Disc Compression in Children with Idiopathic Low Back Pain: An Upright MRI Backpack Study
nodes.summary:
Children with idiopathic low back pain (ILBP) experience less disc compression at T12-L1 to L4-5 with increasing backpack load.
ILBP children have less lumbar lordosis and more pain in response to backpack load compared to normal children.
The 4 kg and 8 kg backpacks significantly compressed the L5-S1 disc height in ILBP children.
Backpack load was positively associated with disc compression at L1-L2, L4-L5, and L5-S1.
ILBP children could not tolerate the 12 kg backpack due to pain and further testing with that weight was abandoned.
Increasing backpack load did not affect lumbar asymmetry or lumbar lordosis in ILBP children.
Pain with backpack loading was significantly worse in ILBP subjects while standing and at all loads in comparison to normal children.

nodes.title: Molecular mechanisms underlying the enhanced functions of three-dimensional hepatocyte aggregates
nodes.summary:
Three-dimensional culture of hepatocytes leads to improved synthetic and metabolic functions.
Global gene expression analyses revealed distinct genes upregulated in 3D culture compared to monolayer culture.
Hepatocyte nuclear factor 4Î± (Hnf4a) binding sites were over-represented in the promoter regions of upregulated genes.
Hnf4a expression was increased in 3D aggregate cultures, maintaining hepatocyte-specific functions.
Mesenchymal and cytoskeletal genes were suppressed in 3D aggregates, inhibiting epithelial-mesenchymal transition.
Three-dimensional cell-cell interactions are crucial for maintaining Hnf4a expression and hepatocyte functions.
These findings provide a basis for designing biomaterials that optimize hepatocyte functions for in vitro and in vivo applications.

nodes.title: Spaceflight and hind limb unloading induce similar changes in electrical impedance characteristics of mouse gastrocnemius muscle
nodes.summary:
Spaceflight and hind limb unloading induce similar changes in electrical impedance characteristics of mouse gastrocnemius muscle.
The phase-slope parameter was significantly lower in both spaceflight and hind limb unloading mice compared to controls.
For control and hind limb unloading groups, the phase-slope values were 23.9Â±1.6Â°/MHz and 19.0Â±1.0Â°/MHz, respectively.
For ground control and spaceflight groups, the values were 24.7Â±1.3Â°/MHz and 14.1Â±1.6Â°/MHz, respectively.
The phase-slope parameter correlated with muscle fiber size and hind limb areal bone mineral density.
These results support the concept that electrical impedance myography may serve as a useful tool for assessment of muscle disuse secondary to immobilization or microgravity.
The study suggests that electrical impedance myography could be used to monitor muscle health in astronauts and patients with musculoskeletal disorders.

nodes.title: Exercise Training Augments Regional Bone and Marrow Blood Flow during Exercise
nodes.summary:
Exercise training increases regional bone and marrow blood flow during exercise in rats.
The study found that exercise training augmented blood flow in 7 of 9 bone regions measured.
In sedentary rats, exercise increased blood flow in only 3 of 9 bone regions.
The increase in blood flow was associated with increased vascular conductance in exercise-trained rats.
Exercise training may enhance bone health by increasing blood flow and interstitial fluid flow.
The study suggests that exercise training can improve bone perfusion and vascular function.
The findings have implications for the prevention and treatment of osteoporosis and other bone-related disorders.

nodes.title: Organization of the ER-Golgi interface for membrane traffic control
nodes.summary:
The ER-Golgi interface is a critical component of the secretory pathway in eukaryotic cells.
It is responsible for bidirectional membrane trafficking between the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) and the Golgi.
The COPI and COPII coat complexes play essential roles in this process, with COPII facilitating anterograde transport and COPI mediating retrograde transport.
The organization of the ER-Golgi interface varies across different species, with mammalian cells having a distinct ERGIC compartment and plant cells having a more compact ER-Golgi unit.
The morphology of the ER-Golgi interface is influenced by the type of cargo being transported and the cellular architecture.
Understanding the regulation of the ER-Golgi interface is crucial for insights into the mechanisms that control protein and lipid trafficking in the early secretory pathway.

nodes.title: Mimicking the host and its microenvironment in vitro for studying mucosal infections by Pseudomonas aeruginosa
nodes.summary:
Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a leading cause of life-threatening nosocomial infections. 
In vitro cell and tissue culture models have been used to study P. aeruginosa pathogenesis. 
These models include two-dimensional monolayers, air-liquid interface cultures, and three-dimensional cell culture models. 
Each model has its advantages and limitations, and the choice of model depends on the research question being addressed. 
The host microenvironment, including factors such as apical-basolateral polarity, junctional complexes, and extracellular matrix proteins, affects P. aeruginosa pathogenesis. 
Mucus and cilia also play important roles in the infectious disease process. 
Multicellular complexity, including the presence of immune cells and the indigenous microbiota, is another important factor to consider. 
Other host factors, such as iron, oxygen, pH, and nutrients, can also impact P. aeruginosa pathogenesis. 
Understanding these factors is crucial for developing effective antimicrobial therapies.

nodes.title: Fifteen Days Microgravity Causes Growth in Calvaria of Mice
nodes.summary:
Mice exposed to 15 days of microgravity on the STS-131 mission showed increased bone volume in their calvariae. 
The mean bone volume of the spaceflight group was 10.48%, compared to 9.64% for the ground control group. 
Cross-sectional thickness also showed a trend of increase, from 0.099mm in the ground control group to 0.104mm in the spaceflight group. 
Tissue mineral density remained similar between the two groups, with 0.878g/cc for the ground control group and 0.893g/cc for the spaceflight group. 
The spaceflight group experienced more aggressive weight loss, with an average loss of 2.82 grams, compared to 1.51 grams for the ground control group. 
Despite the weight loss, the calvariae of the spaceflight group demonstrated volume expansion, contradicting the observed changes in body weight. 
The study suggests that microgravity causes adaptive growth in non-weight-bearing bones, possibly due to head-ward fluid shifts.

nodes.title: Overexpression of CupB5 activates alginate overproduction in Pseudomonas aeruginosa by a novel AlgW-dependent mechanism
nodes.summary:
Pseudomonas aeruginosa is an opportunistic pathogen that produces alginate, 
a protective exopolysaccharide, in response to environmental stresses. 
The production of alginate is regulated by the AlgU pathway, 
which is activated by the degradation of the anti-sigma factor MucA. 
A novel regulator of alginate production, CupB5, has been identified, 
which activates the AlgU pathway through a mechanism dependent on AlgW. 
Overexpression of CupB5 induces mucoid conversion and alginate overproduction 
in P. aeruginosa, and this effect is mediated by a peptide signal in CupB5. 
The CupB5 peptide stimulates OMP-activated AlgW cleavage of MucA and 
partially relieves MucB inhibition, allowing the initiation of AlgU signaling. 
This study reveals a new mechanism for the regulation of alginate production 
in P. aeruginosa, highlighting the complexity of the AlgU pathway.

nodes.title: Partial Reductions in Mechanical Loading Yield Proportional Changes in Bone Density, Bone Architecture, and Muscle Mass
nodes.summary:
Researchers investigated the effects of reduced weight bearing on the musculoskeletal system using a partial weight suspension (PWS) model.
The study found a linear relationship between the degree of unloading and bone and muscle loss in mice.
Bone mineral density, trabecular bone volume, and cortical bone area decreased with decreasing weight bearing.
Muscle mass also decreased with decreasing weight bearing, with the soleus muscle being more affected than the gastrocnemius muscle.
Even a 30% reduction in weight bearing led to significant bone deterioration and muscle atrophy.
The PWS model was found to be a useful tool for studying the effects of reduced weight bearing on the musculoskeletal system.

nodes.title: Morbid Obesity Attenuates the Skeletal Abnormalities Associated with Leptin Deficiency in Mice
nodes.summary:
Leptin-deficient ob/ob mice exhibit a unique skeletal phenotype characterized by low bone mass and density.
The skeletal abnormalities in ob/ob mice are associated with decreased bone formation and impaired osteoclast function.
Pair-feeding ob/ob mice to wild-type mice prevents morbid obesity and exacerbates the skeletal abnormalities.
The prevention of morbid obesity in ob/ob mice leads to further decreases in bone mass, density, and cortical bone volume.
The skeletal effects of leptin deficiency are attenuated by morbid obesity, suggesting a complex relationship between leptin, obesity, and bone metabolism.
Leptin plays a critical role in regulating bone growth, maturation, and turnover, and its deficiency has profound effects on the skeleton.
The study's findings have implications for understanding the relationship between obesity, leptin, and bone health in humans.

nodes.title: Type 2 diabetes alters bone and marrow blood flow and vascular control mechanisms in the ZDF rat
nodes.summary:
Type 2 diabetes alters bone and marrow blood flow and vascular control mechanisms.
The study used the Zucker diabetic fatty rat model to investigate the effects of type 2 diabetes on skeletal vascular control.
Endothelium-dependent vasodilation was reduced in long-term diabetic rats compared to lean controls.
Norepinephrine and myogenic vasoconstriction were enhanced in long-term diabetic rats.
Bone and marrow perfusion and vascular conductance were lower in long-term diabetic rats.

nodes.title: Expressing and Characterizing Mechanosensitive Channels in Xenopus Oocytes
nodes.summary:
Xenopus oocytes are used for heterologous expression of mechanosensitive channels. 
The oocyte system offers advantages for studying plant and bacterial mechanosensitive channels. 
Methods for expressing and characterizing mechanosensitive channels in Xenopus oocytes are described. 
The process involves surgery, oocyte isolation, and preparation, as well as in vitro RNA production and injection. 
Patch-clamp and pressure-clamp techniques are used to characterize mechanosensitive channel activity. 
The inside-out patch configuration is preferred for characterization of mechanosensitive channels. 
Endogenous mechanosensitive channel activity in oocytes can be inhibited or blocked to facilitate characterization of heterologously expressed channels.

nodes.title: Lifelong Wheel Running Exercise and Mild Caloric Restriction Attenuate Nuclear EndoG in the Aging Plantaris Muscle
nodes.summary:
Lifelong wheel running exercise and mild caloric restriction attenuate nuclear EndoG in the aging plantaris muscle.
Nuclear EndoG levels were significantly higher in old rats than in young rats, while caloric restriction and wheel running with caloric restriction attenuated this increase.
HSP27 protein content and phosphorylation at Ser82 were lower in old rats than in young rats, but were increased by caloric restriction and wheel running with caloric restriction.
AIF and HSP70 were unaltered by caloric restriction or wheel running with caloric restriction in aging muscle.
The study suggests that caloric restriction and wheel running with caloric restriction protect against age-related elevation of caspase-independent apoptotic signaling.
The protective effects of caloric restriction and wheel running with caloric restriction on EndoG signaling may be linked to the upregulation of HSP27.
The findings indicate that HSP27 is a primary stress protein target by daily, voluntary running exercise combined with mild caloric restriction.

nodes.title: Unfolded protein response in plants: one master, many questions
nodes.summary:
The unfolded protein response (UPR) is a cytoprotective response that helps cells manage endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress. 
In plants, the UPR involves ER-localized stress sensors that activate distinct downstream signaling pathways. 
Plant UPR studies have identified conserved and unique features compared to yeast and metazoans. 
The IRE1-mediated splicing of transcription factor (TF) mRNA is a conserved strategy for UPR gene regulation. 
However, the splicing output and TF targets differ among eukaryotes, suggesting independent evolution of IRE1-TF targets. 
The diversification of IRE1 signaling in plants includes the activation of a transcription factor and regulated IRE1-dependent decay (RIDD). 
The mechanisms of IRE1 activation and the roles of multiple IRE1 isoforms in plants are still unknown and require further research.

nodes.title: Hypothalamic Leptin Gene Therapy Reduces Body Weight without Accelerating Age-Related Bone Loss
nodes.summary:
Hypothalamic leptin gene therapy reduces body weight in skeletally mature female rats.
The therapy leads to a 17% reduction in body weight and an 80% reduction in abdominal white adipose tissue weight.
Food intake is lower in treated rats, with a 9% reduction in total food intake over 18 weeks.
Serum leptin and IGF1 levels are lower in treated rats, which may have positive effects on cardiovascular disease and cancer risk.
The therapy has minimal effects on bone mass, density, and microarchitecture, contrasting with the negative skeletal effects of caloric restriction-induced weight loss.

nodes.title: Age-related alterations in the sarcolemmal environment are attenuated by lifelong caloric restriction and voluntary exercise
nodes.summary:
Aging results in compromised integrity of the sarcolemmal environment in skeletal muscle fibers.
Lifelong mild caloric restriction and voluntary wheel running mitigate age-related alterations in the sarcolemmal environment.
Disruption of dystrophin-glycoprotein complex proteins, including dystrophin and Î±-syntrophin, occurs with aging.
Aging is associated with increased abundance of membrane repair proteins, such as MG53 and dysferlin.
Lifelong caloric restriction and wheel running maintain membrane repair proteins at near-control levels.
The Nox2 complex, a source of oxidative stress, is reduced with aging, but maintained by lifelong wheel running.
Lifelong caloric restriction and wheel running may prevent age-related impairment of muscle quality and sarcopenia.

nodes.title: Environmental cues and symbiont microbe-associated molecular patterns function in concert to drive the daily remodelling of the crypt-cell brush border of the Euprymna scolopes light organ
nodes.summary:
The squid-vibrio symbiosis exhibits daily modifications of the brush border that supports the symbionts. 
Effacement and repolarization occur on a daily rhythm in adult animals, at the dawn expulsion of symbionts into the environment. 
Symbiont colonization of the juvenile host induces an increase in microvillar density. 
Environmental cues and symbiont microbe-associated molecular patterns function in concert to drive the daily remodelling of the crypt-cell brush border. 
The remodelling of the crypt brush borders begins in juvenile animals and requires influences from both an environmental light cue and interaction with the microbe-associated molecular patterns of symbiont cells. 
The daily changes in the adult brush border occur in juveniles, and are associated with venting, which is affected by the time and influenced by symbiotic state of the animal. 
The increase in microvillar density is induced by phosphorylated lipid A of symbiont cells.

nodes.title: Leptin Stimulates Bone Formation in ob/ob Mice at Doses Having Minimal Impact on Energy Metabolism
nodes.summary:
Leptin stimulates bone formation in ob/ob mice at doses having minimal impact on energy metabolism.
The dose-response effects of leptin administration on serum leptin and indices related to energy metabolism were studied.
Leptin increased osteoblast perimeter, mineralizing perimeter, and bone formation rate at an infusion rate of 4 ng/h.
Bone formation parameters were increased at EC 50 ranging from 7-17 ng/h, whereas higher leptin levels were required to impact energy metabolism.
The study suggests that leptin acts peripherally to couple bone acquisition to energy availability, with limited transport across the blood-brain barrier ensuring that growth-promoting actions are not curtailed by CNS-mediated anorexigenic actions.

nodes.title: Room Temperature Housing Results in Premature Cancellous Bone Loss in Growing Female Mice: Implications for the Mouse as a Preclinical Model for Age-Related Bone Loss
nodes.summary:
Female mice housed at room temperature experience premature cancellous bone loss.
Thermoneutral housing prevents this bone loss and increases cancellous bone volume fraction.
The beneficial effects of thermoneutral housing are associated with increased bone formation and decreased bone resorption.
Housing temperature impacts energy partitioning, with thermoneutral-housed mice having higher percent body fat and lower Ucp1 gene expression.
Thermoneutral housing also affects gene expression related to bone metabolism, including increased expression of genes involved in osteoblast differentiation and function.
The study suggests that thermoneutral housing may be an approach to minimize the impact of adaptive thermogenesis in preclinical studies using female mice as a model for age-related bone loss.
Thermoneutral housing has implications for the use of mice as a preclinical model for osteoporosis and other metabolic bone diseases.

nodes.title: Osteocyte Apoptosis Caused by Hindlimb Unloading is Required to Trigger Osteocyte RANKL Production and Subsequent Resorption of Cortical and Trabecular Bone in Mice Femurs
nodes.summary:
Osteocyte apoptosis is essential for activating bone remodeling in response to disuse.
Hindlimb unloading causes a significant increase in osteocyte apoptosis in both cortical and trabecular bone.
The increase in osteocyte apoptosis precedes the increase in bone resorption.
Osteocyte apoptosis triggers an increase in RANKL-producing osteocytes, leading to bone resorption.
Inhibition of osteocyte apoptosis using a pan-caspase inhibitor prevents bone resorption and loss.
The study suggests that osteocyte apoptosis plays a central role in triggering bone resorption in response to disuse.
Osteocyte apoptosis is a common final pathway for activating and targeting bone resorption in response to diverse stimuli.

nodes.title: Spaceflight-Induced Bone Loss Alters Failure Mode and Reduces Bending Strength in Murine Spinal Segments
nodes.summary:
Spaceflight reduces the bending properties of spinal segments in mice. 
Bending strength is reduced by 17% and the nonlinear toe region is shortened by 32%. 
Flight mouse spinal segments tend to fail within the growth plate and epiphyseal bone. 
Control specimens tend to fail at the disc-vertebra junction, a common source of failure in human disc herniation injuries. 
Spaceflight significantly reduces vertebral bone volume fraction, bone mineral density, and trabecular thickness. 
These changes in bone properties may contribute to the increased risk of disc herniation in astronauts. 
The study's findings have implications for the development of countermeasures to prevent bone loss and disc herniation during spaceflight.

nodes.title: Intrauterine exposure to maternal stress alters Bdnf IV DNA methylation and telomere length in the brain of adult rat offspring
nodes.summary:
Intrauterine exposure to maternal stress alters Bdnf IV DNA methylation and telomere length in the brain of adult rat offspring.
Males exposed to prenatal stress had greater methylation in the medial prefrontal cortex compared to non-stressed male controls and stressed females.
Prenatally-stressed animals had shorter telomeres than controls in the medial prefrontal cortex.
The study used a rodent model of unpredictable, variable prenatal stress to test the hypothesis that a stressful environment in utero can render epigenetic and telomeric changes in the brain of offspring.
The findings highlight the capacity of in utero stress to leave its epigenetic and telomeric mark within specific regions of the brain.
The study provides seminal evidence for an enduring influence of prenatal stress on both brain DNA methylation and telomere length in adulthood.

nodes.title: Prolonged Exposure to Particulate Chromate Inhibits RAD51 Nuclear Import Mediator Proteins
nodes.summary:
Prolonged exposure to particulate hexavalent chromium (Cr(VI)) inhibits the nuclear import of RAD51, a crucial protein in homologous recombination repair.
Cr(VI) exposure induces the subcellular mislocalization of RAD51 nuclear import mediator proteins, RAD51C and BRCA2.
The cytoplasmic accumulation of RAD51C and BRCA2 corresponds temporally with previously reported Cr(VI)-induced RAD51 cytoplasmic accumulation.
RAD51C deficiency alone can induce RAD51 cytoplasmic accumulation, suggesting that Cr(VI)-induced RAD51C inhibition contributes to RAD51 mislocalization.
Cr(VI) exposure does not inhibit the interaction between RAD51 and its nuclear import mediators, RAD51C and BRCA2.
The mechanism of Cr(VI)-induced inhibition of nuclear import may involve the binding of Cr ions to the nuclear localization signal or alterations in post-translational modifications necessary for nuclear import.
Prolonged Cr(VI) exposure may play a key role in its carcinogenic mechanism by inhibiting the nuclear import of tumor suppressor proteins and DNA repair proteins.

nodes.title: Novel organelles with elements of bacterial and eukaryotic secretion systems weaponize parasites of Drosophila
nodes.summary:
Parasitoid wasps of the genus Leptopilina produce virus-like particles (VLPs) 
that play a crucial role in their parasitism of Drosophila hosts. 
The VLPs lack viral coat proteins but contain a diverse array of proteins, 
including eukaryotic vesicular transport system proteins and immunity-related proteins. 
Some VLP proteins have sequence similarities with bacterial secretion system proteins, 
suggesting a possible evolutionary link between the two. 
The VLPs are structurally similar to eukaryotic microvesicles and may have evolved 
from a common ancestor with bacterial outer membrane vesicles. 
The discovery of these novel organelles provides new insights into the evolution 
of parasitism and the complex interactions between parasites and their hosts. 
The VLPs may also have potential applications in the development of new therapies 
for treating emerging infections and opportunistic diseases.

nodes.title: Orchestrating rapid long-distance signaling in plants with Ca 2+ , ROS and electrical signals
nodes.summary:
Plants respond to environmental stresses through rapid systemic signaling networks.
These networks involve the transmission of signals from the site of stress perception to distal parts of the plant.
A trio of messengers, including reactive oxygen species (ROS), Ca2+, and electrical signals, play a key role in this process.
The signals are propagated through the plant at speeds exceeding 1000 Î¼m sec-1, allowing for rapid preparation of distant tissues for impending challenges.
The role of plasmodesmata (PD) in facilitating cell-to-cell communication and signal propagation is still unclear.
The plant cell wall may also influence signal transmission, with its unique chemical environment and potential to limit or facilitate the movement of signaling molecules.
The integration of systemic signaling with other cellular processes, such as transcriptional regulation and post-translational modification, is essential for plant responses to environmental stresses.

nodes.title: Validation of Methods to Assess the Immunoglobulin Gene Repertoire in Tissues Obtained from Mice on the International Space Station
nodes.summary:
Spaceflight affects immune cell populations, including a decrease in splenic B cell numbers. 
To study the impact of spaceflight on the antibody repertoire, a workflow was developed using Next Generation Sequencing and bioinformatic tools. 
The workflow was validated using Illumina MiSeq sequencing data from normal C57Bl/6J mice. 
Three sample preparation methods were compared: cells, tissue, and size-selected tissue. 
Size selection yielded the highest number of antibody sequences, including productive and unknown functionality sequences. 
The workflow was also applied to Illumina HiSeq data from the Rodent Research 1 NASA validation flight. 
Reference mapping and whole genome mapping methods were compared, showing strong correlations in V-gene segment usage. 
The developed workflow can be used for future studies on the antibody repertoire, including those examining the immune response to vaccination during spaceflight. 
The study provides a foundation for understanding the effects of spaceflight on the immune system and the development of effective immune responses.

nodes.title: Effects of hypothalamic leptin gene therapy on osteopetrosis in leptin-deficient mice
nodes.summary:
Leptin-deficient ob/ob mice exhibit a mild form of osteopetrosis due to impaired bone resorption.
The osteopetrotic phenotype is not entirely self-limiting, as cartilage matrix persists in ob/ob mice into adulthood.
Hypothalamic leptin gene therapy restores leptin signaling in ob/ob mice and reduces cartilage matrix in bone.
The reduction in cartilage is associated with increased bone turnover, as evidenced by increased osteoblast and osteoclast perimeters.
Leptin plays a crucial role in regulating bone growth and turnover, and its deficiency contributes to skeletal defects.
The skeletal response to leptin is site-specific, with robust bone turnover occurring in cancellous bone compartments.
Leptin gene therapy promotes maturation of cancellous bone and increases bone formation and resorption in ob/ob mice.

nodes.title: Comparative transcriptomics indicate changes in cell wall organization and stress response in seedlings during spaceflight
nodes.summary:
Arabidopsis thaliana seedlings were grown in spaceflight during the STS-131 mission to study the effects of microgravity on gene expression.
The transcriptome of the seedlings was analyzed using microarray technology and compared to ground controls.
The results showed changes in gene expression related to cell wall organization, stress response, and hypoxia.
The cell wall composition was also analyzed using glycome profiling, which revealed differences in xylan and pectic components.
The study compared the results of three investigative teams that used the same hardware and biological materials, but with different sample preparation methodologies.
The comparison showed similarities and differences in the microarray data among the three studies, highlighting the importance of considering experimental differences.
The study's findings support the idea that stress response pathways and cell wall structure are altered in spaceflight, with implications for plant growth and development in microgravity environments.

nodes.title: A novel blue-light phototropic response is revealed in roots of Arabidopsis thaliana in microgravity
nodes.summary:
A novel blue-light phototropic response is revealed in roots of Arabidopsis thaliana in microgravity.
This response is masked by gravity and is attenuated at 0.1g, but not present at higher gravity levels.
The magnitude of red-light positive phototropic curvature is correlated to the magnitude of gravity.
A 1-h red-light pretreatment enhances the blue-light phototropic response in roots.
The phototropic response in roots is affected by light quality, gravity, and position.
The relationship between phototropism and gravitropism is complex and poorly characterized.
The study provides new insights into the interaction between light and gravity in plant growth and development.

nodes.title: A novel blue-light phototropic response is revealed in roots of Arabidopsis thaliana in microgravity
nodes.summary:
A novel blue-light phototropic response is revealed in roots of Arabidopsis thaliana in microgravity.
This response is masked by gravity and is attenuated at 0.1g, but not present at higher gravity levels.
The magnitude of red-light positive phototropic curvature is correlated to the magnitude of gravity.
A 1-h red-light pretreatment enhances the blue-light phototropic response in roots.
The phototropic response in roots is affected by light quality, gravity, and position.
The relationship between phototropism and gravitropism is complex and poorly characterized.
The study provides new insights into the interaction between light and gravity in plant growth and development.

nodes.title: A novel blue-light phototropic response is revealed in roots of Arabidopsis thaliana in microgravity
nodes.summary:
A novel blue-light phototropic response is revealed in roots of Arabidopsis thaliana in microgravity.
This response is masked by gravity and is attenuated at 0.1g, but not present at higher gravity levels.
The magnitude of red-light positive phototropic curvature is correlated to the magnitude of gravity.
A 1-h red-light pretreatment enhances the blue-light phototropic response in roots.
The phototropic response in roots is affected by light quality, gravity, and position.
The relationship between phototropism and gravitropism is complex and poorly characterized.
The study provides new insights into the interaction between light and gravity in plant growth and development.

nodes.title: Effects of spaceflight on the immunoglobulin repertoire of unimmunized C57BL/6 mice
nodes.summary:
Spaceflight has been shown to suppress the adaptive immune response, altering lymphocyte populations.
B lymphocytes express highly specific and diversified receptors, known as immunoglobulins (Ig), that bind and neutralize pathogens.
Ig diversity is achieved through enzymatic splicing of gene segments within the genomic DNA of each B cell.
The collection of Ig specificities within a host, or Ig repertoire, has been characterized using high-throughput sequencing technology (HTS).
This study utilized HTS to test the hypothesis that spaceflight affects the B-cell repertoire of unimmunized C57BL/6 mice flown aboard the ISS.
Individual gene segment usage was similar between ground control and flight animals, with no significant differences in top V-gene segments or D-, J-gene segment usage.

nodes.title: Morphology of the Utricular Otolith Organ in the Toadfish, Opsanus tau
nodes.summary:
The utricle in the adult oyster toadfish, Opsanus tau, is an elongated sac with a utricular duct and recess.
The utricular macula is divided into three zones: lateral extra-striola, striola, and medial extra-striola.
Hair cell density varies across these zones, with the lateral extra-striola having the highest density.
Afferent innervation patterns also differ across the zones, with those in the medial extra-striola having the greatest complexity.
The otolith mass is composed of calcium, oxygen, and phosphorus, and its size and shape are consistent with other teleost species.
The utricular afferents have distinct morphological parameters, including axonal length, volume, and number of nodes and bouton terminals.

nodes.title: Response of the mouse sublingual gland to spaceflight
nodes.summary:
Mice were flown on space shuttles Discovery and Atlantis to study the effects of spaceflight on sublingual glands.
No differences in mucous acinar or serous demilune cell structure were observed between flight and ground control mice.
The expression of parotid secretory protein (PSP) in sublingual demilune cells was significantly increased in STS-131 flight mice.
Mucin (Muc19) expression in acinar cells and PKA-RII expression in demilune cells were increased in STS-131 flight mice and decreased in STS-135 flight mice.
Demilune cell and parotid protein (DCPP) was slightly decreased in mice from both flights.
The results indicate that the response of salivary glands to spaceflight conditions varies among different glands, cell types, and secretory proteins.
The spaceflight environment modifies protein expression, which may lead to the development of noninvasive methods to assess the physiological status of astronauts.

nodes.title: NemaFlex: A microfluidics-based technology for standardized measurement of muscular strength of C. elegans
nodes.summary:
C. elegans is a genetic model for studying muscle strength and its decline in diseases and aging.
A microfluidics-based system, NemaFlex, measures muscular strength by pillar deflection as the nematode crawls through a forest of pillars.
The system is optimized for robust measurement conditions, yielding a measure of strength independent of behavior and gait.
A scaling factor accounts for animal size, enabling comparative strength studies of mutants.
NemaFlex can reliably score muscular strength in C. elegans, detecting muscle strength weakness in mutants.
The system has potential applications in genetic and drug screens, defining molecular and cellular circuits of neuromuscular function, and dissecting degenerative processes in disuse, aging, and disease.

nodes.title: Cortical Thinning and Structural Bone Changes in Non-human Primates Following Single Fraction Whole Chest Radiation
nodes.summary:
Rapid cortical thinning and loss of bone mineral density occurred in non-human primates after whole chest radiation.
The changes were dependent on both dose and skeletal maturity, with younger animals more sensitive to radiation.
Cortical thinning was observed in the in-field vertebrae by 2 months post-irradiation and persisted to 8 months.
Bone mineral density loss was observed by 4 months post-irradiation in the in-field vertebrae and by 6 months in the out-of-field vertebrae.
Histological analysis showed increased cortical porosity in regions with the greatest degree of cortical thinning.
Younger age at irradiation was associated with greater sensitivity to radiation and increased mortality due to pneumonitis.
The study highlights the significance of early radiation-induced bone changes and their dependence on dose and skeletal maturity.

nodes.title: Candida albicans Colonization Modulates Murine Ethanol Consumption and Behavioral Responses Through Elevation of Serum Prostaglandin E2 and Impact on the Striatal Dopamine System
nodes.summary:
Candida albicans colonization reduces ethanol consumption in mice.
Elevated serum PGE2 levels are associated with reduced ethanol preference.
PGE2 injection decreases ethanol consumption in a dose-dependent manner.
EP1 and EP2 receptor antagonism reverses the reduction in ethanol consumption.
C. albicans colonization alters dopamine receptor expression in the dorsal striatum.
C. albicans-colonized mice develop ethanol-induced conditioned taste aversion more rapidly.
C. albicans colonization increases susceptibility to ethanol-induced motor coordination deficits.

nodes.title: The effect of spaceflight on the gravity-sensing auxin gradient of roots: GFP reporter gene microscopy on orbit
nodes.summary:
The distribution of auxin in the primary root of Arabidopsis thaliana is not dependent on gravity.
Auxin gradients in the root tip are established independently of gravity.
The auxin distribution in spaceflight-grown plants is identical to that of ground controls.
Cytokinin distribution, however, is different in spaceflight-grown plants compared to ground controls.
The spaceflight environment does not affect the expression of auxin-related genes in the root tip.
The results suggest that auxin gradients in the primary root are fundamentally developmental and not dependent on gravity.
The study used GFP reporter gene systems to visualize gene expression in distinct cell types of the primary root tip.

nodes.title: Effects of angular frequency during clinorotation on mesenchymal stem cell morphology and migration
nodes.summary:
Human mesenchymal stem cells (hMSCs) respond to clinorotation by adopting more rounded, less-spread morphologies. 
The angular frequency-dependence suggests that a cell's ability to sense the changing gravity vector is governed by the rate of perturbation. 
Cell area distributions indicated a greater inhibition of cell spreading with higher angular frequency. 
Cells at 75 rpm clinorotation remained viable and were able to re-spread after clinorotation. 
In chemotaxis chambers, clinorotation did not alter migration patterns in elongated cells, but most clinorotated cells exhibited cell retraction, which strongly compromised motility. 
The cellular response to simulated microgravity is more dominant than chemotactic signals, suggesting the role of migration of hMSCs to tissue repair sites might be suppressed in microgravity. 
The results indicate that hMSCs can behave differently depending on clinorotation speed, with changes in cell morphology approaching a limit at an angular frequency close to 75 rpm.

nodes.title: Spaceflight-induced vertebral bone loss in ovariectomized rats is associated with increased bone marrow adiposity and no change in bone formation
nodes.summary:
Spaceflight-induced vertebral bone loss in ovariectomized rats is associated with increased bone marrow adiposity. 
The bone loss is due to increased bone resorption with no change in bone formation. 
Ovariectomized rats flown in space had 32% lower cancellous bone area and 306% higher marrow adipose tissue. 
The increased adiposity was due to an increase in adipocyte number and size. 
Mineral apposition rate and osteoblast turnover were unchanged during spaceflight. 
The findings indicate that cancellous bone loss during spaceflight is accompanied by increased bone resorption and marrow adiposity. 
The results suggest that mesenchymal stem cells are diverted to adipocytes at the expense of forming osteoblasts during spaceflight.

nodes.title: Evaluation of rodent spaceflight in the NASA animal enclosure module for an extended operational period (up to 35 days)
nodes.summary:
The Animal Enclosure Module (AEM) was tested for its ability to support rodents for up to 35 days. 
The study found that the AEM could support 12 adult female C57BL/6 mice for 35 days with self-contained food and water. 
The AEM also supported 5 adult male Sprague-Dawley rats for 35 days with external replenishment of food and water. 
No significant differences were found in animal health evaluations, growth, and body masses between AEM-housed and vivarium-housed animals. 
The results demonstrated the capability and flexibility of the AEM to operate for up to 35 days with minor hardware modifications. 
The study showed that the AEM can be used for extended operational periods, making it suitable for use on the International Space Station or other spaceflight vehicles. 
The AEM's ability to support rodents for extended periods has implications for long-term space life science research, enabling studies of up to 90 days.

nodes.title: Exposure of Mycobacterium marinum to low-shear modeled microgravity: effect on growth, the transcriptome and survival under stress
nodes.summary:
Mycobacterium marinum was grown under low-shear modeled microgravity (LSMMG) to study its effects on growth and survival.
LSMMG cultures transitioned from exponential phase earlier than normal gravity (NG) cultures, with a 50% reduction in optical density.
The transcriptome of LSMMG-exposed M. marinum showed significant changes, with 562 and 328 genes altered after short and long exposure times, respectively.
LSMMG induced a reduction in translation, downregulation of metabolism, and increased expression of chaperone and mycobactin genes.
Sigma factor H (sigH) was the only sigma factor transcript induced by LSMMG, and was implicated in the LSMMG transcriptome response.
